story:
In 2009 the Biodynamic Education Centre was founded by Lynette West to ensure the work she had done over the previous 25 years was continued. At the Centre we are working to bring the hopes and dreams of our founder to life.

Lynette believed that every person had the right to grow food full of energy and nutrients and that this right extended to the generations to follow. For this reason she wrote courses which took the work of Rudolf Steiner and presented it in an easy to understand way. She spent over 10 years developing and refining the Foundation course and it has earned parise from almost everyone who has attended it.

This project is to convert the Foundation Course into a digital form. We have footage of Lynette presenting the course and hope to create a digital version of the course that can be experienced and enjoyed by anyone, anywhere.

We are asking help from the community to bring this dream to reality and allow us to show people how to grow amazing food and keep their land healthy while they do it.

story:
Victoria (Tori) needs help to win a scholarship

Tori maintains a 4.0 GPA and excels at Basketball and track despite the grueling schedule and hardships associated with life on a poor Native American Indian reservation in Eastern Washington.

Currently, she is in her high school basketball season, she’s a 4 year varsity player. She has recently been asked by the Spokane Legacy Select Basketball Team to travel with them to all NCAA Sanctioned basketball tournaments. Here is where she will get the needed exposure, to play in front of college scouts and coaches at all levels. I would like to be able to assist her in any way possible to make this happen for her. She would love to not only play on this team, but possibly be in contact with prospective coaches to ensure her goals of playing basketball at the collegiate level. To finish college and be an asset to our Tribal Community

The goal of this fundraiser is for Tori to be able to travel and play in several Basketball tournaments this spring and summer in order to showcase her skills to NCAA college scouts who would be able to offer her an athletic scholarship.

For Tori to play in all five tournaments will cost about $8,500 before Indiegog and donation collection fees for travel, lodging, food and Team fees.

The costs break down as follows:

Hotel and meals for all 5 tournaments for 4-5 days each is $4,500.
Airfare for Portland, Seattle and San Diego through Southwest Airlines will be about $2,500 depending on when we can buy the flights. Team fees $1,200 (uniforms, travel gear, tournament fees, etc).

If we raise less than the total we are seeking Tori will still attend as many of the tournaments as we can afford. If we raise more than is necessary to attend all five of the tournaments the extra funds will be held in a scholarship found for Tori.

Please help us by making a contribution today, no matter how small, it all helps.

Her is some more information about my daughter:

She is a 4.0 student, an overall of a 3.98. She has dreams and aspirations of becoming a Doctor. She is currently applying for any and all scholarships to assist her in paying for college. She is active in the FBLA (Future Business Leaders of America) at school, has taken the heaviest coursework as a senior with two independent classes of Physics and Calculus which she’s getting a 4.0 in. She’s studied Spanish since JR High and also knows her Salish Language of her tribe. Victoria is also active in our Tribal Community as she is a part of the Tribal Youth Council, works evenings when she isn’t at practice at the Tribal Youth Center with At-Risk Youth, volunteers with the VFW Post, Head Start Program. Even though she left the Reservation school, this is still her home and interacts with everyone on a daily basis. Never thinking she’s better than anyone, always trying to help anyone in need. As she once put it, I may have worn my non-native shoes off the reservation, but my moccasins always bring me back. She is a huge role model for all here in both academics and sports. She is also a phenomenal X-Country and Track Runner…..3 Sport State Contender for 3 years.

Her drive and determination has set standards for many of the young here and off the reservation. Her love for her community, her culture, to prove that all Natives are capable of following and attaining their dreams; a soft-spoken, humble individual with an old soul; she has overcome the obstacles of drugs, alcohol, teenage pregnancy and presented herself as a very respectable young lady.

Here is some more information from Tori's coach:

January 4, 2013

RE: Spokane Legacy Elite Basketball Club

To Whom This May Concern:

Spokane Legacy Elite Basketball is a non-profit organization that was created to encourage high school athletes to play at the collegiate level.  It was designed for the purpose of promoting current unsigned high school players to colleges and universities throughout the country.

Last year, in Spokane Legacy Elite Basketball’s first year, they promoted four seniors to the college ranks.  Both the Spokane Legacy 15U and Spokane Legacy 18U teams traveled to the following NCAA sanctioned events to gain exposure outside of the Spokane region:

  1. Phoenix, Arizona
  2. Yakima, Washington
  3. Portland, Oregon
  4. Seattle, Washington
  5. Las Vegas, Nevada

As well as the above mentioned tournaments, Spokane Legacy played in 3 local NCAA sanctioned events in Spokane, Washington. 

This spring/summer, Spokane Legacy is planning to attend the same tournaments as in 2012 with the exception of the Las Vegas tournament.  Instead of Las Vegas, the Spokane Legacy Elite Basketball Program is planning to attend San Diego, California to finish up their summer.

Each team consists of a maximum of 12 available spots.  Each of the 12 kids is certified with the NCAA sanction in order to be included in a program at each of the above mentioned tournaments.  At each of the tournaments, college scouts are in attendance and use the booklet in order to learn about the whereabouts of the player(s).  College coaches are, by law, able to recruit during each of those tournaments. 

Last year, the cost of participation with Spokane Legacy Elite Basketball was $1,175.00/participant.  This cost included the following: team uniform, team practice jersey, team shooting shirt, team travel bag, team warm-up top and bottom, all gym rentals, and all entries into each NCAA sanctioned event. 

Please help support the individuals in Spokane Elite Basketball.  This program will benefit greatly with the support of local businesses and families.  Without support, it is very difficult for interested college athletes to get an opportunity to play basketball at the collegiate level.

If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to contact me at bswannack@reardan.net or via phone at (509) 981-1094.

Sincerely, 

Bob Swannack, Spokane Legacy Elite Basketball

Thank you in advance for any help you can give to make Tori's dreams come true.

Tori's Mom, Joni Wynecoop

Other ways you can help.

If a financial contribution isn't possible for you right now, you can still help. We welcome all the assistance we can get just spreading the word.  You can email friends, post to Facebook, Twitter and any other social networks you use.......whatever you feel is appropriate to do.  Indiegogo has some great share tools that make it easy.  

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

story:
History of the HighWaterLine Project

HighWaterLine was a public art project enacted on the streets of New York City in 2007. For 6 months, artist Eve Mosher drew a blue chalk line along the 10' above sea level line throughout Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan as a way to draw attention to climate change issues in NYC. This was an artistic strategy for inviting conversations about climate change in the very neighborhoods that are projected to be impacted by a rise in sea level over the next century and how citizens can participate in addressing lifestyle changes that need to happen now. 

Why the HighWaterLine Learning Project?

For the HighWaterLine Learning Project, Mosher is partnering with Patricia Watts, founder of ecoartspace, to develop a learning guide for educators and youth to re-enact the HighWaterLine project in their own neighborhoods. The guide will provide the resources and tools to assist educators in developing citizen science activities combined with aesthetic inquiry that can offer unique opportunities for understanding climate change, ecology, science in empowering ways.


The project is an amazing experience in which to participate. Along with the learning gained from the research they will do, participants get a chance to explore their own neighborhoods inviting new ways of being and seeing in an aesthetic presentation on city streets. It is also an opportunity for them to have conversations with neighbors, build community, and bear witness to the potential impacts of each individual. Mosher's own experience creating the project was life-changing, and she wants to be able to share the project with other communities. It is important to the artist that the project be carried out by community members themselves, and not as a solo performance by Mosher. 


Where the Money Will Go...

The HighWaterLine Learning Project will include development of a guide which will be made available free of charge to educators around the world. The guide will be flexible enough to be applicable to students ages 10-20, as well as adults, and will be designed to meet a wide range of education standards.


$3,000 that's all - it pays the fee for the guide development and writing, graphic design of the guide, and a limited edition printing. The final product will be an approximately 20-page guide in PDF format, available for download on the internet. Next year after educators have the opportunity to use the guide with their students, there will be another round of fundraising for the development of an interactive website with the help of the educators feedback.


Who are Eve & Patricia?

Eve Mosher is the artist who conceived, developed and enacted the HighWaterLine project in 2007. This was her first public/interventionist/interactive artwork, which set her on a path of working on projects with communities in mind. She was so powerfully moved by the experience of creating work that engaged people in the neighborhoods in which they lived and worked, that she has continued to develop projects in that vein in the years since. The HighWaterLine project received international press attention for its ability to translate a complex issue into a visually high impact project that also allowed for interaction. A HighWaterLine | Dublin is currently being planned for early 2012.


Patricia Watts is the founder of ecoartspace and west coast curator who specializes in artists who address environmental issues internationally. She has written art and environmental education activities for public schools and advocates for trans-disciplinary learning for both in school and after school programs. Watts feels that the HighWaterLine project is a transformative learning opportunity for schoolchildren to build critical spatial or visual thinking skills in areas of math, science, ecology and art. Exercising students ability to imagine the future, while using their minds and bodies to explore and delineate the world we live in now, is an invaluable educational activity.

What Else Can You Do?

Make sure you spread the word! Your money can go further if you get friends to donate also. Use the share tools and promote the project on FaceBook and Twitter. Tell your favorite organizations and groups so they can promote it also.

Want to Make it Tax Deductible?

You can make a donation directly through New York Foundation for the Arts, or ecoartspace.

story:
Short Summary

Dear Family, Friends, & Supporters,
I am Destiny M. Bush. I attend South
Carolina State University, entering my sophomore year.I am pursuing my bachelor
degree in English. My dream is to educate students of minority in our
Multicultural schools to become better communicators through writing. I am
collecting funds for the upcoming school year.
Last year I earned a 2.7 GPA
and grew tremendously on a spiritual and emotional level. This semester I plan
maintain 3.0 or above GPA. This summer I was an intern at the Internal Revenue
Service (IRS) and furthered my education by taking a creative writing course at
my church.
Unfortunately this upcoming school year I have had major financial
setbacks. My mother is recovering from surgery and currently not working. My dad
became unemployed earlier this year and cannot support me as much as he'd like.

Your contribution at this time will help me purchase textbooks and other
educational supplies. In addition, your financial support will allow me to focus
more on my academics. Any and all donations will be greatly accepted and
appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

Textbooks and other educational supplies

  • Over the summer I did research on how much my text books will cost for the fall semter.The amount is $600.
  • The funds will go towards my fall and spring semster textbooks for the 2012-2013 school year.

The Impact

The impact that your dontations will have on me  is knowing I have support from many wonderful people.

  • My project is valuable to the contributor and to the world because I can teach many childern around the world how to read the American English lanuage.
  • Since I been in college I have worked at the IRS over the summer where I have recieved an award for outstanding youth.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also helo by keeping me in your prayers and encouraging me.

story:
Who I am:

My name is Raphael Henrique Buthmann , 17 years old , Brazil - Rio de Janeiro.

I'm a Industrial Designer student at UFRJ-School of Fine Arts and a Hobbie Content Creator for a Game.

What I do:

Since 2008 I have been studying how to render and how to model objects.

I ended up falling for Industrial Design, I studied to pass the exam to college and got the first position. I've always been very dedicated to their studies, because I knew I could not afford a private college. I got a place in the second best college Brazilian Industrial design - UFRJ - School of Fine Arts.

Also, since that time, I am a member of a forum for a game called "Racer" and I've been adding content to it.

 Why I need your help:

My course at University doesn't allow me to have a job and I have time only to do my homework. I live with my granparents, because my mother has a psychological disease and not know my father. So I can not afford to buy a new computer. I had a good economical conditions when I bought one , but not anymore.


I know the amount of money is a little bit high...but here in Brazil , things are extremely more expensive than on USA. We pay almost 2 times the price of things because of taxes of importations and etc.

Without a new computer, I can't continue my render projects and learn new methods/techniques.

What i will do with the money:

I'm going to buy me a new computer and a design table.

Some pictures of my arts:

story:
Our Story

My First Pregnancy is an interactive installation based on experiences, awakenings, and challenges of pregnancy depicted through my own experience and 40 weeks of research.  This piece will invite the audience to investigate the daunting challenges of pregnancy on body, mind, and way of life in the spirit of funhouses, amusement rides, science exhibits, and other spectacles of entertainment and wonder. Pregnancy is so common yet so alien and with this piece I intend to shed light on the gravitas of changes taking place each day, week, month, and trimester.  

The structure of the piece consists of two main areas, one is a "ride" and the other is a series of interactive stations. The ride is much like a dark ride where viewers are taken through spaces with living-breathing animatronics enveloped in projection as they re-enact content based around home videos of my fiancé and I talking about the many events and emotions we went through during my pregnancy. This includes clashes with anti-abortion clinics, searching for health insurance as a pre-existing condition, unemployment, co-habitation, anxieties about diet, weight, health, rushes to the emergency room, the inevitable labor and more. 

The interactive "stations" are designed after displays in children's science museums and games or booths in amusement parks. The stations include magic mirrors where one sees the anatomical changes of pregnancy on their own body, video games challenging the player to know what is safe to eat during pregnancy eat before nausea takes hold, baby developmental stages as fruits and vegetables in jars of goo,and plush pregnant appendages to try on with simulated baby movement reacting to sound and touch. Sources for the stations include The Mayo Clinic Guide to Pregnancy, What to Expect When You’re Expecting, Birthing from Within, Dr. Cecilia Hann of Valencia OBGYN Associates and prenatal courses.

My First Pregnancy is on schedule to be exhibited at The California Institute of the Arts in April 2012. The design of the project is focused on flexibility of the stations and possibly the ride to travel for public outreach education in the hopes that it can further the educational reach about pregnancy to clinics, universities, high schools, and more. It currently is supported by a Calarts Interdisciplinary Grant, Valencia OBGYN Associates, and more.

 

The Impact and Influences

A major conceptual influence for this piece is Mary Kelly’s Post Partum Document, 1973-1978.  Kelly documented in rigorous scientific detail her son’s first five years, the resulting records were then framed and presented in galleries.  I feel this piece was a powerful testament to the amount of work put in as a mother and I want to pursue the prenatal experience with a similar approach.  Although it’s common knowledge that women go through a lot in pregnancy, I want to elaborate on just how much physical change a woman has to endure.  But physical changes are just a part of the transformation, which is why I am combining our own story to exemplify the external through religious, financial, political, and social forces. Other influences from Pop Art, Terry Gilliam, Tony Oursler, Gretchen Hogue, Pippilotti Rist, and Bjorn Melhaus inform the aesthetics and approach. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5,000 dollars in order to complete the set design, individual stations and installation costs for the ride/exhibit. We have a few grants from outside sponsors but we need your help! This is a great experience for women and men of all ages in order to educate themselves about the experiences of bringing a baby into this world.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please like us on Facebook and help us get the word out for our project!

Sources for the stations include The Mayo Clinic Guide to Pregnancy, What to Expect When You’re Expecting, Birthing from Within, Dr. Cecilia Hann of Valencia OBGYN Associates and prenatal courses.
My First Pregnancy is on schedule to be exhibited at The California Institute of the Arts in April 2012. The design of the project is focused on flexibility of the stations and possibly the ride to travel for public outreach education in the hopes that it can further the educational reach about pregnancy to clinics, universities, high schools, and more. It currently is supported by a Calarts Interdisciplinary Grant, Valencia OBGYN Associates, and more.
 


The Impact and Influences
A major conceptual influence for this piece is Mary Kelly’s Post Partum Document, 1973-1978.  Kelly documented in rigorous scientific detail her son’s first five years, the resulting records were then framed and presented in galleries.  I feel this piece was a powerful testament to the amount of work put in as a mother and I want to pursue the prenatal experience with a similar approach.  Although it’s common knowledge that women go through a lot in pregnancy, I want to elaborate on just how much physical change a woman has to endure.  But physical changes are just a part of the transformation, which is why I am combining our own story to exemplify the external through religious, financial, political, and social forces. Other influences from Pop Art, Terry Gilliam, Tony Oursler, Gretchen Hogue, Pippilotti Rist, and Bjorn Melhaus inform the aesthetics and approach. 
 


What We Need & What You Get
We need $5,000 dollars in order to complete the set design, individual stations and installation costs for the ride/exhibit. We have a few grants from outside sponsors but we need your help! This is a great experience for women and men of all ages in order to educate themselves about the experiences of bringing a baby into this world. 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Please like us on Facebook and help us get the word out for our project!

story:
Short Summary

The Temple Panthers Football Organization consists of Over-Looked Athletes (ages 18 & up) with diverse backgrounds and skills that have not the opportunity to compete on the football field since high school and/or College. Some athletes had opportunities but were unsuccessful by losing focus; becoming young Fathers out of high school, some are in Tech Colleges where there’s no Athletic program, also getting involved with law enforcement, abusing drugs and alcohol and poor choices while in college.

The Temple Panthers Organization has set a goal and that is to successfully develop a program where "Over Looked Athletes" can get exposure not only in the area of sports, but also in the community arena.  We want these young men to see that they can become successful and productive in their lives as well as communities.

Temple Panthers mentoring, as a team, is effective and our concept is for participants to receive support and advice, and as a result, will support and advice to others. Your contribution will assist Temple Panthers Athletes who desire to share their testimonies on local television.  The hope is to touch the lives of other young athletes who have also been over looked. We have trained volunteer coaches and committed staff waiting to make a difference in individual lives with prevention and developmental family crisis training, Drug and Alcohol, Career/Jobs development, Financial Advice, as well as Spiritual Growth to list a few.

What we need & what you get

The Temple Panthers Organization needs $25,000 dollars to help fund their Over Looked Athletes Mentorship Program.  $5,000 will be applied towards a local TV ad campaign where current athletes will speak to the public telling their own personal story.  Funds raised will be applied toward office space to conduct mentorship classes, Education Counseling, purchasing 20 laptops for job training, recording and duplication equipment to reach top scouts, stadium rental fees for home games, gear for 60 team members, community network for youth programs, youth training camps, advertisement, bus transportation, storage fees, and broadcasting which costs $20k alone.  With these areas in place, Athletes will be encouraged and have a more positive attitude toward pursuing their goals in life.  More importantly, we want to offer a professional environment.

If we're unable to reach our funding goal, we will conjoin with other mentorship programs in the community and continue to raise funds. All funds will be used in a combined effort to improve the program.

The Impact

We believe this community based mentorship program will keep young athletes off the streets and involved in the community.  Further, our desire is to provide a positive environment encouraging athletes to once again, realize and embrace their dreams of achieving their goals in education and athletics. 

During our first year, the Mentorship Program was successful in developing players toward a top college and an Arena League football team. With your contribution, we’ll have more success stories to boast about with the use of television, media and internet.

There is no other sports program in the local area that’s geared towards helping Over Looked Athletes (18 & above) to achieve their educational goals, further develop athletic skills, and provide mentorship.

Other Ways You Can Help

We need educators, counselors, pro athletes that would be willing to provide advice and guidance to these young athletes.  Also, you are our biggest advertisement – please spread the word about the Over Looked Program to young athletes seeking to succeed.  Your voice helps! 

The use of Indiegogo share tools is a Blessing. We as an Organization encourage others to use it and have others to visit the website.

story:
Anita Lesko & Abraham Nielsen, both Autistic, are about to be wed with the first-ever ALL-AUTISTIC Wedding.  They defy ALL stereotypes of Autism.  They are on a mission to change the world's view of Autism!  They are going public with their wedding to show the world that Autistic people ARE capable of love, relationships, and marriage, and that they desire these very same things as everyone else.

Every human being desires to be loved and to love, and to feel included.  That's just basic needs.  Autistic people are often discriminated against, and looked up as not  having emotions, or typical human desires.  That's all a myth.  They are just like every other human being.  They just might not show it like others do. 

The latest statistics from the CDC shows that 1 in every 68 children is being diagnosed with Autism.  These children will eventually grow up to become adults.  Every parent of an Autistic child worries about what will become of their child when they grow up.  Anita & Abraham are here to give them hope that their child CAN grow up to have a happy and fulfilling life, and find love, a relationship, and marriage.

Anita & Abraham decided to get married at the Love & Autism Conference on September 26, 2015 in San Diego.  This is the first step in their journey to change the world's view of Autism.   Joey Travolta (yes, John's older brother!) will be sending his film crew from Inclusion Films to make a documentary of Anita & Abraham's wedding, including the Rehearsal, Rehearsal Dinner, the wedding ceremony, cake cutting, their First Dance, and interviews of all the great people in their wedding party.   The purpose of this film is to give the millions of parents with Autistic children the hope that their child will have a happy and fulfilled life.  It also is intended to give inspiration to the millions of Autistic people that they can find love, relationships, and marriage. 

Anita & Abraham's epic love story will inspire everyone to venture beyond their comfort zone.  They both have a coffee mug which reads, "Life Begins At The End of Your Comfort Zone."  They are proof of that!

Every dollar donated for the production of this documentary will help the parent who cries themselves to sleep at night worrying about a lonely life they fear for their Autistic son or daughter when they become an adult.  The magnitude of taking that pain away is priceless.  Every parent wants the best for their child.  Please help Anita & Abraham on their journey to Change the World's View of Autism.

All donations received will go directly to the film team for the actual costs of the following:
A 6 person film crew including a Director, Director of Photography, 3 crew members and support staff.  Editing and actual production of the documentary are also included in the costs.

story:
Help us raise $32,000 to scholarship a minimum of 40 kids to our STEM-oriented summer camp!

The Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics knowledge areas are some of the primary topics of discussion for the United States Department of Education. In order to compete in an ever-evolving global society, kids need to be prepared with the right knowledge base and develop quantitative reasoning skills. Our Summer Technology Enrichment program will help students develop fundamental skills in these fields in an interactive, fun setting! We will offer a series of structured 10 day sessions that will focus on developing base proficiency in the area of computer science using a hands on method. Regardless of what kids ultimately choose to pursue, these skills will be beneficial in the world of tomorrow!

We live in the age of technology. With the many technological advances that have taken place over the years, technical literacy has become of increasing importance. If we encourage the understanding of these skills amongst the youth, we will equip them with a knowledge base for life.





Ultimately, our goal is to encourage lifetime learners who are excited about math & science while providing a fun and engaging atmosphere. Buffalo STEP will be a bi-weekly 10 day technology and educational urban camp experience that leverages our city's cultural resources to promote education. The camp will be designed for kids, ages 10 to 14, and hosted by Ethan Redd, the creator of the video game “8Bit Ninjas” for the OUYA. The program will feature daily sessions that focus on mathematics, sciences, and computer programming. Additionally, the camp will include educational field trips and optional quality breakfasts, lunches, and snacks. Each day will begin at 8:30am and end at 4:30pm.

The daily schedule will include lessons, activities, tutoring, and games to enforce the subject matter. Participants will have opportunities to work individually and in groups while further developing critical thinking and socialization skills while working on projects that illustrate the theoretical concepts at play. On select days, the city will be our campus; participants will visit local cultural institutions to encourage the use of the educational resources that the city has to offer. 


Prior to beginning his studies as a Computer Science and Electrical Engineering major at New York University, Ethan Redd was a home schooled student with a passion for technology and design. From a young age, Ethan studied the rudiments of programming, computer science, and computer generated imaging (CGI) to gain the skills necessary to see his ideas to fruition. After a year of independent production, he released his debut title ‘8Bit Ninjas’ on the OUYA platform (Summer 2013), and is currently in the process of further development and bringing the game to additional platforms.

As a video game designer and student, Ethan has experienced the life of being a STEM field student first hand, and desires to share his findings with kids from the City of Buffalo. He will share his knowledge in the areas of math, science, and computers, as well as tips and tricks, resources, and much more.



Our objective is to conduct a series of 10 day technology-themed enrichment day camps throughout the summer of 2014, where participants will cultivate a base understanding of computer science and its relation to other fields such as mathematics and the natural sciences. We will provide participants with a quality experience that will inspire an affinity towards lifetime learning and self-study.



We believe that by providing a quality, fun and engaging experience, kids will embrace the information and apply it to their studies and ideally, their daily lives. Our goal is to provide the best experience and resources to our participants to further promote a love for learning and an appreciation for the S.T.E.M. disciplines.



In order to serve a minimum of 40 children over the course of 6 weeks, we will need to raise $32,000 to scholarship participants.

Children in the Buffalo area will benefit from your contribution. There are also special “perks” to contributing to our campaign. The different perks are made available in exchange for your generosity.

We value each contribution and appreciate your support!


If you cannot make a contribution, you can still help us bring this project to reality! You can help us by spreading the word and sharing this page with your family, friends, co-workers, etc.


Thank you for the support!

story:
So you're wondering, "What is Buppl?"

First conceived by 3 undergrad students (who also happen to be siblings) at the University of New Mexico, Buppl will be an online platform that enables university students to connect with each other in an easy and fun way.

College can be a rough time for a lot of kids, and whether it is social, academic, or economic areas of life that are impacted, it's not always easy.

During our college experience (which is still ongoing, by the way) we quickly realized that making college a lot less stressful is all about leveraging connections. And that got us thinking: "What better way to do that than through a mobile app? After all, most college kids have mobile phones of some kind."


Feature Breakdown


Now for a breakdown of Buppl’s main features…

Buppl will use the power of social media to change the university experience for the better. Sound like fun? Check out the features this upcoming mobile app will have!

·  A GPS-based map chatting system so students can easily stay connected with each other on campus

·  A local university marketplace, where students can buy and sell products and services among each other

·  A tutoring system: every student can tap into the knowledge of other students by looking for student tutors at the university

·  A Club feature allows any student to create and browse clubs, bringing like-minded students together at a university

·  Classes, Events, and other features ensure that students have the power to thrive both academically and socially

The important thing to emphasize here is that Buppl will provide a platform for student connections on a local level. That means that a student of UNM will only connect with other students at UNM, students at UW will connect with other students at UW, etc. Cool? Cool. 

We'll also keep Buppl completely free for students to use, because we know how valuable a quarter can be on laundry day. Or when you're starving for a snack out of the vending machine.


Why Buppl?

There currently isn’t any one, central hub for students of any given university to connect with each other, collaborate, and sell their products and services to other students (which would be very useful and beneficial to the university community as a whole). That’s why we’ve decided to create something that does exactly this – and we call it Buppl!


This is Buppl team member David.

Buppl makes it easier for college students to thrive both academically and socially. Tutors will be around every corner, ready to help a fellow college kid in distress, and Buppl’s chat system means that students will always know what’s going on around them – whether it’s a demonstration that’s being planned or something less newsworthy.

In short, given that people are increasingly managing different parts of their lives through online interfaces, we think that it’s time for those in a university setting to have the right tools to do this.


We will initially launch Buppl at UNM (and other colleges throughout New Mexico) during the fall semester of 2014. After we’ve successfully established a presence in New Mexican institutions of higher learning, we’ll take Buppl to campuses across the United States – so if you’re currently a college kid, keep your eyes peeled for Buppl on your campus because we’ll be heading your way!


Why Indiegogo?

College kids don’t have a reputation for being particularly wealthy, and we’re no different.

Team member Livingstone enjoying some soup.

Now, we've already designed the graphical user interface and user experience aspects of this app/website. What remains is the programming, and a platform of this scope will require funding for a development team to move forward with this.

Here's our funding plan, then:

  • We will initially raise $10,000 through crowdfunding here on Indiegogo (hopefully!), and with these funds, we will be able to develop a web version of Buppl, as well as hybrid apps (instead of native apps). This will act as an initial prototype for UNM students to try out and enjoy, and this is what this current round of crowdfunding is for.
  • Once we have this proof-of-concept down, we'll seek  major funding from venture capitalists, angel investors, and the like, to take Buppl to colleges and universities throughout the country.

Although we can scrape up enough money to fund a small percent of what’s needed for programming the first version, we don’t have enough to go it all alone – and that’s why we need your help. Every contribution is a step towards successfully seeing this project through, so we really would appreciate any support – no matter how small.

Where is your money going? Check this out!




Budget Breakdown:

  • In order to reduce costs as much as possible, we'll be handling much of the programming in-house. That's also why we're going to start off with hybrid apps, instead of native apps.
  • Developing the desktop version of Buppl will take up most of the $10,000, as the hybrid apps will be based off of the website.
  • Developing the iOS and Android hybrid apps will each take up 20% of the funding.
  • A total of 10% of the funds we receive will be devoted to fees for legal consultation (to address such issues as copyright protection of our work, trademarking, data-collection concerns, etc.). 
  • Funds for server costs will go towards -- you guessed it -- covering the costs for server usage for the first few months after we've launched at UNM. 


Meet the Team!

If you’re wondering about our relevant experience, check out our bios below!


Livingstone Marmon

Co-founder and Marketing Director

Freelance copywriter, biotechnology enthusiast, and UNM honors student, spiced with a dash of urban climbing just for fun.

Relevant Experience

·  Involved in bioinformatics internship at Los Alamos National Laboratory during the summer of 2013, which yes, required some knowledge of programming languages (Python and Unix).

·  Experience in running small business that has provided ad content, marketing strategy, and copywriting for numerous companies, non-profits, and websites. Incidentally, that’s why I’m the Marketing Director for Buppl.


N'Djamena Marmon (the N'D is silent)

Co-founder and Technical Director

Senior Pre-med student at the University of New Mexico and web and mobile programmer outside of school.

Relevant Experience

·  Have been designing and developing websites professionally for several years, and have mastered coding languages like HTML, CSS, PHP/MySQL , and jQuery. Oh, and I made my first browser-based multiplayer game when I was 15.

·  Participated in the UNM Fall 2013 Mobile Application Development Contest and took 4th out of 17 competitors, and currently have 2 mobile apps in Google Play.


David Marmon II

Creative Director

Passionate film and photography student at UNM, and creative designer at my own business, MarmonCreations.

Relevant Experience

·  Runs small business with focus on web and graphic design, successfully managing multiple team members for the completion of various projects for corporations, non-profits, and startups.

·  I'm an Interdisciplinary Film and Digital Media major at the University of New Mexico, so I have that visual design edge that's needed for producing slick user interfaces.


FAQ

Here's where we'll respond to questions we receive from you! It'll be updated regularly, so stop by whenever you'd like!


Ways You Can Help

Can't sacrifice funds towards this campaign? No worries -- there are other ways you can be a part of this!

  • Tell your family and friends about this campaign.
  • Retweet/tweet about us to your Twitter followers. Follow our main Twitter here or follow Livingstone's twitter for updates on what's new with this project and campaign. 
  • Follow us on Facebook and share with family, friends, and coworkers.


Want to get in touch with us? It's easy.

Feel more than welcome to contact us for any reason, whether you have an idea for improving this campaign or you'd just like to say "hi."

Email us at team@buppl.com.
Send us a message on Facebook.
Direct message us or @ mention our Twitter account.
Take a peek at our website, too.

Drop by this campaign page for updates in which we'll showcase some of our perks, run contests, and keep you updated on our progress. Let's do this!

This will act as an initial prototype for UNM students to try out and enjoy, and this is what this current round of crowdfunding is for. 

Once we have this proof-of-concept down, we'll seek  major funding from venture capitalists, angel investors, and the like, to take Buppl to colleges and universities throughout the country. 

Although we can scrape up enough money
to fund a small percent of what’s needed for programming the first version, we don’t have enough to go it all alone – and that’s why we need your
help. Every contribution is a step towards successfully seeing this
project through, so we really would appreciate any support – no
matter how small. 

Where is your money going? Check this
out!
Budget Breakdown:
In order to reduce costs as much as possible, we'll be handling much of the programming in-house. That's also why we're going to start off with hybrid apps, instead of native apps. 

Developing the desktop version of Buppl will take up most of the $10,000, as the hybrid apps will be based off of the website. 

Developing the iOS and Android hybrid apps will each take up 20% of the funding. 

A total of 10% of the funds we receive will be devoted to fees for legal consultation (to address such issues as copyright protection of our work, trademarking, data-collection concerns, etc.). 
Funds for server costs will go towards -- you guessed it -- covering the costs for server usage for the first few months after we've launched at UNM. 
Meet the Team!
If you’re wondering about our
relevant experience, check out our bios below!Livingstone MarmonCo-founder and Marketing DirectorFreelance copywriter, biotechnology enthusiast, and UNM honors student, spiced with a dash of urban climbing just for fun.
Relevant Experience
· 
Involved in bioinformatics internship at Los
Alamos National Laboratory during the summer of 2013, which yes, required some knowledge of programming languages (Python and Unix). 
· 
Experience in running small business that has
provided ad content, marketing strategy, and copywriting for numerous
companies, non-profits, and websites. Incidentally, that’s why I’m the
Marketing Director for Buppl.N'Djamena Marmon (the N'D is silent)Co-founder and Technical DirectorSenior Pre-med student at the University of New Mexico and web and mobile programmer outside of school.Relevant Experience
· 
Have been designing and developing websites
professionally for several years, and have mastered coding languages like HTML,
CSS, PHP/MySQL , and jQuery. Oh, and I made my first browser-based multiplayer
game when I was 15. 
· 
Participated in the UNM Fall 2013 Mobile Application
Development Contest and took 4th out of 17 competitors, and currently have 2 mobile apps in Google Play. David Marmon IICreative DirectorPassionate film and photography student at UNM, and creative designer at my own business, MarmonCreations.Relevant Experience
· 
Runs small business with focus on web and
graphic design, successfully managing multiple team members for the completion
of various projects for corporations, non-profits, and startups. 
· 
I'm an Interdisciplinary Film and Digital Media major
at the University of New Mexico, so I have that visual design edge that's needed for producing slick user interfaces. 

FAQHere's where we'll respond to questions we receive from you! It'll be updated regularly, so stop by whenever you'd like!Ways You Can HelpCan't sacrifice funds towards this campaign? No worries -- there are other ways you can be a part of this!
Tell your family and friends about this campaign. 

Retweet/tweet about us to your Twitter followers. Follow our main Twitter here or follow Livingstone's twitter for updates on what's new with this project and campaign. 

Follow us on Facebook and share with family, friends, and coworkers. 

Want to get in touch with us? It's easy.Feel more than welcome to contact us for any reason, whether you have an idea for improving this campaign or you'd just like to say "hi."Email us at team@buppl.com.Send us a message on Facebook. Direct message us or @ mention our Twitter account. Take a peek at our website, too. Drop by this campaign page for updates in which we'll showcase some of our perks, run contests, and keep you updated on our progress. Let's do this!

story:
In Brief:

The Pancor Jackhammer is one of the most impressively intimidating shotguns ever made - except that it never went into production. It is a drum-fed, fully automatic 12 gauge shotgun and only a couple prototypes were ever made. When they sell, they bring in excess of $100,000.
I have been offered an opportunity to do a video on one of these prototype Jackhammers. These guns show up in all sorts of video games, but there is no video I am aware of showing an actual example of one. My video would show the features of the gun and disassemble it to show how it works. I may also be able to shoot it, and get both real-time and slow motion (~3000 fps) footage of that (I have not yet been able to confirm if shooting will be possible).
Here's the problem: this is an opportunity only available for a short time and it requires me flying a long way for just this. I don't have a budget to make a trip like this on short notice. I would love to take advantage of what may well be my only opportunity to make a great video showing the Pancor to people, but I need your help to cover the travel costs.

What You Will Get in This Video:

  • A chance to see an actual Pancor Jackhammer
  • Everything there is to know about the Jackhammer's history
  • Everything there is to know about how the Jackhammer works
  • (maybe) Live fire footage
  • (maybe) Awesome slow motion footage
  • Video in full 1080p
  • Video posted to YouTube, free to view for everyone
Specific Costs:
  • Airfare - $750
  • Hotel & car: $250

Why Me?

I have a long history of making cool videos about really exotic guns you won't find anywhere else. I have the background and knowledge to do this right, and I have the camera gear to make it look good. See my web site at Forgotten Weapons, and my YouTube channel.

The Bottom Line

I would love to do this, but I just can't afford to do it myself. So, I will leave it up to you guys, my audience. I have gotten a lot of requests for a Pancor Jackhammer video over the years. If you still want to see it, this is the opportunity.
I am not offering any special perks, because they are just things that will add more cost to the thing, I don't want to restrict the video to only people who donate, or anything like that. It's a simple proposition: if you will send me on this trip, I will make a great video on a great gun we will probably never have another chance to see in public.
This opportunity has a limited window, like I said above. This funding campaign will run only until September 3rd - by that time I will have to either make my travel reservations or cancel the trip. This is a fixed-funding campaign, too - if I don't make the full amount in time, everyone gets their donation returned.
Thanks!
Ian

story:
Medical and Health Science SLC

  • We are a small learning community (SLC), part of Luther Burbank High School in Sacramento, Ca.
  • Our SLC works with a small group of kids, approx. 300 for their 4 years of high school.
  • Our "theme" is Medical and Health Science.

What We Need 

  • We want to purchase t-shirts for each student with our logo.
  • Students and teachers would wear the shirts every Thursday - OUR SLC Day.
  • All funds go directly towards the cost of the shirts, design, and print.
  • The cost for 300 shirts, color print, design, front and back is $2,000.

The Impact

  • In addition to teaching the core subjects: Math, English, Science, Social Science - Our SLC strives to encourage students to live a healthier lifestyle - starting now and beyond high school. 
  • Our SLC focuses on mental health issues, nutrition, sex education, physical fitness and much more.
  • Our goal with the t-shirts is to HELP create a healthier lifestyle culture on our campus. 
  • We are also collecting recyclables on campus to help with funding.
  • We thank you for your support.
  • http://lutherburbank.scusd.edu/

   What We Need   We want to purchase t-shirts for each student with our logo. Students and teachers would wear the shirts every Thursday - OUR SLC Day. All funds go directly towards the cost of the shirts, design, and print.
The cost for 300 shirts, color print, design, front and back is $2,000.    The Impact  In addition to teaching the core subjects: Math, English, Science, Social Science - Our SLC strives to encourage students to live a healthier lifestyle - starting now and beyond high school.  Our SLC focuses on mental health issues, nutrition, sex education, physical fitness and much more.
Our goal with the t-shirts is to HELP create a healthier lifestyle culture on our campus.  We are also collecting recyclables on campus to help with funding.
We thank you for your support.

story:
Hi, we are a middle school in Tucson, Arizona. We are hoping to raise enough money for our field trips and other projects. With the money we are working to earn we will go to the 4-H High Ropes Course where we will learn to trust and to communicate with our classmates. The money will also go to our trip to the Me-to-We Windsong Ranch. The ranch has a mission to save the world by empowering youth to make a difference. The Me-to-We trip will teach us about the ways we can help the environment and if we had a passion how to go after it. We start with the things that are happening already and we try to help. Some of us are going after an artistic or musical passion others are interested in creating peace or designing buildings, everybody has a dream. Help us fulfill ours, we would love if you could donate to our cause. For donating you can select handmade perks: sculptures, necklaces, earrings, bracelets and more. We will change the world with the art we make! 

Chain link earrings

Beaded earrings

Crane earrings

Beaded bracelets and necklaces

Handmade bead necklace

70- fold origami dragons

Bicycle tea candle holders (Large and Small)

Bicycle part mobile

Bicycle part guitar sculpture


Bicycle part snake sculpture

story:
Help Hawai‘i's Team Soar

While beautiful and remote, our location is thousands of miles from the continental U.S. making travel expensive! As Hawaii’s only NCAA Division I-A institution with more than 470 young men and women competing in 21 intercollegiate sports, having a robust travel budget is essential to stay competitive.

The travel fund gives our stellar team the opportunity to compete against top-level athletic programs across the U.S. It also helps us bring the best competitors here, to energize our state and excite our fans with live quality sports events.

Did you know?

  • University of Hawai‘i Athletics has the highest travel costs in the country because we have to fly everywhere.
  • UH Athletics spends approximately $5.6 million per year on travel (approximately 18% of the total Athletics operating budget)
  • When the University of Hawai‘i brings other teams here to compete, we pay for their airfare, hotel and meals. This is a unique situation for the NCAA. Last year we spent $2.2M on travel subsidies and guarantees.
  • The high costs of travel also impact recruitment. Bringing sterling athletes and their parents to Hawai‘i for recruitment, costs an average of $7,000.

Last year the men’s basketball team spent $235,000 on 9 trips and spent 40 days on the road. Total air miles traveled: 46,000.

Help Build Pride

Help us build UH Rainbow Warrior pride around the U.S. and grow our winning tradition both on and off the field.

UHM student-athletes and teams consistently display competitive excellence — in the classrooms and on the fields of play — contributing to our rich and celebrated history.

Successful athletic programs build strong student and community leaders.

Winning is about succeeding in life. Let’s help them soar.

** The travel fund also supports training equipment, training table meals, travel, and recruitment.

story:
Help me complete my mission to return to Gaza  


I am Saoirse, 20 years old, , From Ireland, Dublin

I support Palestine because I am from Ireland and six counties are still occupied till this day by foreign forces, when i first became aware of the brutal occupation in Palestine i felt connected, My initial awareness came from the Israeli attack on the Mavi Marmara humanitarian ship back in 2010 when they attempted to break the siege on Gaza. I immediately became active in the Palestinian cause, I traveled to Gaza by small aid convoy, I stayed in Cairo, in both places i met friends and revolutionaries, The experience changed everything for me, i vowed to myself to give my time to support and show solidarity with Palestine, I left a piece of my Heart in Gaza, and a piece of my soul in Tahrir  

Above pictured myself and activsits involved in The international Egyptian convoy, with Prime minister of Hamas Ismail Haniyeh, September 2011

I have protested back in 2010 with Act for Palestine weekly demos outside the Israeli embassy for a whole year in solidarity with Westbank, Billin weekly demos

Involved in Boycotting Israeli goods

If you help contribute to funding my travels to Gaza, this will help me stay a longer period 1-2 months of volunteering, in the buffer zones (No go zone) were it borders Israel and reduces the agricultural lands effecting Palestinian farmers tending their lands, hoping without fear of being shot at by IDF (Israeli Defence Force), and on the fisher boats with internationals, Gaza's no go zones, the sea in Gaza has a limit of 6 miles before the fishermen receive shootings from the Israeli Navy forces, with many reports of kidnapping the fishermen

 "from experience that if it is allowed to go out six miles, the Israeli navy keeps them within five miles, and when they were officially allowed to go only three miles, it was in reality only two." -Joe Catron International living in Gaza Interviewing Gaza's only woman fisherman 

Volunteering in The buffer zones, and the fisher boats you act as a human shield when the Israeli forces try to open fire, what you do is give the workers like fishermen, and farmers the right to tend their work desperately needed to survive, and break the Israeli restrictions upon them without fear

what i will will do is photograph and report to people online, and to people back at home of the daily horrific life the Palestinians conjure everyday

Little faces of Palestine, Kahn younis refugee camp, Photograph- (Saoirse Bennett) 



Your help sponsoring me to travel to Gaza


With your kind generosity sponsoring me to travel to Gaza and volunteer, your funding with be put to the expenses of 

- Flights to Cairo, from Ireland Return Costs 413 - 500 Euro 

- Taxi to Rafah crossing from Cairo city, is six hours travel, costs 60 Euro there and back equals to 120 Euro total 

- Visas - Avg 50 euros, Egyptian and Palestinian visas  

- Accommodation costs 400 p/m, extra costs staying in Cairo for one or two nights prior and leaving is 15 euro per night 

- Extra costs will be small donations i can bring to Gaza 

 

Sponsoring to volunteer in Gaza 

Since i have visited Gaza in 2011, with The international Egyptian convoy we brought much needed medicine and aid with the help of the red cross entering in trough Rafah border, my week (short) stay brought me to promise many people i will return to stay for a longer period the next time, and instead of bringing aid, the use of me volunteering as an international will bring me such an achievement to help the Palestinians, physically, mentally and learn how they live there daily lives, so i can learn from them in life, to bring back what the mainstream media doesn't show, an eyewitness account, documents, such as photographs, videos, reports of the Apartheid imposed on them

"This has to stop. I think it's a good idea for all of us to drop everything and devote our lives to making it stop." -Rachel Corrie



Other ways to contribute 

Share on Facebook, social networks, Twitter 

tell your friends 

any way you can help, would be much appreciated 

Much Love 

Saoirse Bennett

story:
Summary

The tall ship St. Lawrence II has been changing young peoples' lives through sail training for 60 years. It is the longest running sail training program in North America, and recognized as an exceptional program in the international sail training community. We are dedicated to continuing the mission of empowering, connecting and inspiring youth through our programs aboard the St. Lawrence II, and hope to do so for another 60 years. However, maintaining any vessel, especially a tall ship, comes with a lot of work and significant price tag.

This year we are looking to replace our lower masts with some new ones. They have served us well for many years, but as it is always in good practice on any ship to replace something before it fails you, the time has finally come.

As this project is fairly ambitious compared to our regular winter maintenance and upgrades, we need your help to support these needed mast replacements.

What We Need & What You Get!

We are looking to purchase materials such as lumber, epoxy and tools required for construction of the masts.

In exchange for your generous donation, we have a lot of exciting gift incentives to offer. These include ornaments, T-shirts, day sails, and even a plaque on the mast to recognize your contribution to our historical vessel.

The Impact

Your contribution, no matter how big or small, will go a long way. Maintaining and caring for a ship like the St. Lawrence II is all about giving the next generation of sailors the once in a lifetime experience you may have had, thanks to the financial and other support given to you by the generations who sailed before. It is our dream that the St. Lawrence II will continue in its life-altering role of shaping new generations of youth into strong and capable leaders of tomorrow.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially to our campaign, you can still help! Spread the word about our fundraising campaign and even share some stories about your experiences aboard the St. Lawrence II while you're at it.

And remember, we are always looking for future crew members. So if you know anyone between the ages of 13 and 18, let them know about us. Who knows, it could change their life forever!

story:
Hi, I am Dylan and have lived in St. Augustine since I was born. I am 15 years old, and I started high school last year. I am a hard-working student who earned the A-B honor roll in my freshman year. I am committed to working even harder this year.  I am shooting for straight A honor roll. 


      It is a dream of mine to travel to Spain this summer with a foreign exchange program. There are a few reasons for this. While in Spain I will learn the Spanish language faster than I ever could here in America.  Also, I will learn the culture and history from first hand experience, and a perspective only seen from foreign soil.  Lastly, the enjoyment of travelling to Europe and taking in a new part of the world would be life-changing.


      You may be asking yourself, "Why go to this extent just to better your grades in school?".  A higher GPA is not the only benefit to my scholastic career.  A foreign exchange program will attract attention from colleges, increasing my changes of being accepted by the school of my choice.


       Thank you for taking the time to read this! I appreciate any help that you may be able to provide, weather it be a donation (every penny counts!! even a 5$ donation will help TREMENDOUSLY!) or assistance promoting my project.


 God Bless

story:
Thank you so much to all of our supporters and partners from this campaign!  We raised enough to bring in a bicycle generator system to add to our 4 Tower Gardens.  Now we are not only helping kids grow and eat healthy food, but also understand how energy is created, stored and used, and even power blenders with our kid-powered bicycles to make smoothies with the very vegetables they just grew!  

We aren't done yet!  We have relaunched the campaign here, along with the Bronx Brussel Hustle.  Please join is us Part 2 and together let's grow something greater!


We have just inherited a 60 x 25 foot empty library in a 100+ year old school building! We dream of turning it into the FIRST EVER Health, Wellness and Biodiversity Center in the South Bronx; an innovative and engaging wonderland where children, teachers and the community can explore, experiment, wonder and work towards a brighter future - a place of aspiration and inspiration for all! Help us grow something greater for school children and our community.

Please support Bronx educator Stephen Ritz ( AKA El Capitan ) and Green Bronx Machine to build a prototype "STEAM" - Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math - Facility for the residents of Claremont Village in the South Bronx.

We are looking to feature urban agriculture, food preparation, robotics, computer access, solar technologies, renewables, and earth/life sciences, with a sense of wonder and inquiry fueled by bicycle powered smoothie machines,  hands-on science experiments, interactive hi-tech projects, farmers markets, integrated art projects, a food truck & more.  100% of funds raised in this campaign will be used toward the purchase of equipment and facility upgrades in order to set this vision into motion.  

We believe we can harvest hope and cultivate minds four stories up in this historic public school and need your support! Ideally, this independent and locally grown model will become the prototype for schools and cities across the nation connecting communities to 21st Century opportunities and post secondary options! We are poised, ready, willing and able to prove that the Bronx CAN - Change Attitudes Now!

https://www.ted.com/talks/stephen_ritz_a_teacher_growing_green_in_the_south_bronx?language=en

www.greenbronxmachine.org 

https://www.facebook.com/green.BX.machine

https://twitter.com/greenBXmachine

All donations are tax deductible and we are always looking to partner with innovative organizations. Together we can plant fresh seeds to grow a brighter future!  Reach out to us at info@greenbronxmachine.org.

story:
Hi everybody!
We are here. We are four students and postgrad students from Russia everywhere from Moscow to the Far East.
We want to go to Toronto but not for sightseeing! Our goal is to participate in a conference organized by the main chemistry education organization of our planet, the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry.


We are a team of young undergrad and grad students from Moscow State University. We have been working in education in Russia for five years, actively introducing new technologies. And at some point we were faced with a question: what to do next? We decided that taking part in the 23rd IUPAC International Conference on Chemistry Education is a great chance to open new horizons.
So, we wrote our theses and sent them. Aaaaand - hurray! – we were accepted. After recovering from our initial joy we realized that a flight there is not cheap at all… 
But we really want to get there – and that’s why we ask for your help.
A little bit about us: we are young. We were high school students just a few years so we understand the language appropriate to speak with the students. We know how to interest students in the world around them and how to convince them that it's really fascinating, and we try to answer the billions of questions that they have.



The last February was the fourth time we organized the Moscow Chemical tournament which over the years became an all-Russian event. This event attracts young chemists from all parts of Russia. Moreover, there are only a few analogies of similar events, not only in Russia, but worldwide, too.
And one more thing: we know very little about Canada, in fact the only knowledge we have is from Robin Scherbatsky and South Park. So we really want to know how it really is to be there and what its culture is like.

We just need a little help from you to make our dream come true so we ask for your donation which will grant you some bonuses of course.

story:
“Play is actually a child’s way of learning about his environment and about himself ... The playground is as important a learning institution as a school, and should be given equivalent priority”

(Dattner, 1969)

لقراءة الشرح باللغة العربية يرجي النظر اسفل الصفحة، و بالإمكان أيضا اضافة الترجمة العربية على الفيديو أعلاه باختيار اللغة العربية


Hi! 

We are CatalyticAction, a not-for-profit, design studio that works internationally; intervening with projects that catalyse change in society.

This project will see the production of a playground aimed at Syrian refugee children in Bar Elias, Lebanon; a region which is now hosting a huge population within informal tented settlements. Following the crisis in Syria, over 1.1 million refugees have fled to Lebanon; where the UNHCR predicts that, of these, over 600,000 are children. Despite some international efforts to deliver shelter, food and medication, there is still not enough done to tackle the psychological traumas that these children have experienced. 

We believe that a playground has the power to heal and help 

these children cope.

Our Values:

We are working voluntarily so all the money raised will be invested in the realisation of the project itself. This project will be a core initiative that will kick-start further work from our studio and so we have been spreading the word by presenting at several conferences and starting conversations with different organisations about the future of this project. For this reason your contribution will not just help this project to become reality but will also catalyse future projects and ensure their success (see a list of our current project here: www.catalyticaction.org). We plan to deliver this project in August 2015 if we receive the full amount requested. If we do not receive this amount we will seek further funding and deliver the project later in the year.

Participatory Design Approach

The playground has been designed, and will be constructed, with a participatory approach; prioritising children within the process. In February and March 2015, we engaged the children of the Nahreya School, with the support of our partners (AUB CCECS and Kayany Foundation) in a series of exercises that aimed at understanding their playing practices and play spaces. The children, of various age groups, were introduced to the project and were given the opportunity to communicate what they would hope to see in a playground through a brainstorming activity and a collage and drawing session. The first exercise aimed at initiating memories of play spaces, while the second aimed at visualising the play spaces the children desire; triggering their creative imagination. The result was a series of artworks; consisting of a combination of drawing, writing and collage. For more information about this see our blog post here: 

http://www.catalyticaction.org/participatory-exercises-syrian-children/

This participatory approach has allowed us to understand what action would create a positive and long-term impact; which directly informed the space’s design. The structure of the playground is modular and easily assembled, disassembled and reassembled so to guarantee the temporality required for any structure built in Lebanon’s Informal Tented Settlements. The design can be easily reproduced and adapted to other schools and camp settlements so to ensure that the local community will be able to recreate this space without any additional external design input. The playground’s components are all easily transportable; so they can be moved back to Syria when the war ends and stability returns. The modules are developed to accommodate a central basketball/football activity space; where physical education can take place. The modules also contain swings, climbing walls, a slide and other active spaces; as well as places for relaxation and teaching. 

We have studied the recycling and reuse practices within the Telyani Informal Tented settlements in order to inspire the playground's design components. It proves how a person with scarce resources has a creative intuition to generate what he is in need of. 

Design-Build Workshop

We will be hosting a design-build workshop during the construction period of the project. This will allow for international participants from various professional backgrounds to work alongside local NGO’s, students and the local community members. This workshop will also allow to share this experience and our work with all the participants; supporting mutual knowledge exchange. The first stage of the workshop will focus on building the structure of the playground and the second stage will focus on the playground components and finishing. For further information about these workshops and how to be part of our team, please see the perks and read more info at: http://www.catalyticaction.org/become-a-volunteer/

Participatory art will also be used to engage the children during the erection of the playground and the space will also offer agricultural facilities and educational zones; fostering a more holistic and interdisciplinary approach. Local contractors and residents of the site will be working together to construct this structure, which will cultivate community solidarity.

Our Partners

The Community Development and Projects Unit (CDPu), at the AUB’s (American University of Beirut) Centre of Civic Engagement and Community Service (CCECS) partnered with KAYANY foundation and the Ministry of Social Affairs (MOSA) to provide four schools for children in the Beqa’a region. These schools have received high attendance and are allowing children to continue with their education; providing hope for their futures. We have partnered with these organisations, engaged local constructors and families within the informal tented settlements in order to carry out this project. We are building on the success of these schools and further highlighting the importance of children for the future. 

We are also very privileged to have partnered with Da Move, a European freestyle group who will provide training and will perform at the inauguration of the playground. This is the first project that they are supporting in the Middle East and they are putting their efforts into helping realise this project. This playground will enable the children to engage in physical and recreation activities, alike those that Da Move practices and perform, and has been finalised following several meeting and discussion about the positive impact it will have for these children. The performance at the inauguration of the playground will not only be a fantastic day for the children but an opportunity to raise further awareness with their international platform. Da Move will also provide few days of training for the children and the teachers of the school, who will continue to carry out physical education after this point. 

As well as these organisations, we are working with experts who have offered their services pro-bono to ensure that we can complete this project safely and with great professionalism. The full team of CatalyticAction provide us with invaluable support and without them the project would not be possible. Read about us here: http://www.catalyticaction.org/about-us/

“It is in play that our desire for a perfect world under our complete control is satisfied, and it is there that all the meanings of play meet ... Play is the expression of human freedom, and, in a large sense, play is freedom”

(Dattner, 1969)

If you cannot provide a monetary contribution but you believe in our work, we would be very grateful if you could share and spread the word about this campaign and about us using the buttons below!

Shukran (Thanks)!

A special thanks goes to every person involved in this project:

Dima Mabsout, Gilbert Maull, Pedro Pablo Mora Délano, Amy O’Brien, Bisher Yazigi, Carolina Antoinette Talavera, Elias Chikhani, Tania Kammoun, Sara Chidiac, Allaa Barri, Jad Raad, Samar Maqusi, Luca Astorri, Fabrizio Palamara, Lorenzo Pinciroli, Bouchr Dabaj, Stefania Gyftopoulou, Mai Hassan, Nora Sharabati Joumblatt, Lamia Masri, Firas Suqi, Themis Pagonis, Ali Basma, Hala Fleihan, Rabih Shibli, Marwan, Yazan, Gretta, and the children of Bar Elias: Shamyaa’, Sarah, Mohammad, Amal, Khaled … 

The team of CatalyticAction



Arabic Translation

مرحباً

نحن 'كاتاليتيك أكشن" استديو تصميم غير ريعي (تطوعي) يعمل حول العالم من خلال مشاريع تحفز التغيير في المجتمعات

يعمل هذا المشروع على تصميم و تنفيذ باحة لعب و نشاطات في واحدة من مدارس الأطفال السورين في منطقة "بر الياس" في لبنان, التي تؤي عدد كبيراً من اللاجئين في مخيمات غير منظمة. نتيجةً للأزمة المتفاقمة في سوريا لجأ قرابة ١,١ مليون سوري الى لبنان, حيث تقدر المنظمة الدولية للاطفال أن من بينهم ما يزيد عن ستمائة الف طفل. و على الرغم من بعض الجهود الإغاثية المشكورة لتأمين سكن, غذاء و دواء, فقد تم عمل القليل لمواجهة و استيعاب الضرر النفسي الذي لحق بهؤلاء الأطفال

إننا نؤمن بأن باحة لعب قد تملك من القدرة ما يكفي لإبراء جراح الأطفال و تمكينهم من التغلب عليها

نحن نعمل تطوعياً و لذلك سيتم استخدام كافة التبرعات في تنفيذ المشروع المحدد. هذا المشروع هو باكورة أعمال الاستديو و لذلك نحن نقوم بنشر و تسويق عملنا من خلال تقديمه للناس في عدد من المؤتمرات و بدء مشاورات حول مستقبل المشروع مع منظمات مختلفة. لهذا السبب مساهماتكم لن تساعد في تنفيذ هذا المشروع و حسب بل ستكون حافذاً لمشاريع مستقبلية. سنعمل على تنفيذ المشروع في أغسطس (آب) في حال استطعنا جمع كالم ميزانية المشروع, واذا تعذر جمع كامل ميزانية المشروع فسنسعى لتأمين بقية التمويل و سننفذ المشروع لاحقاً هذا العام

الاسلوب التشاركي المتبع في زياراتنا للموقع مكننا من معرفة ما هو العمل الأمثل لخلق تأثير إيجابي طويل الأمد, و قد أثر ذلك مباشرة على التصميم. ستكون هيكلية باحة اللعب مرنة و قابلة للتجميع, الفك, و اعادة التجميع مما يتوافق مع الطبيعة المؤقتة لأي بنية في المخيمات العشوائية في لبنان. مكونات باحة اللعب قابلة للنقل بسهولة حيث يمكن نقلها الى الداخل السوري بعد نهاية الحرب و استتباب الأوضاع. التصميم مطور ليشمل ملعب كرة قدم/كرة سلة مركزي, حيث يمكن لحصص الرياضة أن تتم. هنالك أيضاً مراجيح, حيطان تسلق, "زحليطة" و نشاطات أخرى, بالإضافة إلى فسحات للراحة و التعليم

شكراً
