story:
Hello friends,

My name is Rachel Ten Eyck. I’ve debated a while as to whether or not my cause was worthy of asking for your generosity.  I’ve decide, Yes it is! For me, this would be the equivalent to a trip to India or Europe. This is my adventure! My Passion! My Piece de resistance! I desire to become an Expressive Arts Therapist!

This has been a life long journey of art making and healing. In the spring of 2013, I caught a ride to the bay area. I biked and couch surfed my way to Meet Anna Halprin, the 94 year old co-founder of Tamalpa Institute. Her work has transformed my life. It has since become my mission to heal the world with counseling and expressive arts therapy!

Now that I have made my way into Anna Halprin’s program at the Tamalpa institute, I am ready to begin the next step of my journey. I plan to pursue a PhD at Meridian University where I can  earn an MFT (Marriage Family Therapist license) . I desire to work with low income women and children in crisis situations. I also have a vision to take this work worldwide. This would include creating art pieces to share with communities and also help participants build the tools to approach life in a holistic manner.

This work is deep and is what I believe our society is craving. Art can act as an extension of our souls in situations where words fail us. I truly feel this is my life’s work and would be honored if you would be a part of helping me along my journey in becoming an Expressive Arts Therapist.  

How else can you help?
Simply by spreading the word through facebook!

story:
Short Summary

The statistics on bullying and youth suicide are alarming:

Suicide is the third leading cause of death among young people, resulting in about 4,400 deaths per year, according to the CDC. For every suicide among young people, there are at least 100 suicide attempts. Over 14 percent of high school students have considered suicide, and almost 7 percent have attempted it.
Bully victims are between 2 to 9 times more likely to consider suicide than non-victims, according to studies by Yale University
A study in Britain found that at least half of suicides among young people are related to bullying
10 to 14 year old girls may be at even higher risk for suicide, according to the study above
According to statistics reported by ABC News, nearly 30 percent of students are either bullies or victims of bullying, and 160,000 kids stay home from school every day because of fear of bullying
Bully-related suicide can be connected to any type of bullying, including physical bullying, emotional bullying, cyberbullying, and sexting, or circulating suggestive or nude photos or messages about a person.

Some schools or regions have more serious problems with bullying and suicide related to bullying. This may be due to an excessive problem with bullying at the school. It could also be related to the tendency of students who are exposed to suicide to consider suicide themselves. 

 Living Values Educational Program is unusually comprehensive. It offers both methodology and content. Educators teach values through modeling and facilitating a values-exploration process that motivates a bully free environment. LVE provides educator training and hundreds of lessons that build skills sequentially. LVE invites educators to explore this method of values education and then create their own activities and draw from the culture of the students.  Its multi-modality approach contributes to impacting both left- and right-brain thinkers. Not just a “values awareness” approach, LVE educators and activities encourage students to reflect and think deeply in order to engage the heart as well as the mind.

LVE educators reinforce positive character traits and emotional intelligence in all students. One key to LVE effectiveness is the lack of moralizing. “Resistant” students or marginalized youth turn away from a moralizing approach to character education.

What types of activities are included in LVE?

LVE provides a broad range of activities to encourage the development of both cognitive and affective skills. Students are engaged in conflict-resolution exercises, discussions, artistic activities (art, dramas, song, dance, and storytelling), games, communication exercises, role- playing, mind-mapping, creative writing, imagining and relaxation/focusing exercises. For older students, some activities foster awareness of social justice and responsibility. Each site implementing LVE is encouraged to include stories, songs and activities from the culture of the students with whom they work.

Why “living” values?

History is built around the gap between what people say and what they do. LVE believes that adults are important role models. We encourage school development plans that identify values held in common.

What specific values are you looking to promote?

LVE helps people explore and choose their own personal values as well as develop intrapersonal and interpersonal skills to “live” those values. The purpose of this education is to awaken what already exists and provide tools to understand the ramifications of actions for the self, others and society and increase values-based decision-making ability. LVE activities elicit from students ideas about what they would value in their ideal world, and students explore the things they feel give meaning to their lives.

The twelve values explored by LVE have been articulated and widely endorsed around the world at conferences such as the 1989 UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the 1992 Aspen Conference.

What do you do during LVE Workshops?

During LVE workshops, educators participate in values-awareness sessions. They are asked to reflect on their own values, imagine an optimal learning environment, and brainstorm quality teaching practices that would create a values-based atmosphere. LVE’s theoretical model and schematic of how values are developed are shared. This is followed by sessions engaged in Living Values Activities. The workshop then turns to skills for creating a values-based environment: acknowledgment, encouragement, and positively building behaviors; active listening; conflict resolution; collaborative rule making, and values-based discipline. Educators who work with children at risk undergo additional training as do facilitators for Living Values Parent Groups.

USA site: www.livingvalueseducation.org 

International site: www.livingvalues.net

What We Need & What You Get

With your donations in support of teachers in your community, we can successfully meet our goal of raising $150,000. The funds will be used to equip teachers with the skills necessary to create a vibrant, safe, caring classroom/school in which quality learning can take place. Funding will be allocated as follows :

        • Transform schools by training entire staffs of teachers in the Living Values Education methodology (Mindfulness, values exploration and development, active listening, solution-based-thinking and conflict resolution).
        • Art supplies and materials required to facilitate experiential activities in the Living Values Education curriculum.
        • Make available the Living Values Education At-Risk curriculum to educators in need of additional training.
        • Sustainability training using the Living Green Values curriculum.
        • In appreciate for your generosity you will receive a token of our appreciation, please check the perks section.  

Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal

All funds received will be utilized towards training as many teachers in the Living Values Education methodology and supply the necessary materials for the experiential activities in the classroom.

The Impact

One entire school, located in Pawling, New York, has implemented LVE for more than ten years. The staff and students experience a school culture of peace, caring and respect. Children feel valued and understood; bullying is not part of the culture. Students experience an in increase in creativity, social acumen  and emotional intelligence which supports academic excellence. A K-8 LVE school in Florida became the top seventh school in Florida. The Principal stated, "There simply is no bullying." Pre-schools and day care centers in the USA which implement LVE have created a culture of caring and kindness. 

LVE is active internationally. In Iceland, a veteran first-grade teacher reported seeing surprising and dramatic improvements in caring, respect, cooperation, concentration, and learning to read. In Lebanon, second-graders in a classroom at ACS learned conflict resolution so well that they solved all peer conflicts themselves; the teacher reported she is free to teach. For the two years in Thailand, the schools winning the country’s award for the best school in the country, the Royal Reward, were schools implementing LVE. Eighty percent drops in school disciplinary referrals were reported by three primary schools within their first year of implementing LVE as whole schools in Bermuda. In Australia, a secondary-level nine student reported, “It’s not just that I like values classes, I really enjoy them. At the start I was dead against values, I didn’t feel like I got anything out of the class... Then I thought for one lesson I would really contribute. That lesson changed the way I felt about values. I can relate to everything that we talk about. I find myself discovering things about myself that I never knew. Values class is really worthwhile.” In South Africa, formerly violent secondary students led LVE workshops for their peers.

There are many wonderful results with LVE’s at-risk materials. In Thailand, one year after implementing LVEP, nine out of 24 refugee-camp teachers working with children and youth reported 100-percent improvement in violent behavior; the others cited an 80- percent reduction in aggressiveness. With children in difficult circumstances, street educators using Living Values Activities for Street Children in Vietnam reported considerable decreases in aggression and at-risk behaviors. They noted, “Now they are confident and friendly with adults and their peers. There is almost no conflict in the classes and they now do not get into trouble after school either. The students have also developed many skits on how to keep safe from dangerous adults and really enjoy performing them. Now when they are on the streets and see children that are new to the streets they give support and advice to the new children and invite them to meet their teacher and join their classes.” The Ministry of Labor in Vietnam reported in March of 2008 that LVE’s program for Drug Rehabilitation was the most successful program in government drug rehabilitation clinics.

LVE Curriculum Resources

    •  Living Values Activities for Children Ages 3–7 

       Living Values Activities for Children Ages 8–14

       Living Values Activities for Young Adults

        LVEP Educator Training Guide 

       Living Values Parent Groups: A Facilitator Guide

      This Living Values Series of five books received Learning Magazine’s Teachers’ Choice Award 2002. All or some of these books are published in 12 languages. Translation is ongoing in an additional 17 languages.

      The distribution of LVE materials for children at-risk is restricted to educators who attend special LVE training for these modules. 
Other Ways You Can Help

 Share this link on your social media platform page or share right here on Indiegogo!
story_txt:
Short Summary
The statistics on bullying and youth suicide are alarming:
Suicide is the third leading cause of death among young people, resulting in about 4,400 deaths per year, according to the CDC. For every suicide among young people, there are at least 100 suicide attempts. Over 14 percent of high school students have considered suicide, and almost 7 percent have attempted it.Bully victims are between 2 to 9 times more likely to consider suicide than non-victims, according to studies by Yale UniversityA study in Britain found that at least half of suicides among young people are related to bullying10 to 14 year old girls may be at even higher risk for suicide, according to the study aboveAccording to statistics reported by ABC News, nearly 30 percent of students are either bullies or victims of bullying, and 160,000 kids stay home from school every day because of fear of bullyingBully-related suicide can be connected to any type of bullying, including physical bullying, emotional bullying, cyberbullying, and sexting, or circulating suggestive or nude photos or messages about a person.
Some schools or regions have more serious problems with bullying and suicide related to bullying. This may be due to an excessive problem with bullying at the school. It could also be related to the tendency of students who are exposed to suicide to consider suicide themselves. 
 Living Values Educational Program is unusually comprehensive. It offers both methodology and content. Educators teach values through modeling and facilitating a values-exploration process that motivates a bully free environment. LVE provides educator training and hundreds of lessons that build skills sequentially. LVE invites educators to explore this method of values education and then create their own activities and draw from the culture of the students.  Its multi-modality approach contributes to impacting both left- and right-brain thinkers. Not just a “values awareness” approach, LVE educators and activities encourage students to reflect and think deeply in order to engage the heart as well as the mind.
LVE educators reinforce positive character traits and emotional intelligence in all students. One key to LVE effectiveness is the lack of moralizing. “Resistant” students or marginalized youth turn away from a moralizing approach to character education.
What types of activities are included in LVE?
LVE provides a broad range of activities to encourage the development of both cognitive and affective skills. Students are engaged in conflict-resolution exercises, discussions, artistic activities (art, dramas, song, dance, and storytelling), games, communication exercises, role- playing, mind-mapping, creative writing, imagining and relaxation/focusing exercises. For older students, some activities foster awareness of social justice and responsibility. Each site implementing LVE is encouraged to include stories, songs and activities from the culture of the students with whom they work.
Why “living” values?
History is built around the gap between what people say and what they do. LVE believes that adults are important role models. We encourage school development plans that identify values held in common.
What specific values are you looking to promote?
LVE helps people explore and choose their own personal values as well as develop intrapersonal and interpersonal skills to “live” those values. The purpose of this education is to awaken what already exists and provide tools to understand the ramifications of actions for the self, others and society and increase values-based decision-making ability. LVE activities elicit from students ideas about what they would value in their ideal world, and students explore the things they feel give meaning to their lives.
The twelve values explored by LVE have been articulated and widely endorsed around the world at conferences such as the 1989 UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the 1992 Aspen Conference.

The workshop then turns to skills for creating a values-based environment: acknowledgment, encouragement, and positively building behaviors; active listening; conflict resolution; collaborative rule making, and values-based discipline. Educators who work with children at risk undergo additional training as do facilitators for Living Values Parent Groups.

International site: www.livingvalues.net

story:
O que é a Bright Future?

Assim como em muitas culturas, os ugandenses também têm uma palavra para o “homem branco”: Mzungu. Seja brasileiro, chinês ou australiano, você continua sendo mais um rosto branco na multidão. Quando me viram no primeiro dia de aula, ao invés de oi, as crianças me falavam "goodbye mzungu". Acho que elas estão acostumadas com essas pessoas sem cor que vêm visitar uma realidade diferente e depois vão embora pra casa. 

Só que eu não fui. 

Faz quatro semanas que ando ensinando e aprendendo intensamente. Mas agora nem sei mais quem é que está ensinando quem. Quando cheguei, tudo o que eu enxergava era pobreza, sujeira e desconforto. Depois de um mês, ainda vejo essas coisas, mas o que vejo mais são os olhos ávidos por aprender e os sorrisos constantes. Concluí que a pobreza é mesmo muito ruim, mas o que impressiona mais é a o espírito humano. 

A escola primária Bright Future fica em Banda, uma das mais antigas favelas de Kampala, capital e maior cidade de Uganda. A renda média das família que aqui residem é 2,50. Reais. Por dia. E pensando que as famílias médias no país tem 6 filhos, não é tranquilo viver com essa grana. Muitas das crianças fazem parte da primeira geração a ir para a escola, enquanto alguns dos seus irmãos também não poderão ir por não poder pagar. Gostaríamos que isso fosse diferente.  

A escola tem 300 alunos, de 2 a 15 anos. O que ela não tem é água corrente, sistema de esgoto, eletricidade ou parede de tijolos. Cada uma dessas crianças pode ser a célula que vai mudar o país nos próximos anos, e eu gostaria que vocês me ajudassem a dar um empurrãozinho. 

Do que precisamos?

  • A maioria das crianças nunca conheceram hábitos de higiene. O primeiro dinheirinho arrecadado vai pra comprar escovas de dente, pasta, sabonete, papel higiênico e tanques de água com torneira para que as crianças lavem as mãos, já que crianças saudáveis tem mais chances de melhor aproveitar a escola. Para esta etapa, precisamos de 500 reais (250 dólares).
  • Se passarmos de 500 reais, vamos comprar com o dinheiro sobressalente cadernos, lápis, canetas, lápis de cor, etc., afim de garantir o aproveitamento das crianças ano que vem. Para isso, precisamos de 1000 reais. 
  • Se passarmos dos 1000 reais, vamos patrocinar os melhores alunos da escola ano que vem, dando comida, material escolar e uniformes. Para isso, precisamos de um total de 2400 reais. 
  • Escolhemos fazer por crowdfunding ao invés de receber os materiais porque o correio em Uganda não é confiável. 

O Impacto

  • Acreditamos que dentro de um ambiente mais ameno as crianças terão mais chances de atingir seu potencial intelectual, enquanto melhoram sua saúde.
  • Acreditamos que quando um governo ignora seu povo, fica a cargo dos indivíduos mais favorecidos compartilharem sua boa fortuna.
  • Gostaríamos de dar mais possibilidades de uma vida feliz a cada um, porque as crianças merecem. Queremos dar o apoio e o incentivo para que sigam seus sonhos.

Mas quanto eu tenho que doar?

Quanto você quiser.
  • Com R$10, você compra escovas de dentes para 20 crianças. 
  • Com R$20, você compra cadernos para 40 crianças.
  • Com R$40, você compra 20 caixas de lápis de cor!
  • Com R$100, você patrocina 1 criança por 1 ano.

story:
Durante los meses de diciembre y enero, la costa Caribe colombiana recibe aproximadamente 20,000 turistas. El impacto ambiental durante esta época es muy fuerte. Las comunidades costeras de la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, específicamente Palomino en la Guajira, necesitan de una educación ambiental adecuada para poder controlar la cantidad de desechos y residuos sólidos que deja el turismo durante estas fechas, pues la basura que se genera se está quemando, enterrando o en el peor de los casos está siendo arrojada al mar. ¡Es un problema muy grave!

El FESTIVAL DEL JAGUAR, es un evento musical con una temática medioambiental que realizará su 3ra versión en Palomino en enero 7 y 8 de 2016. Dentro del marco del Festival habrán artistas invitados, una feria de productos y artesanías de la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta (Eco-feria), un ciclo de cine medioambiental que incluye a la comunidad étnica Kogui y Wiwa, y una serie de talleres sobre educación ambiental, reciclaje y manejo adecuado de basuras (selección-separación-compostaje) con NIÑOS y ADULTOS de la comunidad de Palomino.

El FESTIVAL DEL JAGUAR y la fundación ASHÉ (ONG colombiana que trabaja desde la educación y la cultura comunitaria) están pidiendo la ayuda de la comunidad global para poder financiar y conseguir recursos para los talleres de educación ambiental que se desarrollarán en diciembre de 2015 con la población de Palomino, Guajira, durante un periodo de 15 días. 

Estos talleres se realizarán a través de visitas domiciliarias cubriendo un 90% de la población, mediante las que un grupo de voluntarios enseñará a cada familia incluyendo padres e hijos sobre el manejo adecuado de las basuras (selección-separación-compostaje) y sobre la construcción de objetos con botellas PET y basura. Contamos con el liderazgo y voluntariado de profesionales en sociología, educación, ecología y diseño industrial.

El objetivo de estos talleres es promover la eduación y el empoderamiento de la comunidad frente al tema de manejo de basuras, impacto ambiental, compostaje, reciclaje y construcción con botellas PET. Asimismo, queremos realizar una LIMPIEZA y REFORESTACIÓN de las riberas de los 2 ríos que bordean Palomino y de las playas, con la ayuda de la defensa civil y un grupo de niños a los que llamaremos los "Jaguaritos Salvaplaneta", con esta basura podremos realizar la construcción de 15 sillas con residuos sólidos para mostrarle a las personas que SÍ es posible darle un segundo uso a estos desechos no-orgánicos.

Su ayuda es MUY importante para nosotros. De su aporte depende la posibilidad de generar estos espacios con poblaciones vulnerables que carecen de educación frente a temas tan esenciales como el manejo de los desechos orgánicos e inorgánicos. 

Con su donación podremos cubrir el costo de materiales, transporte y alimentación de los voluntarios y producción e impresión de cartillas educativas.

Además, podremos llevar a cabo talleres a gran escala y a largo plazo, que involucren no solamente a la comunidad de Palomino sino a poblaciones aledañas que tienen menor índice turístico pero que también necesitan de esta formación. Poblaciones como Buritaca, Mingueo y Dibulla (Guajira).

La Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta nos necesita. Es el corazón de la tierra. Si las comunidades se educan y empoderan desde la consciencia ambiental, serán ellos mismos quienes cuiden y hagan respetar su ecosistema. (Es necesario aclarar que el gobierno colombiano no tiene NINGÚN interés por el manejo de basuras o la educación ambiental en zonas como la Guajira).

///

During the months of December and January, the Colombian Caribbean coast receives about 20,000 tourists. The environmental impact during this time is very strong. Coastal communities of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, specifically Palomino, urge an adequate environmental education in order to control the amount of waste that leaves tourism during this time. The waste generated is being burnt out, buried or in the worst case it is being thrown into the ocean. It's a very serious problem we're dealing here!

The JAGUAR FESTIVAL is a musical event with an environmental theme that will be held on its 3rd version in Palomino the 2nd and 3rd of January 2016. As part of the Festival there will be guest artists (DJ Set of Systema Solar, Dj set of Bomba Estereo, Carmelo Torres, among others), a farmer's market of products and handicrafts from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, a series of environmental films which include the Kogi and Wiwa ethnic communities and a series of workshops on environmental education, recycling and proper waste management ( selection- separation - composting) with children and adults of the community of Palomino.

The JAGUAR FESTIVAL and ASHÉ Foundation (a Colombian NGO working for community education and culture) are asking for your help and support in order to fund and raise resources for the environmental education workshops that will be held in December 2015 with the people from Palomino, Guajira, for a period of 15 days.

These workshops will take place through home visits covering 90% of Palomino's population, through which a group of volunteers will teach each family including parents and children on the proper handling of waste (selection - separation - composting) and object-construction with PET bottles and trash. We count with the leadership and volunteering of professionals in sociology, education, ecology and industrial design.


The purpose of these workshops is to promote education and empowerment of the community address the issue of waste management, environmental impact, composting , recycling and construction with PET bottles . We also want to make a cleaning and reforestation of the banks of the two rivers bordering Palomino and the beaches with the help of civil defense and a group of children who we call the "Planet-saver Jaguars".

With your donation we will be able to cover the cost of materials, transportation and meals for volunteers and production and printing of educational pamphlets .

Your help is very important to us. Of your contribution depends the possibility of generating opportunities for vulnerable communities whose sustenance depends from tourism, but after the high season passes they get a hard time with the contamination of their beautiful beaches and rivers. Moreover, with your contribution we can carry out large-scale workshops, involving not only the community of Palomino but surrounding towns such as Buritaca, Mingueo and Dibulla (Guajira).

The Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta needs us. It is the heart of the earth. If communities are educated and empowered through environmental consciousness, they will be able to take care and generate respect for their ecosystem. (Colombian government has absolutely no control or education towards garbage and waste management).


#palominofund

For more information we'll be willing to answer your needs:

Para más información consulta nuestras redes o escríbenos:

www.ashefundacion.org/proyectos
www.facebook.com/FestivalJaguarp?fref=ts
www.facebook.com/ashefundacion
ashefundacion@gmail.com

Durante los meses de diciembre y enero, la costa Caribe colombiana recibe aproximadamente 20,000 turistas. El impacto ambiental durante esta época es muy fuerte. Las comunidades costeras de la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, específicamente Palomino en la Guajira, necesitan de una educación ambiental adecuada para poder controlar la cantidad de desechos y residuos sólidos que deja el turismo durante estas fechas, pues la basura que se genera se está quemando, enterrando o en el peor de los casos está siendo arrojada al mar. ¡Es un problema muy grave!El FESTIVAL DEL JAGUAR, es un evento musical con una temática medioambiental que realizará su 3ra versión en Palomino en enero 7 y 8 de 2016. Dentro del marco del Festival habrán artistas invitados, una feria de productos y artesanías de la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta (Eco-feria), un ciclo de cine medioambiental que incluye a la comunidad étnica Kogui y Wiwa, y una serie de talleres sobre educación ambiental, reciclaje y manejo adecuado de basuras (selección-separación-compostaje) con NIÑOS y ADULTOS de la comunidad de Palomino.El FESTIVAL DEL JAGUAR y la fundación ASHÉ (ONG colombiana que trabaja desde la educación y la cultura comunitaria) están pidiendo la ayuda de la comunidad global para poder financiar y conseguir recursos para los talleres de educación ambiental que se desarrollarán en diciembre de 2015 con la población de Palomino, Guajira, durante un periodo de 15 días. Estos talleres se realizarán a través de visitas domiciliarias cubriendo un 90% de la población, mediante las que un grupo de voluntarios enseñará a cada familia incluyendo padres e hijos sobre el manejo adecuado de las basuras (selección-separación-compostaje) y sobre la construcción de objetos con botellas PET y basura. Contamos con el liderazgo y voluntariado de profesionales en sociología, educación, ecología y diseño industrial.El objetivo de estos talleres es promover la eduación y el empoderamiento de la comunidad frente al tema de manejo de basuras, impacto ambiental, compostaje, reciclaje y construcción con botellas PET. Asimismo, queremos realizar una LIMPIEZA y REFORESTACIÓN de las riberas de los 2 ríos que bordean Palomino y de las playas, con la ayuda de la defensa civil y un grupo de niños a los que llamaremos los "Jaguaritos Salvaplaneta", con esta basura podremos realizar la construcción de 15 sillas con residuos sólidos para mostrarle a las personas que SÍ es posible darle un segundo uso a estos desechos no-orgánicos.Su ayuda es MUY importante para nosotros. De su aporte depende la posibilidad de generar estos espacios con poblaciones vulnerables que carecen de educación frente a temas tan esenciales como el manejo de los desechos orgánicos e inorgánicos. Con su donación podremos cubrir el costo de materiales, transporte y alimentación de los voluntarios y producción e impresión de cartillas educativas.Además, podremos llevar a cabo talleres a gran escala y a largo plazo, que involucren no solamente a la comunidad de Palomino sino a poblaciones aledañas que tienen menor índice turístico pero que también necesitan de esta formación. Poblaciones como Buritaca, Mingueo y Dibulla (Guajira).La Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta nos necesita. Es el corazón de la tierra. Si las comunidades se educan y empoderan desde la consciencia ambiental, serán ellos mismos quienes cuiden y hagan respetar su ecosistema. (Es necesario aclarar que el gobierno colombiano no tiene NINGÚN interés por el manejo de basuras o la educación ambiental en zonas como la Guajira).///During the months of December and January, the Colombian Caribbean coast receives about 20,000 tourists. The environmental impact during this time is very strong. Coastal communities of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, specifically Palomino, urge an adequate environmental education in order to control the amount of waste that leaves tourism during this time. The waste generated is being burnt out, buried or in the worst case it is being thrown into the ocean. It's a very serious problem we're dealing here!The JAGUAR FESTIVAL is a musical event with an environmental theme that will be held on its 3rd version in Palomino the 2nd and 3rd of January 2016. As part of the Festival there will be guest artists (DJ Set of Systema Solar, Dj set of Bomba Estereo, Carmelo Torres, among others), a farmer's market of products and handicrafts from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, a series of environmental films which include the Kogi and Wiwa ethnic communities and a series of workshops on environmental education, recycling and proper waste management ( selection- separation - composting) with children and adults of the community of Palomino.The JAGUAR FESTIVAL and ASHÉ Foundation (a Colombian NGO working for community education and culture) are asking for your help and support in order to fund and raise resources for the environmental education workshops that will be held in December 2015 with the people from Palomino, Guajira, for a period of 15 days.These workshops will take place through home visits covering 90% of Palomino's population, through which a group of volunteers will teach each family including parents and children on the proper handling of waste (selection - separation - composting) and object-construction with PET bottles and trash. We count with the leadership and volunteering of professionals in sociology, education, ecology and industrial design.
The purpose of these workshops is to promote education and empowerment of the community address the issue of waste management, environmental impact, composting , recycling and construction with PET bottles . We also want to make a cleaning and reforestation of the banks of the two rivers bordering Palomino and the beaches with the help of civil defense and a group of children who we call the "Planet-saver Jaguars".


With your donation we will be able to cover the cost of materials, transportation and meals for volunteers and production and printing of educational pamphlets .
Your help is very important to us. Of your contribution depends the possibility of generating opportunities for vulnerable communities whose sustenance depends from tourism, but after the high season passes they get a hard time with the contamination of their beautiful beaches and rivers. Moreover, with your contribution we can carry out large-scale workshops, involving not only the community of Palomino but surrounding towns such as Buritaca, Mingueo and Dibulla (Guajira).

The Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta needs us. It is the heart of the earth. If communities are educated and empowered through environmental consciousness, they will be able to take care and generate respect for their ecosystem. (Colombian government has absolutely no control or education towards garbage and waste management).





#palominofund
For more information we'll be willing to answer your needs:
Para más información consulta nuestras redes o escríbenos:
www.ashefundacion.org/proyectoswww.facebook.com/FestivalJaguarp?fref=tswww.facebook.com/ashefundacionashefundacion@gmail.com

story:
Over the summer The National Campaign Against Fees and Cuts called a demonstration for free education on November 4th in London. This has since been backed by NUS UK and over 40 Universities. It is vital that we protest in London, and that students from all over the UK can participate. 

That's where you come in! Getting a coach load of students from Aberdeen to London isn't cheap and that's why we are asking you to donate as much or as little as you can. 

Free Education & Living Grants for All!

More can be found out about the demo here http://anticuts.com/demo-nov-2015/

Our event to attend is here https://www.facebook.com/events/734134910052122/

story:
Our Story.


My name is Roxanne, and I'm the founder of My Wildhood. My Wildhood facilitates project-based workshops for youth that blend arts-based outdoor exploration with basic graphic design.

Sometimes I feel like I live two lives. In one, I'm relentlessly pursuing the outdoors, exploring every corner of the island that I now call home. On the other, I am actively creative, enthralled by design and it's ability to bring imaginative ideas to life. And I know I'm not alone! 

That's why I created My Wildhood. 

Our goal at My Wildhood is to have youth increase their confidence to (1) explore outdoors independently, and (2) be creative!

And as a contributor, you will have a hand in helping shape the first ever My Wildhood Workshops:
  • Outdoor Photography & Photoshop Design
  • Outdoor Sketch & Illustrator Design 
  • Surf Photography & Photoshop Design

Let's Break It Down.

It's going to cost $5000 to kick off My Wildhood this Fall -- to purchase previously owned cameras and laptops, obtain an Adobe Creative Cloud Education Membership, rent space to host the workshops in, pay for specialized facilitators to teach the kids certain aspects of each workshop and more!

All $5000 and beyond will go straight to My Wildhood's educational design programs. With each donation, you will receive some My Wildhood stickers, and a personal thank you note from myself. Each and every donation, no matter how small, will not go unnoticed -- I can promise you that! 


Impact.


For the first half of each workshop series, students will be outdoors, either taking photographs or sketching. After around 5 weeks, students will translate the images and designs they've created outside, onto the computer using Adobe Illustrator or Photoshop. The remaining lessons will give students the tools they need to enhance, reproduce, or recreate their artwork digitally.  At the end of the workshop, students will have the opportunity to share what they've created with their friends, family, and community through a My Wildhood Art Exhibit. My Wildhood covers the cost of printing and framing each piece of artwork for the exhibit.

We hope that through our workshops, youth gain the confidence to be creative and try new things, both inside and out!

So thank you from our wild family to yours for helping make this possible. 

- - - - - - - - For more information, check out our website here! - - - - - - - -

story:
Mission Chocó


(Versión en español a continuación)

Mission Chocó is a social project, an entrepreneurial project, a creative project and first and foremost a humanitarian project. It's a co-creation, an collaboration between dislocated families of Colombia, employees of the social business Maria Panela and a group of students from a creative business school in Denmark called the KaosPilots.

 

THE BACKGROUND

 The department of Chocó is one of the most complex areas of Colombia. Located in the northwest, it borders Panama and has coastlines on both the Caribbean and the Pacific. Most of Chocó is low-lying tropical rain forest (one of the rainiest spots in the world), though in the south and the east it starts to rise in the mountains. It is a natural paradise, home to a huge diversity of plant and animal species.  The area is rich of natural resources and a home to thousands of Afro-American and indigenous families, through all racial mixtures, and unlimited cultural views and ancestral traditions.

Sadly, its natural wealth and the low government presence, created the suitable conditions to the creation of drug-runners, both in terms of production and transportation to the coast which has attracted armed groups directly and affected the population, generating a high rate of forced displacement that not only affects quality of people’s life, but jeopardizes the intangible heritage of humanity in terms of language and culture.

In the region the access to education is not easy, either by distance, infrastructure, poor levels of technology or lack of teachers, all of the above triggers in poor academic performance of students which places them in the bottom of the educational scale in the country.

 The economic of the region is primarily focused on the extraction of natural resources that makes the employment options very limited.

This naturally leads to a shared idea in the society that the capital offers employment and educational opportunities that do not exist in Chocó. However the reality is that when the families reach the city the dreams and hopes of finding a job fades a way quite fast. On top of that the educational system is not free or always easy to start immediately and unlike the green jungle where food grows everywhere the city in only a jungle of concrete 

Despite social and governmental initiatives, conditions in both the region and the city have not improved significantly. In our opinion one of the reasons are that the initiatives have been in the form of aid and have created learned helplessness and dependency rather then strengthening the community.

 One of our closes examples is the group that we will cooperate with in this project, the Waunnan’s. They are an indigenous family that came to the city over nine years ago but still haven’t manage to find a sustainable way to get an income for a respectable life. They are dependent on selling their handcrafts that generates revenue of about 200.000 pesos (113 US$) for a family of at least four members. This is not an income they can rely on being constant. It makes them very dependant on support from the government as well as non-governmental aid that is very time consuming.

 

THE PROJECT

Mission Choco is a project led by Maria Panela organization and supported by a group of the KaosPilots‘s students. It seeks to directly benefit the indigenous family Waunnan with job options. Alongside this project, we will make a pilot projects of community strengthening with two more groups, through training and the development of a community plan. 

The focus of the project is to build the Innovation Café: María Panela Chocó that requires $ 40,000 to build the café and get it running.  This coffee will have three main objectives:

 

What?

 1.    To promote the Choco region by showing it’s beauty, natural and cultural wealth as well as their needs. Bringing awareness to the possibilities and resources to create a sustainable and helpful development for the families instead of a dependant and short-term assistance. 

2.    To generate income for the community by sales platform for Chocó’s communities. It will be run according to the Maria Panela fair trade model where they can start selling their beautiful handcrafts and show what is behind each of their products, that is not mere commodities but a piece of art. The café will be staffed with members of the indigenous community of the Waunnan’s, creating good jobs and steady income and in that way it will contribute to the improvement of the quality of their life in the city. The café will serve as a place for them and the other Chocó communities to preserve their traditions and culture through performances, handcraft workshops, food and other activities. 

3.    To strengthen communities with everything mentioned above as well as reinvesting 70% of the Café’s profit into further work and processes with families from the Chocó region. Maria Panela will also facilitate work spaces where the families can receive training and advisory for their projects.

 

 How?

The social processes with the families will be split down to five phases, each phase lasting one year:

1.    CONSCIOUSNESS: The aim is for the group to unlearn the helplessness of a life dependent on aid and embody new ways of social innovation and community development. 

2.    TRAINING: They will acquire skills that support them in adapting into the city life, the labor market and in the generation of sustainable businesses and organizations.

3.    LIFE PLAN: Based on the training phase they will now start building life plans: viable and sustainable, they also allow each individual to be part of the Community Living Plan. In this way, it is intended that all community members are competent to take on life and together sustain and preserve their heritage and create decent living conditions for themselves

4.     SUPPORT: The community will have the permanent support of María Panela’s team to start their life plan.

5.    CONSULTING: We support specific issues that the community requires and will monitor their achievements.

From the fifth year, community groups begin to be more independent and only receive support in the form of specific advices. Their connection to the project will though stay strong as once each group completes the process of the five phases they are a part of supporting a new group starting on the plan. This will generate more dynamic project and greater the impact!

María Panela has the experience of starting up innovation Café´s that are built on values of fair trade and community impact. The Maria Panela team furthermore has an extensive knowledge and background in working with community development and education. We therefore believe all this will together create a strong foundation to build our project on. 

The group is already working on different approaches to reach its goal and all contributions count! We will need 40.000 dollars to be able to invest in a location, to get the interior, the machinery and utensils to be able to open the café for the public as soon as possible.

We have a unique opportunity to celebrate and thank the supporters of the project since our resources within art and culture as well as social business are quite big. Not to forget the café itself and all the possibilities the projects holds. Please take a look at our profits on the right side and see how well can contribute to our project.

Our goal is set to flexible since we will continue to fund raise the money with other methods if we can't reach our goal. We really do hope though that the café can come to reality by the amazing concept that crowd funding is! 

All contributions to the project will go on supporting the families of Choco!

If you can't support us with money but would like to help please share our project and story with as many as possible! We highly appreciate it!

For more information about María Panela and the KaosPilots please click on these links!

http://www.kaospilot.dk/
http://mariapanela.com/ 

 

---

MISIÓN CHOCÓ

 

 

Misión Chocó es un proyecto social, empresarial, creativo, pero sobre todo humanitario.  Es una co-creación, una colaboración entre familias que enfrentan la situación de desplazamiento en Colombia, los empleados de la empresa social María Panela y un grupo de estudiantes de una escuela de negocios creativos en Dinamarca llamada KaosPilots.


El Contexto


El departamento del Chocó es una de las zonas más complejas de Colombia.  Situado en el noroeste del país, limita con Panamá y tiene costas sobre el Caribe y el Pacífico. La mayoría de Chocó es de baja altitud bosque húmedo tropical (es uno de los lugares más lluviosos del mundo), aunque en el sur y en el este comienza a subir en las montañas.  Es un paraíso natural, en el cual habitan una gran diversidad de especies vegetales y animales.  La zona es rica en recursos naturales y hogar de miles de familias afroamericanas e indígenas, pasando por todas las mezclas raciales, y un sin límite de miradas culturales y tradiciones ancestrales.

Irónicamente, su riqueza natural y la baja presencia gubernamental, generó las condiciones propicias para la creación de corredores de drogas, tanto en términos de producción como de transporte hacia las costas que ha atraído grupos armados y afectado directamente a la población, generando un alto índice de desplazamiento forzado que no sólo afecta la calidad de vida de las personas, sino pone en riesgo el patrimonio inmaterial de la humanidad en términos de lenguas y cultura.

En la zona el acceso a la educación no es fácil, sea por distancia, infraestructura, bajos niveles de tecnología o insuficiencia en la planta docente; todo lo anterior desencadena en pobres resultados académicos de los estudiantes, colocándolos en el nivel más bajo de la escala educativa en el país.  

De otro lado, lo económico gira en torno a una extracción primaria de recursos naturales que generan limitadas opciones de trabajo. 

Todo lo anterior es un caldo de cultivo que desemboca en el  imaginario de que la capital ofrece oportunidades de trabajo y educación que no se ofrecen en el Chocó. Sin embargo, al llegar a la ciudad el sueño se desvanece pues conseguir empleo es difícil, la incorporación al sistema educativo no es inmediata ni gratuita, y no existe como en la selva la opción de alimentación a través del pan coger, llegan a una selva de cemento que no produce alimentos.

Pese a diversas iniciativas sociales y gubernamentales, las condiciones tanto en el departamento como en la ciudad no han mejorado notablemente.  Nuestra perspectiva sugiere que una de las razones es que la mayoría de apoyos han sido asistencialistas y generan dependencia en lugar de fortalecimiento comunitario.

Uno de los ejemplos cercanos es el grupo con el que pilotearemos nuestra iniciativa:  la familia indígena Waunnan:  Llegó a la ciudad hace más de nueve años y aún no consiguen sostenibilidad ni acceso a una vida digna.  Dependen de la venta de sus artesanías lo cual genera ingresos aproximados de $200.000 por familia de mínimo cuatro miembros, que no entran ni siquiera de manera constante.  Eso los hace dependientes a subsidios y ayudas gubernamentales y no gubernamentales que requieren una alta inversión de tiempo.

 

El Proyecto

Misión Chocó es un proyecto liderado por la organización María Panela con el apoyo de un grupo de estudiantes de KaosPilots,  que busca beneficiar directamente a la familia indígena Waunnan con opciones de trabajo.  Junto a este proyecto, se piloteará en dos grupos más, el fortalecimiento comunitario a través de la formación y desarrollo de un plan comunitario. 


El centro del proyecto consiste en generar el Café de Innovación María Panela Chocó que requiere de 40.000 dólares para su montaje y puesta en marcha.  Este café tendrá tres objetivos centrales:

 

¿Qué? 

  1. Promover la región del Chocó mostrando su belleza, riqueza natural y cultural, así como sus necesidades.  Sensibilizando así a la población hacia la movilización de recursos a la zona no de manera asistencialista sino con el objetivo de generar desarrollo humano armónico y sostenible a largo plazo.
     
  2. Generar ingresos para la comunidad siendo vitrina comercial de las comunidades Chocoanas.   Lo anterior operando bajo el modelo de comercio justo para poner en venta sus hermosas artesanías y mostrar lo que hay detrás de cada uno de sus productos, así que no serán simples productos sino obras de arte con poder de transformación.  El lugar, será atendido por miembros de la comunidad indígena Waunnan, buscando con ello contribuir al mejoramiento de su calidad de vida en la ciudad, con un empleo digno que genere ingresos constantes.  Esta y otras comunidades del Chocó harán presentaciones culturales, talleres de artesanías, de comidas y de todo aquello que contribuye al rescate de las tradiciones, la cultura y las lenguas ancestrales, buscando con ello impactar positivamente en los espacios y grupos urbanos.
     
  3. Fortalecer a las comunidades a través de la generación de espacios de trabajo y la reinversión del 70% de la utilidad del Café de Innovación en dichos procesos, así como  facilitar espacios de trabajo para los grupos comunitarios en la ciudad en dónde recibirán capacitación y asesoría para sus proyectos.

¿Cómo? 

El trabajo social que se deriva de este proceso se realizará con cada grupo en cinco fases, cada una con duración de un año:

  1. Concienciación: Se desaprenderán las viejas maneras asistencialistas de buscar ayuda y se construirán nuevas formas de innovación social para el desarrollo comunitario, siendo consientes que si bien las condiciones de entorno y raza no dependen de nosotros sí lo que hagamos con ellas y nuestro destino.
  2. Capacitación: Se adquirirán competencias que permitan la adaptación a la ciudad, la inserción en el mercado laboral y la generación de empresas u organizaciones sostenibles.
  3. Plan de vida: Una vez aprobada la fase de capacitación se buscará la construcción de planes de vida: viables y sustentables, que además, permitan a cada individuo ser arte y parte del Plan de Vida Comunitario.  De esta manera se pretende que todos los miembros de la comunidad sean competentes para asumir la vida y juntos rescaten, mantengan y posicionen el legado inmaterial que traen de sus ancestros, dentro de unas condiciones de vida dignas.
  4. Soporte: La comunidad tendrá el acompañamiento permanente del equipo María Panela para poner en marcha su plan de vida.
  5. Asesoría: Se apoyarán temas puntuales que requiera la comunidad y se realizará seguimiento de sus logros.

 

A partir del quinto año los grupos comunitarios empezarán a ser independientes y obtendrán asesorías puntuales cuando lo requieran, pero no un apoyo permanente.  Su vinculo se mantendrá activo cambiando hacia el liderazgo puesto que una vez un grupo completa su proceso (cinco fases) apadrina a otro grupo en su dinámica para generar mayor impacto y fortalecimiento.

 

María Panela cuenta con la experiencia en el montaje de Cafés de Innovación, compartiendo los mismos valores de comercio justo e impacto comunitario; y el equipo de proyección social cuenta con amplia experiencia en el desarrollo comunitario y educación, lo cual genera una mezcla ganadora para nuestro proyecto. 

 

Su apoyo!


El equipo se encuentra trabajando en diferentes enfoques para llegar a la meta y todas las contribuciones cuentan!.  Necesitamos 40.000 dólares para poder invertir en la adecuación de un lugar, la maquinaria y utensilios para que el Café pueda entrar a operar lo antes posible.


Tenemos una oportunidad única para celebrar y agradecer a los patrocinadores del proyecto, ya que nuestros recursos tanto en el arte y la cultura, como en nuestro modelo social son bastante grandes.  Tenemos para esto diversas opciones, pues cada donante, de acuerdo al monto, puede tener: su nombre en los diversos espacios del café, postales y artesanías que tendrá como recuerdo. Por favor, eche un vistazo a nuestros beneficios en el lado derecho y así también vea cuánto pueden contribuir a nuestro proyecto.

Nuestra meta es flexible, ya que vamos a seguir recaudando fondos con otros métodos, si no podemos alcanzar nuestra meta.  Realmente esperamos que a través de hacer realidad el Café de Innovación podamos mostrar el asombroso concepto que es el financiamiento solidario!


Todas las ayudas sobre la meta fijada van a entrar en el apoyo a las familias del Chocó!

Si usted no nos puede apoyar con dinero, pero le gustaría ayudar por favor, comparta nuestro proyecto y la historia con el mayor número de personas posible. ! Realmente lo apreciamos!


Para obtener más información acerca María Panela y los KaosPilots, por favor haga clic en los enlaces.

http://www.kaospilot.dk/
http://mariapanela.com/

It is a natural paradise, home to a huge diversity of plant and animal species.  The area is rich of natural resources and a home to thousands of Afro-American and indigenous families, through all racial mixtures, and unlimited cultural views and ancestral traditions.
Sadly, its natural wealth and the low government presence, created the suitable conditions to the creation of drug-runners, both in terms of production and transportation to the coast which has attracted armed groups directly and affected the population, generating a high rate of forced displacement that not only affects quality of people’s life, but jeopardizes the intangible heritage of humanity in terms of language and culture.
In the region the access to education is not easy, either by distance, infrastructure, poor levels of technology or lack of teachers, all of the above triggers in poor academic performance of students which places them in the bottom of the educational scale in the country.
 The economic of the region is primarily focused on the extraction of natural resources that makes the employment options very limited.
This naturally leads to a shared idea in the society that the capital offers employment and educational opportunities that do not exist in Chocó. However the reality is that when the families reach the city the dreams and hopes of finding a job fades a way quite fast. On top of that the educational system is not free or always easy to start immediately and unlike the green jungle where food grows everywhere the city in only a jungle of concrete 
Despite social and governmental initiatives, conditions in both the region and the city have not improved significantly. In our opinion one of the reasons are that the initiatives have been in the form of aid and have created learned helplessness and dependency rather then strengthening the community.
 One of our closes examples is the group that we will cooperate with in this project, the Waunnan’s. They are an indigenous family that came to the city over nine years ago but still haven’t manage to find a sustainable way to get an income for a respectable life. They are dependent on selling their handcrafts that generates revenue of about 200.000 pesos (113 US$) for a family of at least four members. This is not an income they can rely on being constant. It makes them very dependant on support from the government as well as non-governmental aid that is very time consuming.
 
THE PROJECT
Mission Choco is a project led by Maria Panela organization and supported by a group of the KaosPilots‘s students. It seeks to directly benefit the indigenous family Waunnan with job options. Alongside this project, we will make a pilot projects of community strengthening with two more groups, through training and the development of a community plan. 
The focus of the project is to build the Innovation Café: María Panela Chocó that requires $ 40,000 to build the café and get it running.  This coffee will have three main objectives:
 
What?
 1.    To promote the Choco region by showing it’s beauty, natural and cultural wealth as well as their needs. Bringing awareness to the possibilities and resources to create a sustainable and helpful development for the families instead of a dependant and short-term assistance. 
2.    To generate income for the community by sales platform for Chocó’s communities. It will be run according to the Maria Panela fair trade model where they can start selling their beautiful handcrafts and show what is behind each of their products, that is not mere commodities but a piece of art. The café will be staffed with members of the indigenous community of the Waunnan’s, creating good jobs and steady income and in that way it will contribute to the improvement of the quality of their life in the city. The café will serve as a place for them and the other Chocó communities to preserve their traditions and culture through performances, handcraft workshops, food and other activities. 
3.    To strengthen communities with everything mentioned above as well as reinvesting 70% of the Café’s profit into further work and processes with families from the Chocó region. Maria Panela will also facilitate work spaces where the families can receive training and advisory for their projects.
 
 How?
The social processes with the families will be split down to five phases, each phase lasting one year:
1.    CONSCIOUSNESS: The aim is for the group to unlearn the helplessness of a life dependent on aid and embody new ways of social innovation and community development. 
2.    TRAINING: They will acquire skills that support them in adapting into the city life, the labor market and in the generation of sustainable businesses and organizations.
3.    LIFE PLAN: Based on the training phase they will now start building life plans: viable and sustainable, they also allow each individual to be part of the Community Living Plan. In this way, it is intended that all community members are competent to take on life and together sustain and preserve their heritage and create decent living conditions for themselves
4.     SUPPORT: The community will have the permanent support of María Panela’s team to start their life plan.
5.    CONSULTING: We support specific issues that the community requires and will monitor their achievements.
From the fifth year, community groups begin to be more independent and only receive support in the form of specific advices. Their connection to the project will though stay strong as once each group completes the process of the five phases they are a part of supporting a new group starting on the plan. This will generate more dynamic project and greater the impact!
María Panela has the experience of starting up innovation Café´s that are built on values of fair trade and community impact. The Maria Panela team furthermore has an extensive knowledge and background in working with community development and education. We therefore believe all this will together create a strong foundation to build our project on. 
The group is already working on different approaches to reach its goal and all contributions count! We will need 40.000 dollars to be able to invest in a location, to get the interior, the machinery and utensils to be able to open the café for the public as soon as possible.
We have a unique opportunity to celebrate and thank the supporters of the project since our resources within art and culture as well as social business are quite big. Not to forget the café itself and all the possibilities the projects holds. Please take a look at our profits on the right side and see how well can contribute to our project.
Our goal is set to flexible since we will continue to fund raise the money with other methods if we can't reach our goal. We really do hope though that the café can come to reality by the amazing concept that crowd funding is! 
All contributions to the project will go on supporting the families of Choco!
If you can't support us with money but would like to help please share our project and story with as many as possible! We highly appreciate it!
For more information about María Panela and the KaosPilots please click on these links!http://www.kaospilot.dk/http://mariapanela.com/ 
 
---
MISIÓN CHOCÓ
 
 
Misión Chocó es un proyecto social, empresarial, creativo, pero sobre todo humanitario.  Es una co-creación, una colaboración entre familias que enfrentan la situación de desplazamiento en Colombia, los empleados de la empresa social María Panela y un grupo de estudiantes de una escuela de negocios creativos en Dinamarca llamada KaosPilots.

El Contexto

 El departamento del Chocó es una de las zonas más complejas de Colombia.  Situado en el noroeste del país, limita con Panamá y tiene costas sobre el Caribe y el Pacífico. La mayoría de Chocó es de baja altitud bosque húmedo tropical (es uno de los lugares más lluviosos del mundo), aunque en el sur y en el este comienza a subir en las montañas.  Es un paraíso natural, en el cual habitan una gran diversidad de especies vegetales y animales.  La zona es rica en recursos naturales y hogar de miles de familias afroamericanas e indígenas, pasando por todas las mezclas raciales, y un sin límite de miradas culturales y tradiciones ancestrales.
Irónicamente, su riqueza natural y la baja presencia gubernamental, generó las condiciones propicias para la creación de corredores de drogas, tanto en términos de producción como de transporte hacia las costas que ha atraído grupos armados y afectado directamente a la población, generando un alto índice de desplazamiento forzado que no sólo afecta la calidad de vida de las personas, sino pone en riesgo el patrimonio inmaterial de la humanidad en términos de lenguas y cultura.
En la zona el acceso a la educación no es fácil, sea por distancia, infraestructura, bajos niveles de tecnología o insuficiencia en la planta docente; todo lo anterior desencadena en pobres resultados académicos de los estudiantes, colocándolos en el nivel más bajo de la escala educativa en el país.  
De otro lado, lo económico gira en torno a una extracción primaria de recursos naturales que generan limitadas opciones de trabajo. 
Todo lo anterior es un caldo de cultivo que desemboca en el  imaginario de que la capital ofrece oportunidades de trabajo y educación que no se ofrecen en el Chocó. Sin embargo, al llegar a la ciudad el sueño se desvanece pues conseguir empleo es difícil, la incorporación al sistema educativo no es inmediata ni gratuita, y no existe como en la selva la opción de alimentación a través del pan coger, llegan a una selva de cemento que no produce alimentos.
Pese a diversas iniciativas sociales y gubernamentales, las condiciones tanto en el departamento como en la ciudad no han mejorado notablemente.  Nuestra perspectiva sugiere que una de las razones es que la mayoría de apoyos han sido asistencialistas y generan dependencia en lugar de fortalecimiento comunitario.
Uno de los ejemplos cercanos es el grupo con el que pilotearemos nuestra iniciativa:  la familia indígena Waunnan:  Llegó a la ciudad hace más de nueve años y aún no consiguen sostenibilidad ni acceso a una vida digna.  Dependen de la venta de sus artesanías lo cual genera ingresos aproximados de $200.000 por familia de mínimo cuatro miembros, que no entran ni siquiera de manera constante.  Eso los hace dependientes a subsidios y ayudas gubernamentales y no gubernamentales que requieren una alta inversión de tiempo.
 
El Proyecto
Misión Chocó es un proyecto liderado por la organización María Panela con el apoyo de un grupo de estudiantes de KaosPilots,  que busca beneficiar directamente a la familia indígena Waunnan con opciones de trabajo.  Junto a este proyecto, se piloteará en dos grupos más, el fortalecimiento comunitario a través de la formación y desarrollo de un plan comunitario. 
 El centro del proyecto consiste en generar el Café de Innovación María Panela Chocó que requiere de 40.000 dólares para su montaje y puesta en marcha.  Este café tendrá tres objetivos centrales:
 

¿Qué? 

Promover la región del Chocó mostrando su belleza, riqueza natural y cultural, así como sus necesidades.  Sensibilizando así a la población hacia la movilización de recursos a la zona no de manera asistencialista sino con el objetivo de generar desarrollo humano armónico y sostenible a largo plazo. 
Generar ingresos para la comunidad siendo vitrina comercial de las comunidades Chocoanas.   Lo anterior operando bajo el modelo de comercio justo para poner en venta sus hermosas artesanías y mostrar lo que hay detrás de cada uno de sus productos, así que no serán simples productos sino obras de arte con poder de transformación.  El lugar, será atendido por miembros de la comunidad indígena Waunnan, buscando con ello contribuir al mejoramiento de su calidad de vida en la ciudad, con un empleo digno que genere ingresos constantes.  Esta y otras comunidades del Chocó harán presentaciones culturales, talleres de artesanías, de comidas y de todo aquello que contribuye al rescate de las tradiciones, la cultura y las lenguas ancestrales, buscando con ello impactar positivamente en los espacios y grupos urbanos. 
Fortalecer a las comunidades a través de la generación de espacios de trabajo y la reinversión del 70% de la utilidad del Café de Innovación en dichos procesos, así como  facilitar espacios de trabajo para los grupos comunitarios en la ciudad en dónde recibirán capacitación y asesoría para sus proyectos.

¿Cómo? 
El trabajo social que se deriva de este proceso se realizará con cada grupo en cinco fases, cada una con duración de un año:


Concienciación: Se desaprenderán las viejas maneras asistencialistas de buscar ayuda y se construirán nuevas formas de innovación social para el desarrollo comunitario, siendo consientes que si bien las condiciones de entorno y raza no dependen de nosotros sí lo que hagamos con ellas y nuestro destino.

Capacitación: Se adquirirán competencias que permitan la adaptación a la ciudad, la inserción en el mercado laboral y la generación de empresas u organizaciones sostenibles.

Plan de vida: Una vez aprobada la fase de capacitación se buscará la construcción de planes de vida: viables y sustentables, que además, permitan a cada individuo ser arte y parte del Plan de Vida Comunitario.  De esta manera se pretende que todos los miembros de la comunidad sean competentes para asumir la vida y juntos rescaten, mantengan y posicionen el legado inmaterial que traen de sus ancestros, dentro de unas condiciones de vida dignas.

Soporte: La comunidad tendrá el acompañamiento permanente del equipo María Panela para poner en marcha su plan de vida.

Asesoría: Se apoyarán temas puntuales que requiera la comunidad y se realizará seguimiento de sus logros.
 
A partir del quinto año los grupos comunitarios empezarán a ser independientes y obtendrán asesorías puntuales cuando lo requieran, pero no un apoyo permanente.  Su vinculo se mantendrá activo cambiando hacia el liderazgo puesto que una vez un grupo completa su proceso (cinco fases) apadrina a otro grupo en su dinámica para generar mayor impacto y fortalecimiento.
 
María Panela cuenta con la experiencia en el montaje de Cafés de Innovación, compartiendo los mismos valores de comercio justo e impacto comunitario; y el equipo de proyección social cuenta con amplia experiencia en el desarrollo comunitario y educación, lo cual genera una mezcla ganadora para nuestro proyecto. 
 
Su apoyo!
 El equipo se encuentra trabajando en diferentes enfoques para llegar a la meta y todas las contribuciones cuentan!.  Necesitamos 40.000 dólares para poder invertir en la adecuación de un lugar, la maquinaria y utensilios para que el Café pueda entrar a operar lo antes posible.
 Tenemos una oportunidad única para celebrar y agradecer a los patrocinadores del proyecto, ya que nuestros recursos tanto en el arte y la cultura, como en nuestro modelo social son bastante grandes.  Tenemos para esto diversas opciones, pues cada donante, de acuerdo al monto, puede tener: su nombre en los diversos espacios del café, postales y artesanías que tendrá como recuerdo. Por favor, eche un vistazo a nuestros beneficios en el lado derecho y así también vea cuánto pueden contribuir a nuestro proyecto.
Nuestra meta es flexible, ya que vamos a seguir recaudando fondos con otros métodos, si no podemos alcanzar nuestra meta.  Realmente esperamos que a través de hacer realidad el Café de Innovación podamos mostrar el asombroso concepto que es el financiamiento solidario!
 Todas las ayudas sobre la meta fijada van a entrar en el apoyo a las familias del Chocó! Si usted no nos puede apoyar con dinero, pero le gustaría ayudar por favor, comparta nuestro proyecto y la historia con el mayor número de personas posible. ! Realmente lo apreciamos!
 Para obtener más información acerca María Panela y los KaosPilots, por favor haga clic en los enlaces.
http://www.kaospilot.dk/http://mariapanela.com/

story:
My name is Teja Shankara and I am a western yogini, which means I do yogic spiritual practices designed to take me to a state of inner Peace. I am passionate about helping to raise the vibration of the human species so that we can all live in a world community of Peace. In Ashland, Oregon, U.S.A., I work hard as a cheerleader for spiritual practices, through leading a weekly Radiance Rising Circle, writing regular articles on the Teja Blog on my website, and promoting my self-published books. This campaign will support me in continuing the good work I am already doing, as well as help me in branching out into other communities.

 

I intend to lead Radiance Rising Circles at promotional events, so that many people can experience the inner Peace that arises through doing spiritual practices, like the ones I outline in my pocket book, Radiance Rising: Spiritual Practices for Daily Living. Through doing regular daily practices, such as silent meditation, I have healed myself almost entirely of depression, migraine headaches, anxiety, insomnia, and destructive thought patterns. Now I am inspired to teach others how to heal themselves through spiritual practices.

 

The funding need for this campaign is $36,000. Specifically, that amount will fund the following: $12,000 – 6 months of fees for a fiery publicist who will widely promote my books, blogs, and circles; $12,000 – expenses for promotional events in several U.S. cities (including L.A., Portland, and Phoenix), and workshop fees for me to improve my skills in leading spiritual practices (Kirtan workshop with Jai Uttal and Spiritual workshop with Ram Dass); $12,000 – 6 months of living expenses (I am very good at keeping to a monthly budget).

 

If the total amount of this campaign is not reached, the campaign will still happen in part – any monies received will be used to initiate the campaign’s stated goals. Each donor of $10 or more will receive an e-book copy of Radiance Rising. And, anyone donating $100 or more will receive a print copy of Radiance Rising. Donors of $1,000 or more will receive all three of my books. Donors of $5,000 or more will receive all three books plus Reiki healing energy will be sent to them (by distance) for 30 days.

 

I am a new voice speaking for a very old tradition, that of the yogis and yoginis of ancient India. Please say “Yes! Yogini!” and help me spread the word about this campaign to raise the vibration of the human species, thereby increasing Peace on this sacred planet Earth. Please tell all your friends and utilize the share tools here on the IndieGoGo site! Thank you so much. Namaste. I bow to the Divine within you that is also within me. http://www.yogini-bliss.com

story:
Short Summary

 

"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has."- Margaret Mead


I should probably start off with what drives me toward these types of projects. As far back as I can remember there has been this feeling in my gut that there was so much that was wrong, and that I needed to do something about it. When I was younger I would see the homeless and always ask my mom if we could help them. I convinced my parents to adopt a child from the T.V. infomericals as a child, because the images upset me so much. I get very angry at the issues that our world faces, mostly because I'm so saddened by the horrible issues that people encounter. I believe that there is always hope. In such a big world it's easy to feel like what we do doesn't make a difference, but I have seen that idea to be incorrect. Personally growing up there were some obstacles that I encountered which were difficult and hard to deal with, but there were always people in my life who cared and strived to ensure that I was given the best chance to succeed in this world. People matter. What people say and do matters more than anything else. People matter more than money, and politics, and religion. At the end of the day we are all people with the same emotional capabilities and capacity for love and that is why I know that my purpose on this earth is to help as much as I possibly can and contribute positively where I can be of assistance. I want to be a servant to the world, even if that world only involves my small community. I fervently believe that the smallest actions can have huge ripple effects.

I am currently pursuing my Bachelor's in Global Studies from Arizona State University. I also work on campus as a Peer Ambassador creating programs for exploratory freshman who are in the process of choosing a major. In order to graduate, my major requires that I study abroad. I applied, and I am so honored and excited to have been accepted to go on a volunteer community development program in Vietnam, rather than do a conventional internship or study abroad program through the university. The programs place volunteers in a variety of projects in and around Hanoi (the capital of Vietnam) and in Ho Chi Minh City (formerly Saigon) including teaching English and French, caring for disabled children and working with local Non-governmental organizations. In the information I have been given I have been told to understand that resources are extremely limited in the institutions I will be working. Therefore, any supplies volunteers can bring, appropriate to their program are always appreciated by the local people and staff.


My role as a volunteer in Vietnam is to augment the provision of English in institutions where under-staffing and skills shortages are an issue. The teaching programs are based in either a Vietnamese school or community centre catering to pupils of both primary and high school age. Of invaluable assistance to the local teachers on the project, the volunteer teacher assists with classroom management, educational activities and games. I would also have to opportunity caring for disabled children at a residential school which educates around 60 orphans who would otherwise be homeless, volunteers in Vietnam provide much-needed support and assistance. The government-owned facility caters for orphans aged five to twenty who are housed in single-sex dorms. The facility continues its support of students through either university or vocational studies. Duties mainly involve teaching the children English, organising and helping out with extra-curricular activities, as well as playing with the children. There are plans to introduce HIV and AIDS education as a contribution to reducing the size of the threat which this disease poses in Vietnam. Depending on personal inclination, volunteers can also lend a hand in the kitchen, which provides an opportunity to acquire traditional Vietnamese cooking skills.


http://www.lovevolunteers.org/programs/childcare-volunteers-vietnam-community-work-volunteers-vietnam


What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this possible I have decided to fund-raise. That's where all you lovely and gracious people come in. As a college student obviously I am not rolling in dough and in this tough economy I am aware that many people have been struggling and continue to do so. For those of you who have been blessed with the finances and would like to donate It would be greatly appreciated. For those of you cannot help financially I would greatly appreciate your prayers and positive thoughts. I would love any kind of support that you are willing to offer. I have currently raised $1000 and I am currently trying to raise another $1500. My flight alone cost $1500, the program fee is another $600, plus the insurance cost is about $200, and there are other minor expenses that the rest would cover.

Now a task like this can seem daunting, because it is so much money, but any small amount that you could contribute would be significant and it really adds up. For example, If 100 people donate $5 each then I would have $500 dollars or if 100 people donate $10 each then I would be at $1000, you get my point. Any small sacrifice that you could give would not go in vain and would be deeply appreciated.

The Impact

I often hear people comment that change is not possible, but any positive meaningful impact that you can have on one person is a step towards change. Likewise I often hear people comment about all the unfortunate social issues that individuals face. Through your donation you not only help me achieve this dream of mine, but you also indirectly affect the lives of children. I am a firm believer that we can constantly learn new things especially from different cultures, and my hope is that what I learn there will transform me into a better person.

I would love any support you can give me and I hope that you would take my plea to heart and help me on this journey. Sending many blessings your way :)

Thanks,

Rebecca Denis

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word!
