Likewise I often hear people comment about all the unfortunate social issues that individuals face. Through your donation you not only help me achieve this dream of mine, but you also indirectly affect the lives of children. I am a firm believer that we can constantly learn new things especially from different cultures, and my hope is that what I learn there will transform me into a better person.I would love any support you can give me and I hope that you would take my plea to heart and help me on this journey. Sending many blessings your way :)Thanks,Rebecca Denis
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Please spread the word!

story:
The Story


Mr Grampa and The Magic Hat helps chronically ill children tap into their inner magic and empowers them to be brave. If they believe in magic they get to wear the Magic Hat. Once they have the Magic Hat on, they get to mix their magic with the hat magic and then get to put their fear into the hat and take out the courage they need to get through the next hospital procedure they are faced with. This is done with storytelling and play.


The Mr. Grampa project is unique in that it not only addresses the childs needs but the needs of the parents and caregivers as well. By helping the child magically transform their fear into courage relieves stress and anxiety for all concerned thereby creating a calmer healing enviroment. The child in effect becomes a participant in their own healing process.


The Statistics Of Childhood Cancer Are Staggering.


According to the CDC (center for disease control) in Atlanta, just the numbers for 2007 were 14,235 children under the age of 21 diagnosed with some sort of cancer. Thats 39 per day, every day. That does not include those diagnosed before or since and does not include any adults. Now imagine those kids feeling more courageous and empowered in their own healing process while the parents and caregivers are feeling less stress and anxiety. That is the goal. We are building an extended community of like minded people who reach out from a place of genuine knowing because they have faced the exact circumstances faced by newly diagnosed patients and parents.


What Does Your Financial Support Provide?


a. I have written a book and it needs to be illustrated, published

b. Development and manufacturing of the Magic Hat. (the sale of the first two items hopefully will support our efforts to grow and bring help nationwide.)

c..Web site design and development with 3 chat rooms. Kids, Moms, DADS

d. Business start up costs.

e.Office equipment/staff


About Me And The Mr. Grampa Project.


This project evolved from my experience of having a child who has had Cancer 6 times over the last 33 years. I have been dealing with this emotional roller coaster for all that time. In order to survive I underwent 15years of therapy, volunteered 8 years in hospice, and worked with kids with cancer or kids who's parent or grandparent has cancer. My experience is all from in the trenches, not learned from a book. A decided edge when it comes to dealing with a distraught parent. I represent a strong, positive male voice in this arena.


If we go over the initial amount of money requested it will help us make this happen in more places, faster. If you believe in this project please send this link to your friends, family, business contacts asking them to do the same. That way we have a lot of people getting involved with a worthwhile project that will help our most vulnerable population, our kids.


Anyone contributing any amount will be listed on my web-site under the heading PEOPLE WITH HEART AND VISION. I will list you by state and name only. Hopefully this will generate a little competition among states. In all events the kids will benefit and that is what counts. Take a moment and go over the rewards and see which makes the most sense for you and don't forget to pass the link to your contacts.

story:
About Blackhawk Learning Connection

Blackhawk Learning Connection's mission is to provide quality, affordable child care so that low-to-moderate-income families residing in Rockford can achieve and maintain economic independence.

Blackhawk Learning Connection strives daily to meet each child's physical, emotional, social, and intellectual needs.  We are able to do so through your generous donations and contributions.  If you would like to make a difference, please make a donation today.  Your donation will help Blackhawk Learning Connection continue to provide exceptional care.

What We Need & What You Get

Blackhawk Learning Connection uses your generous donations to provide children with educational tools, books, reading materials, healthy lunches, and many other things that help create a positive learning environment.  We can't do it without your support!  We proudly feature each donor's name on our donor wall with a plaque in your honor.

The Impact

Your donation goes directly toward supporting Blackhawk Learning Connection and makes an incredible difference in the life of one of our children and their family.  Thanks to your support, low-to-moderate income families can depend on us for quality child care while they go to work, pursue an education, or volunteer in their community.  You are making a very real difference to very real people.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would rather make a different type of contribution, Blackhawk Learning Connection is always in need of the following items:

  • Children's clothing (ages 6 weeks to 10 years)
  • Children's books (Spanish and English, preschool to school-age)
  • Small blankets
  • Art supplies
  • School-age games
  • Computer games
  • Computers

Visit our website at http://www.blackhawklearning.com for more information!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Get Thomas Back to class campaign!

We are the Diploma Class 2014 at St. George TAFE NSW. We have established a committee to fundraise to bring Thomas back to class to complete his studies.

Thomas is an asylum seeker on a Temporary Visa. He flew persecution in his native country and left everything including his family (wife and 4 children) to seek protection in Australia. He is also living with a physical disability and cannot get local work in the manual fields. Whilst awaiting Refugee status, Thomas is not able to afford or raise his college tuition costs. He’s therefore been stopped from attending classes. 

What We Need

TAFE NSW Full Year Fee:                                    Au $ 1,514.00

Temporary Visa Holder(TVH) Tuition Fees:  Au $ 9,097.00

Indiegogo Charges (9%):                                      Au $  954.99

                                                                 Total    Au $ 11,565.99

What We Will Do

·  When we reach (50 + 9)% we will pay fees for the 1st Semester

·  When we reach the remaining 50% we will clear tuition for 2nd Semester

·  Any excess amount will be donated to any charity agreed by the class

All payment options to TAFE NSW are outlined in the Tax Invoice

Your voluntary and kind donation is much-needed for Thomas to;  

    • Urgently safeguard his education;
    • Complete his Diploma and acquire much needed skills for employability;
    • Contribute enormously in the community services industry 

Despite living with physical disability, Thomas has a lot of overseas experience in the administration and management of Social Justice Programs. A local qualification like the Diploma in Community Services will make him an invaluable addition to the community services workforce!

Please Share Our Campaign with Others!

Thank you so much for your support - your contribution will make a difference in the life of an exceptionally needy asylum seeker.

story:
We are seeking access to a computer & some funds to assist our office for Embrace the Amazon to further reforesting efforts by the people who live there:

  • Technology will assist us in so many ways. What is taken for granted as normal is highly prized and valued here, a computer gives us such access to things so much more easily. (one email with documents can save a 100 mile drive)
  • My name is Roney and along with some other passionate farmers we have established an OSCIP (which is similar to an NGO only a legally established identity) named ADAMAZA. We live right in the heart of Rondonia which is one of the most deforested areas in the Amazon basin.
  • Our ultimate goal is to reforest the devastated areas we live in. We have many plans and processes in place all of which are dependant on each other but basically the groundwork has been done and now the rest begins. (The video above shows the amount of deforestation in the State I live in over a few years - that is many thousands of miles)

Please take a moment to see our brief overview here and there is a link below it to our new website if you would like to see more details


What We Need & if you can help

Our immediate need is to purchase a computer and have some funds to allow one of us to continue visiting with radio stations in outer areas :

    • 1000 USD aprox for A computer (to allow us efficient access to product and supplies)
    •   400 USD aprox for Transport budget (this will allow us to complete the final stage of our initial phase)
    •    200 USD aprox for promotional package spots on 5 major radio stations
    •    100 USD for fast internet connection to start the project
    • If our funding goal is not reached: we will use the funds to the most effect computer being the first priority. 
    • If the funding goal is exceeded: thankyou -  depending on the amount we would be very happy to purchase a second computer , do further promotion, purchase much needed business supplies such as the funds received will allow.


Just so you know, its taken Roney a borrowed video recorder and a 200 mile round trip to a lanhouse (internet cafe) and another 6 hours to upload this video.. there are more to come but time did not allow for further uploads today.. The connection in the local area will make such a huge difference to local life.

THE IMPACT

You can see some of our major projects here:


  • All the groundwork has been laid, in effect we the people in the Amazons' most affected deforestation area, committed to returning the balance. Have the plans and heart to do the job even against the odds. 
  • We have gained the support of a number of groups who are assisting in numerous ways from within the Amazon and the other side of the globe. 
  • As there has been such a history of distrust we need to "show proof" which is what we will do with this first phase of the project,  
    In effect proving to farmers there are far more sustainable ways to provide an income for your family than slash and burn farming and cattle grazing. This is always forced on family farms by being effectively squeezed out. 
  • With your help we can make a real difference in real life situations while we build a trust bank and more importantly a future bank with our children - knowing that the trees are worth more alive than dead.

Other Ways You Can Help

We certainly understand some folks cannot contribute financially, but if you can help in other ways we would love to hear from you also:

  • Spreading the word is a major help so if you can share in your network that will be very helpful
  • Visiting and sharing our brand new facebook page where we will share our stories
  • Translation (English Spanish Portuguese)
  • Our web development has taken a huge leap and we have a very large intranet to assist with education and farming practises, if you have skills you are willing to share in these areas we would love to hear from you.
    Looking to seed our Agricultural Wiki now.
  • Maybe if you need a Tshirt or other item, new products are being added as we expand, you could take a look at our website knowing the money goes directly to the people on the land.


PERKS - Some of our Popular bumper stickers.. 

More PERKS ON THE WAY -- Getting photos together for some wonderful handmade items 

THE CATALYST: Millions of Small farmers in devastated areas of Amazonia in Brazil are disheartened, trust no one, have no hope for a better life – they are cutting down thousands of precious fruit and Cocoa trees (thousands!!!) on their properties, because the middle men pay almost nothing for their produce, so to gain a living they cut down trees to plant grass in order to raise cattle – which are easier to care for and they need no helpers.

They then counsel their sons and daughters to go away, to large cities to get a “better education” and become “qualified” professionals. These small farmers and their wives get old and sick, and go to the large cities without an income to suffer to the end of their lives. The large farmers and huge companies then buy their land for nothing.

Compounding the problem is when their sons and daughters enter further into the forest, devastating new areas to start their lives – and so, the problem only grows, “silently” during the nights.

My background was in a Non Profit organisation in the capital city of Brazil for 18 years, I moved here for a quiet life, but was somewhat taken aback by the local situation, now I am a small farmer who wants to give a better future for my only son and for the sons and daughters of those millions. But how to do that alone? It is impossible.  My family currently bake breads at home to sell.  If I stop baking them at home and stop selling them from door to door how can I take care of my families needs and still help others? 

There are varied long term projects that encompass education to practical job and ongoing skills for the actual people who live in the areas all requiring a REforest agreement to proceed, ensuring a spreading success.
All done in a way to use and protect natural resources as their precious money making machines.

100 PERK :  Personalized (from choices provided)

story:
HOBY WORLD LEADERSHIP CONGRESS GLOBAL CHALLENGE

WHAT AND WHEN: The 2014 Hugh O'Brian Youth (HOBY) World Leadership Congress (WLC) will take place in Chicago, Illinois from July 19-26, 2014 at Loyola University-Chicago.  The WLC brings together 400+ rising high school juniors from all over the world to participate in an eight-day leadership development seminar, that will leave the Ambassadors (the students) inspired and eager to return to their communities to positively impact the world around them.

THE PROJECT

In 2014 HOBY WLC ambassadors will participate in a series of mentored workshops to develop an action based idea or organization.  Ambassadors should consider ideas that will  have a positive impact in their high school, community, state, country or the world.  The theme of the 2014 WLC is "It Starts Here."  We are hoping, with your support, ambassadors will develop a plan that will serve as a concrete foundation for them to implement their idea after returning home.  Mini grants will be awarded to a minimum of the top seven ideas in order to put those ideas into action once each ambassador returns home.  The goal of this project is to create a ripple effect of change that will have started at the 2014 HOBY World Leadership Congress.

THE GRANT: Seven Ambassadors will receive a start-up grant in a minimum amount of $250.

SELECTION CRITERIA

  1. Sustainability of the idea/activity/event/organization

  2. Likelihood of impact

  3. The purpose that it serves

WHEN THE RECIPIENTS WILL BE ANNOUNCED:  The recipients will be announced at the 2014 HOBY WLC Closing Ceremonies on July 25, 2014.

story:
To my Village,

In less than 2 months, I will be a SENIOR at Croton Harmon High School (Class of 2015)! Where has the time gone? I wanted to tell you I have been offered a memorable opportunity for this Summer and I am writing to you to request your help in making it happen!


I applied to this really amazing art camp offered by the New York State Summer Schools of the Arts (NYSSSA). I submitted my art portfolio full of examples of work from the past three years and I got accepted! (http://www.oce.nysed.gov/nysssa/SVA/)

I would go and room in the dorms at SUNY Fredonia with 95 other selected students for four weeks over the summer. While I’m there, I would take two intensive art classes, a 2D material class and a 3D material class and receive a full year High School Art credit. I have several friends who have gone to this program and have had wonderful experiences. I feel like this is an amazing chance to improve my art skills and expand my creative horizons. 


The full tuition for this program is $2100. This covers room and board, as well as the two classes and all the art supplies I will need. I am trying to fundraise half the tuition and some travel. 


I am so proud to be accepted to this program and would appreciate any donation to help me get there. THANK YOU for your support over all these years. It has not gone unnoticed!

Warmest thoughts,

Delaney Buccellato-Ritchie

I wanted to tell you I have been offered a memorable opportunity for this Summer and I am writing to you to request your help in making it happen!I applied to this really amazing art camp offered by the New York State Summer Schools of the Arts (NYSSSA). story:
Overview:

HipHopForChange, Inc. uses grassroots activism to educate people about socio-economic injustices and advocate solutions through hip hop culture.  We raise funds for local causes that enrich marginalized and historically oppressed communities.
Supporting this project means keeping this organization's mission active through our Grassroots team!  These individuals work with other organizations that support under-served populations around the Bay.

The Campaign:

New tracking software for our Outreach office: $400

Data analysis for an academic evaluation of our educational program: $300

Supplies for our Grassroots Officers: $300

The Impact:

Our Grassroots department is responsible for disseminating information and examples of progressive hip hop culture and artists. By building relationships with our community, the program seeks to engage people with the broader national context of socio-economic injustices and raise funding for local solutions.

Your support means our Grassroots department can further grow and flourish this year, thereby forwarding our mission in the Bay Area community.


Spread the Word!
Please, tell your friends about this campaign.  Share with your community via social media.  Any money we raise over our goal will go toward our organization's mission and commitment to education and social justice!

story:
The youtube video is part of a documentary called "War Dance" It shows the children in Uganda back in 2007 and shows us a part of their daily lives and what they've gone through<br>

Who I am and How I Got Involved

My name is Mikala Bietschek and I grew up in a pretty small town. I'm a college student at Portland Community College and that's where I met a good friend of mine, Winnie. She is a translator from Uganda and at a little party she threw I got to know some of the people that go on these trips. Well after about ten minutes I was hooked and excited to go!

What We Do

The church group that i'm going with have made several trips to Africa before. The church is the Abundant Life Church and they partner with Ukids and  Christian Life Ministries (our ministry partner in Uganda) to make this happen. They have worked hard on their physical needs like clean drinking water and structural needs like building schools and covered areas. Now they are in Uganda helping their emotional needs. They are actually there right now! When they get back they'll figure out the dates of their next trip which will be in the summer and I will be going with them.

The next trip will be focusing on kids emotional needs and they have been

These kids have been through things we can't even begin to comprehend, they have been child soldiers, watched their families die, been beaten and tortured, and other terrible things. The problem is that so many are becoming orphans and in such large numbers that they get lost in the shuffle. Well we're going to change that. We'll be going from house to house talking to the children and help the mums who take care of them giving them the attention they deserve. We'll be partnering with a group called Memory Books for Children and each child will receive a memory book designed to help them tell their stories using writing, drawing, crafts, drama, music and storytelling. Helping them heal is what we are trying to do.

What I Need

How this is designed is each team member is responsible for their own fundraising, the money goes towards my airfare, hotel, and all the expenses in between. If I have any left over it will go towards either the next trip for me or another, or I will buy things to take to the children such as flop flips (which they love!)

Just think (if you can get anywhere close to understanding because I know I can't) If you had to watch your family die, be abducted from your home, separated from any siblings you may have left, and being put into a rebel army where they will kill you if you don't kill others? That's what these kids have to go through, not to mention not being allowed to go home and put into a military protected camp where you have to depend of food the military can provide because of these rebel armies. This is what we are going for, to help teach these kids to heal. One on one attention which they are so lacking.

Anything you can give will help and if you can't donate talk to you friends, your families, even your neighbors! Please help me on my mission trip to Uganda!

And bless you for your kindness, even if you can't give anything.

story:
Summary

I am the Manager of Education Programs for Land's Sake, a non-profit farming and forestry education organization. Our programs take place on our diversified vegetable farm in the heart of Weston where we cultivate over 20 acres of town-owned land using organic practices. Our mission is to connect people to the land, and we engage youth of all ages in community building while they participate in meaningful experiences around farm and woodland ecology. Our education programs reach over 3,000 students from Weston, Waltham, Sudbury, Wellesley, and surrounding communities, including over 120 urban youth from two Boys and Girls Clubs in the City of Boston.


This winter our chicken coop was repeatedly broken into by a predator, and several of our chickens were killed. Due to the extreme amount of snow over the winter, one of the supports that held up the bird netting collapsed allowing easier access to the chickens. The coop is in a general state of disrepair and children are no longer able to walk inside to interact with the chickens. The old coop is very small and makes it nearly impossible for kids to help clean it and reach the eggs.  Our goal is to have a small team of supporters build a new coop that is kid-friendly and safe for our chickens to live in. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need building supplies to construct the coop. I have a high school student who has produced a mock-up of a new coop and priced out how much it would cost. The coop itself is $800 with the addition of an outside run being around $200. Any additional funds we raise above $1000 will be put towards renovating our rabbit tractors and creating a better winter home for them. 

For donations of $10 we will send you a Land's Sake sticker!

For donations of $20 you will get a sticker and a personalized photo of one of our chickens!

For donations of $50 you will get a sticker, a photo, and a dozen eggs (if you live within driving distance to the farm, we can't ship those!)

For donatios of $100 or more you will get a sticker, a photo, a dozen eggs, and we will name one of the six nesting boxes after you!

The Impact

Currently our chickens are being housed in three temporary homes after the coop was damaged. Your donation will make it possible to reunite all of chickens in the same safe environment. The chicken coop is an integral part of most of our education programs. For example, our local kindergarten students come once every season to visit the farm and see how it changes over time. The chickens are always a major stop on this tour and they discuss eggs, feathers, and what chickens need to survive each season. Having a kid-friendly, large walk-in coop will make this part of their experience much more meaningful and interactive. Our chickens are also a daily part of our summer camp programs and kids help to care for them and our rabbits every day. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign!  You can also volunteer to help on the farm and take on other projects for the education garden. Our budget for infrastructure and supplies is very small and we are always in need of volunteer donations and time.  

THANK YOU FROM ALL OF OUR FEATHERED FRIENDS!

story:
A Madagascar, 70% de la population vit en milieu rural et 80% vit essentiellement des activités agricoles. Cette population paysanne produit la plus grande part de l'alimentation de la population dans l'ensemble. Mais cette population qui travaille dur et qui nourrit les populations "riches" des villes est la plus pauvre, la plus vulnérable et la plus mal nourrie. Ceci est généralement dû à une structure socio-économique néo-esclavagiste de fait et en grande partie à la faiblesse du développement du secteur agricole dans les campagnes malgaches faisant du paysan un acteur toujours asservi, dépendant des intermédiaires et acheteurs profiteurs des villes. Notons que ce phénomène existe partout en Afrique.

La permaculture (de culture permanente), est une discipline holistique qui vise le bien-être des humains en harmonie avec la nature. C'est une approche nouvellement promue par Ecovillage Madagascar sur le territoire malgache. Fort de son expérience sur d'autres unités déjà mises en place, Ecovillage Madagascar organise un atelier de renforcement et de création du 2 au 14 Novembre 2014, avec ces 12 jours de travaux intensifs durant lequel des spécialistes de différentes nationalités vont collaborer avec les paysans locaux malgaches pour mettre en place un modèle de système permacultural permettant d'atteindre l'autosuffisance alimentaire et l'indépendance totale du paysan à moyen terme.


Ecovillage Madagascar (voir notre site sur www.ecovillagemadagascar.com) est un projet couvrant 5 ha de terrain servant en même temps de site de production d'aliments sains et naturels, de site de formation à la permaculture, de site d'expérimentation et recherche-action et un site de détente et de relaxation pour ceux qui cherchent le calme et la sérénité à 30km de la capitale bruyante et polluée de Madagascar, Antananarivo.

Le site est structuré en plusieurs unités permaculturales dont l'évolution varie. L'unité N°6 sur la carte ci-dessous fait l'objet du  présent projet.



L'unité N° 6 couvre environ 1200m² et est en pente avec une dénivellation d'environ 25m. De grandes surfaces avec des pentes douces se trouvent en amont et des rizières se trouvent en aval sur le bas fond. Le terrain est exposé à l'ouest et est venteux. Le sol est actuellement pauvre mais un petit cours d'eau tiré des sources en amont y passe et permet d'irriguer toute la pente.

Le défi est de construire une unité permaculturale bien conçue pour permettre l'autonomie totale à moyen et long terme. Ecovillage se propose de réaliser ce défi dans un délai de 12 jours avec une équipe d'une vingtaine de personnes.

Le projet prévoit 

  1. la construction d'un petit éco-habitat pour les paysans qui vont y habiter et travailler 
  2. la construction et l'aménagement de tout le système de rétention d'eau (petits étangs) et d'irrigations (canaux)
  3. la construction des terrasses avec les plantations
  4. la plantation d'arbres pionniers avec une serre ou pépinière et un petit atelier de travail
  5. la mise en place de différents éléments classiques d'un système permacultural tel que compostière, lombricompostière, spirale d'herbes aromatiques, tracteur à poule ...

Cette illustration donne une idée d'un scénario de transformation du paysage de l'unité N°6 après 2 à 3 ans d'existence. Les fondations seront mis en place durant les 12 jours de la formation, y compris les terrasses, les canaux, la maison et la plantation d'arbres bénéfiques.


Votre contribution et votre appui permettront de supporter :

  • les charges pédagogiques (matériel et formateurs) qui s'élèveront à 10% du budget, la plupart des formateurs étant des volontaires
  • les constructions et l'achat des matériaux de construction utilisés durant l'atelier de formation, le tout s'élevant à environ 50% du budget
  • les frais (alimentation, hébergement, indemnité) des paysans volontaires qui travailleront sur le site durant les 12 jours (environ 25% du budget)
  • la production d'un documentaire de 20min qui capitalisera le processus et les résultats de travaux effectués durant les 12 jours (15% du budget)

Les travaux les plus coûteux (en matériaux et main d'oeuvre) sont:

  • l'éco-habitat rural (pouvant accueillir jusqu'à 4 personnes et construit avec des matériaux entièrement locaux)
  • la serre/pépinière avec une partie atelier de travail et rangement
  • la fabriquation des étangs et systèmes de canalisations pouvant atteindre 80m
  • la construction de terrasses pour les plantations

Ci-desous quelques éco-constructions déjà en place à l'Ecovillage Madagascar.

Les autres dépenses seront les semences, jeunes plants d'arbre, les petits outils nécessaires etc... Nous pourrons toujours faire bon usage des moyens que vous mettrez à notre disposition quel que soit le montant collecté.

Pour que votre contribution soit mémorable et gravé quelque part et en signe de remerciement, nous vous offrons :

  • l'insertion de votre identité (nom ou logo ...) en tant que contributeur ou sponsor (selon votre contribution) figurant dans la vidéo qui sera produite et et publiée en ligne ainsi que dans le site web d'Ecovillage Madagascar (www.ecovillagemadagascar.com)
  • une possibilité d'hébergement gratuit à Ecovillage (repas malgache et nuité gratuits) pour vous ou un proche que vous recommanderez si vous passez par Madagascar dans le futur (un délai est toutefois prévu).


Les premières unités permaculturales qui ont été développées à Ecovillage Madagascar ont entraîné des changements importants dans la qualité de vie des paysans et l'environnement dans lequel ces derniers vivent. La première unité a débutée en Décembre 2013 et a pris plus de six mois pour atteindre un niveau de maturité tendant progressivement vers l'autosuffisance et le sentiment de liberté.

Le succès de la mise en oeuvre et de la capitalisation d'une expérience d'implémentation modèle en 12 jours dans l'Ecovillage aura un impact non négligeable sur les paysans et le monde rural à Madagascar:

  • au niveau local, la connaissance et la technicité des paysans augmenteront et s'amélioreront significativement avec la quinzaine de packages techniques permaculturaux qui seront enseignés par différents spécialistes venant de différents pays durant les 12 jours. Cette formation entraînera une amélioration notable des techniques pratiquées et la qualité de vie des populations rurales comme ce qui a été observé dans les unités tendant vers la maturité précédente
  • au niveau national et plus généralement, la production et la diffusion du reportage sur le modèle renforceront et accéléreront la multiplication de tels systèmes. Le film produit servira de guide et de source d'inspiration pour ceux qui souhaiteraient réaliser des projets similaires dans le futur

Supportez cette initiative ! Engagez-vous et supportez cette initiative noble.

Si vous ne pouvez contribuer financièrement, il existe d'autres moyens pour nous supporter :

  • Influencez votre entourage et tous ceux que vous connaissez, les personnes influentes, les écologistes, les entrepreneurs qui ont de l'éthique et faites passer le message. Faites un peu de publicité pour le projet (le lien raccourci pour ce site est  http://igg.me/at/freedom-with-permaculture
  • Demandez à ceux que vous connaissez et qui peuvent supporter financièrement ce projet de contribuer
  • Envoyez-nous des idées et suggestions d'améliorations. Notre page de contact est: http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/
  • Venez nous rendre visite et vous former et/ou faire du volontariat à Ecovillage Madagascar 
  • Devenez nos amis à long terme et collaborons à d'autres occasions, vous pouvez toujours nous contacter sur  http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/



Around 70% of the Malagasy population lives in rural areas with 80% of them surviving with agricultural activities. Peasantry produces food for a major proportion of the Malagasy population, They work hard to nourish "rich" people living in town but they are the mostly poor, vulnerable and undernourished.

This situation is the result of an unbalanced neo-slavery socio-economic structure encouraged by the weak development of the agricultural sector in the Malagasy countryside. Farmers are always dependent on intermediaries and buyers from town who take advantage from their ignorance.

Permaculture (from permanent culture) is a holistic planning method to design harmonious human-nature relations e.g. through architecture and agriculture techniques. It's a relatively new approach on the red island Madagascar and it is promoted by Ecovillage Madagascar.

Thanks to previous experiences in setting up other Permaculture units, Ecovillage Madagascar will organize a design and implementation training workshop from 2nd to the 24th of November 2014. During 12 days, specialists from different countries will collaborate with local farmers to build a model Permaculture system which aims at food self-sufficiency and later total independence for the farmers who will stay there.

Ecovillage Madagascar project (website : www.ecovillagemadagascar.com) covers 5ha of land which serves at the same time as a production site (for organic and natural food), a Permaculture training site, an experimental and action-research site and a site for relaxation for those who look for calm and serenity, 30km from the loud and polluted capital of Madagascar, Antananarivo.

The site is structured in seven Permaculture units with different progress status. This fundraising project is related to Unit # 6 on the map below.

Unit # 6 covers around 1.200 sqm on a slopy land totaling a gradient of 25m. More land is available above it and the rice field is at the bottom. The land is exposed to the West and is often windy. The soil is actually very poor but a water source and a canal from the upper side allows to irrigate all the land on the slopy side.

The challenge is to build a clever Permacutlure unit design to achieve total autonomy in the medium and long term. The Ecovillage will take this challenge and try to design and implement the unit in 12 days with a team of around 20 people.

The project plans to:

  1. build a small eco-habitat for the farmers who will stay there
  2. build the water system including the ponds and the swales for irrigation
  3. build the terraces for plantation
  4. plant pioneer trees with a greenhouse and build a nursery during a workshop
  5. build and put in place different elements such as compost heap, worm compost, herb spiral, chicken tractor etc ...

This illustration gives an idea of a scenario of landscape transformation at unit #6 after 2 to 3 years. The foundation will be put in place within 12 days of intense training and collaborativd work with local farmers, including the terraces, the swales, the house and plantation of beneficial trees.

Your contribution and support will cover :

  • training expenses (material and trainers), around 10% of the budget, note that most trainers are volunteering
  •  construction costs including materials to be used during the training workshop, around 50% of the budget
  • basic expenses (food, accommodation and stipend) for volunteers and local farmers, who will work onsite during the 12 days (around 25% of the budget)
  • the production of a 20 min documentary video capitalizing the process and the results of the work done during the 12 days (around 15% of the budget)

Most expensive items (because of material and labor) are:

  • the construction of the rural eco-habitat (this place will be designed to host up to 4 persons and will be build with earth bricks on site)
  • the greenhouse/nursery and workshop 
  • the construction of ponds and swale systems (maybe up to 80m length)
  • the construction of terraces for the plantation
Below are some existing eco-constructions built at Ecovillage Madagascar.

Other expenses are seeds, tree seedlings, tools for the workshop etc ... in any case we will use your donation efficiently and update you on our website.

Because we would like your contribution to be memorable and casted somewhere and for acknowledgement, we will offer:

  • the insertion of your logo/name as a contributor or sponsor in the credits of the video that will be produced and published online on the Ecovillage Madagascar website (www.ecovillagemadagascar.com)
  • a free stay (including accomodation and malagasy food) for you or a relative you will recommend if you come Madagascar sometimes in the future (there are some deadlines)

The first Permaculture units developed at Ecovillage Madagascar has triggered important changes in the quality of life of the local peasants and their environment. Started in December 2013, the first unit has taken almost 6 months to reach its level of maturity progressing slowly toward self-sufficiency and freedom.

The successful implementation and capitalization of the 12 day eco-implementation will probably have a huge impact and role model effect on the peasantry and rural places in Madagascar:

  • at local grassroot level: knowledge and techniques will increase, during the 12 days the farmers is given the 15+ Permaculture technical packages taught by international specialists from different countries 
  • at national level and at a more general level: the production and dissemination of the movie will enhance and accelerate the replication of the system that will be put in place. The film will serve as a guideline and source for inspiration for those who are willing to realize similar projects in the future.

If you can't contribute financially, there are many other ways to support us:

  • Influence your surrounding and everybody you know, influential people, ecologists and entrepreneurs with ethics. Spread the word. Do some ads for this project. The short link to this fundraising site is  http://igg.me/at/freedom-with-permaculture
  • Ask others you may know and who are able to contribute financially 
  • Send us more ideas and suggestions for improvements. Our contact page is: http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/
  • Come visit us or come to be trained and volunteer at Ecovillage Madagascar 
  • Become our long term friend and let's collaborate in other projects. You have access to us, just contact us at http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/
story_txt:
A Madagascar, 70% de la population vit en milieu rural et 80% vit essentiellement des activités agricoles. Cette population paysanne produit la plus grande part de l'alimentation de la population dans l'ensemble. Mais cette population qui travaille dur et qui nourrit les populations "riches" des villes est la plus pauvre, la plus vulnérable et la plus mal nourrie. Ceci est généralement dû à une structure socio-économique néo-esclavagiste de fait et en grande partie à la faiblesse du développement du secteur agricole dans les campagnes malgaches faisant du paysan un acteur toujours asservi, dépendant des intermédiaires et acheteurs profiteurs des villes. Notons que ce phénomène existe partout en Afrique.La permaculture (de culture permanente), est une discipline holistique qui vise le bien-être des humains en harmonie avec la nature. C'est une approche nouvellement promue par Ecovillage Madagascar sur le territoire malgache. Fort de son expérience sur d'autres unités déjà mises en place, Ecovillage Madagascar organise un atelier de renforcement et de création du 2 au 14 Novembre 2014, avec ces 12 jours de travaux intensifs durant lequel des spécialistes de différentes nationalités vont collaborer avec les paysans locaux malgaches pour mettre en place un modèle de système permacultural permettant d'atteindre l'autosuffisance alimentaire et l'indépendance totale du paysan à moyen terme.Ecovillage Madagascar (voir notre site sur www.ecovillagemadagascar.com) est un projet couvrant 5 ha de terrain servant en même temps de site de production d'aliments sains et naturels, de site de formation à la permaculture, de site d'expérimentation et recherche-action et un site de détente et de relaxation pour ceux qui cherchent le calme et la sérénité à 30km de la capitale bruyante et polluée de Madagascar, Antananarivo.Le site est structuré en plusieurs unités permaculturales dont l'évolution varie. L'unité N°6 sur la carte ci-dessous fait l'objet du  présent projet.L'unité N° 6 couvre environ 1200m² et est en pente avec une dénivellation d'environ 25m. De grandes surfaces avec des pentes douces se trouvent en amont et des rizières se trouvent en aval sur le bas fond. Le terrain est exposé à l'ouest et est venteux. Le sol est actuellement pauvre mais un petit cours d'eau tiré des sources en amont y passe et permet d'irriguer toute la pente.Le défi est de construire une unité permaculturale bien conçue pour permettre l'autonomie totale à moyen et long terme. Ecovillage se propose de réaliser ce défi dans un délai de 12 jours avec une équipe d'une vingtaine de personnes.Le projet prévoit 
la construction d'un petit éco-habitat pour les paysans qui vont y habiter et travailler 
la construction et l'aménagement de tout le système de rétention d'eau (petits étangs) et d'irrigations (canaux)
la construction des terrasses avec les plantations
la plantation d'arbres pionniers avec une serre ou pépinière et un petit atelier de travail

la mise en place de différents éléments classiques d'un système permacultural tel que compostière, lombricompostière, spirale d'herbes aromatiques, tracteur à poule ...

Cette illustration donne une idée d'un scénario de transformation du paysage de l'unité N°6 après 2 à 3 ans d'existence. Les fondations seront mis en place durant les 12 jours de la formation, y compris les terrasses, les canaux, la maison et la plantation d'arbres bénéfiques.Votre contribution et votre appui permettront de supporter :
les charges pédagogiques (matériel et formateurs) qui s'élèveront à 10% du budget, la plupart des formateurs étant des volontaires
les constructions et l'achat des matériaux de construction utilisés durant l'atelier de formation, le tout s'élevant à environ 50% du budget

les frais (alimentation, hébergement, indemnité) des paysans volontaires qui travailleront sur le site durant les 12 jours (environ 25% du budget)

la production d'un documentaire de 20min qui capitalisera le processus et les résultats de travaux effectués durant les 12 jours (15% du budget)
Les travaux les plus coûteux (en matériaux et main d'oeuvre) sont:
l'éco-habitat rural (pouvant accueillir jusqu'à 4 personnes et construit avec des matériaux entièrement locaux)
la serre/pépinière avec une partie atelier de travail et rangement

la fabriquation des étangs et systèmes de canalisations pouvant atteindre 80m

la construction de terrasses pour les plantations

Ci-desous quelques éco-constructions déjà en place à l'Ecovillage Madagascar.Les autres dépenses seront les semences, jeunes plants d'arbre, les petits outils nécessaires etc... Nous pourrons toujours faire bon usage des moyens que vous mettrez à notre disposition quel que soit le montant collecté.Pour que votre contribution soit mémorable et gravé quelque part et en signe de remerciement, nous vous offrons :
l'insertion de votre identité (nom ou logo ...) en tant que contributeur ou sponsor (selon votre contribution) figurant dans la vidéo qui sera produite et et publiée en ligne ainsi que dans le site web d'Ecovillage Madagascar (www.ecovillagemadagascar.com)

une possibilité d'hébergement gratuit à Ecovillage (repas malgache et nuité gratuits) pour vous ou un proche que vous recommanderez si vous passez par Madagascar dans le futur (un délai est toutefois prévu).

Les premières unités permaculturales qui ont été développées à Ecovillage Madagascar ont entraîné des changements importants dans la qualité de vie des paysans et l'environnement dans lequel ces derniers vivent. La première unité a débutée en Décembre 2013 et a pris plus de six mois pour atteindre un niveau de maturité tendant progressivement vers l'autosuffisance et le sentiment de liberté.Le succès de la mise en oeuvre et de la capitalisation d'une expérience d'implémentation modèle en 12 jours dans l'Ecovillage aura un impact non négligeable sur les paysans et le monde rural à Madagascar:
au niveau local, la connaissance et la technicité des paysans augmenteront et s'amélioreront significativement avec la quinzaine de packages techniques permaculturaux qui seront enseignés par différents spécialistes venant de différents pays durant les 12 jours. Cette formation entraînera une amélioration notable des techniques pratiquées et la qualité de vie des populations rurales comme ce qui a été observé dans les unités tendant vers la maturité précédente

au niveau national et plus généralement, la production et la diffusion du reportage sur le modèle renforceront et accéléreront la multiplication de tels systèmes. Le film produit servira de guide et de source d'inspiration pour ceux qui souhaiteraient réaliser des projets similaires dans le futur

Supportez cette initiative ! Engagez-vous et supportez cette initiative noble.Si vous ne pouvez contribuer financièrement, il existe d'autres moyens pour nous supporter :
Influencez votre entourage et tous ceux que vous connaissez, les personnes influentes, les écologistes, les entrepreneurs qui ont de l'éthique et faites passer le message. Faites un peu de publicité pour le projet (le lien raccourci pour ce site est  http://igg.me/at/freedom-with-permaculture

Demandez à ceux que vous connaissez et qui peuvent supporter financièrement ce projet de contribuer
Envoyez-nous des idées et suggestions d'améliorations. Notre page de contact est: http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/

Venez nous rendre visite et vous former et/ou faire du volontariat à Ecovillage Madagascar 
Devenez nos amis à long terme et collaborons à d'autres occasions, vous pouvez toujours nous contacter sur  http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/


Around 70% of the Malagasy population lives in rural areas with 80% of them surviving with agricultural activities. Peasantry produces food for a major proportion of the Malagasy population, They work hard to nourish "rich" people living in town but they are the mostly poor, vulnerable and undernourished.This situation is the result of an unbalanced neo-slavery socio-economic structure encouraged by the weak development of the agricultural sector in the Malagasy countryside. Farmers are always dependent on intermediaries and buyers from town who take advantage from their ignorance.Permaculture (from permanent culture) is a holistic planning method to design harmonious human-nature relations e.g. through architecture and agriculture techniques. It's a relatively new approach on the red island Madagascar and it is promoted by Ecovillage Madagascar.Thanks to previous experiences in setting up other Permaculture units, Ecovillage Madagascar will organize a design and implementation training workshop from 2nd to the 24th of November 2014. During 12 days, specialists from different countries will collaborate with local farmers to build a model Permaculture system which aims at food self-sufficiency and later total independence for the farmers who will stay there.Ecovillage Madagascar project (website : www.ecovillagemadagascar.com) covers 5ha of land which serves at the same time as a production site (for organic and natural food), a Permaculture training site, an experimental and action-research site and a site for relaxation for those who look for calm and serenity, 30km from the loud and polluted capital of Madagascar, Antananarivo.The site is structured in seven Permaculture units with different progress status. This fundraising project is related to Unit # 6 on the map below.Unit # 6 covers around 1.200 sqm on a slopy land totaling a gradient of 25m. More land is available above it and the rice field is at the bottom. The land is exposed to the West and is often windy. The soil is actually very poor but a water source and a canal from the upper side allows to irrigate all the land on the slopy side.The challenge is to build a clever Permacutlure unit design to achieve total autonomy in the medium and long term. The Ecovillage will take this challenge and try to design and implement the unit in 12 days with a team of around 20 people.The project plans to:
build a small eco-habitat for the farmers who will stay there
build the water system including the ponds and the swales for irrigation
build the terraces for plantation

plant pioneer trees with a greenhouse and build a nursery during a workshop
build and put in place different elements such as compost heap, worm compost, herb spiral, chicken tractor etc ...

This illustration gives an idea of a scenario of landscape transformation at unit #6 after 2 to 3 years. The foundation will be put in place within 12 days of intense training and collaborativd work with local farmers, including the terraces, the swales, the house and plantation of beneficial trees.


Your contribution and support will cover :



training expenses (material and trainers), around 10% of the budget, note that most trainers are volunteering

 construction costs including materials to be used during the training workshop, around 50% of the budget

basic expenses (food, accommodation and stipend) for volunteers and local farmers, who will work onsite during the 12 days (around 25% of the budget)
the production of a 20 min documentary video capitalizing the process and the results of the work done during the 12 days (around 15% of the budget)

Most expensive items (because of material and labor) are:


the construction of the rural eco-habitat (this place will be designed to host up to 4 persons and will be build with earth bricks on site)
the greenhouse/nursery and workshop 
the construction of ponds and swale systems (maybe up to 80m length)
the construction of terraces for the plantation


Below are some existing eco-constructions built at Ecovillage Madagascar.




Other expenses are seeds, tree seedlings, tools for the workshop etc ... in any case we will use your donation efficiently and update you on our website.
Because we would like your contribution to be memorable and casted somewhere and for acknowledgement, we will offer:



the insertion of your logo/name as a contributor or sponsor in the credits of the video that will be produced and published online on the Ecovillage Madagascar website (www.ecovillagemadagascar.com)


a free stay (including accomodation and malagasy food) for you or a relative you will recommend if you come Madagascar sometimes in the future (there are some deadlines)




The first Permaculture units developed at Ecovillage Madagascar has triggered important changes in the quality of life of the local peasants and their environment. Started in December 2013, the first unit has taken almost 6 months to reach its level of maturity progressing slowly toward self-sufficiency and freedom.
The successful implementation and capitalization of the 12 day eco-implementation will probably have a huge impact and role model effect on the peasantry and rural places in Madagascar:


at local grassroot level: knowledge and techniques will increase, during the 12 days the farmers is given the 15+ Permaculture technical packages taught by international specialists from different countries 
at national level and at a more general level: the production and dissemination of the movie will enhance and accelerate the replication of the system that will be put in place. The film will serve as a guideline and source for inspiration for those who are willing to realize similar projects in the future.



If you can't contribute financially, there are many other ways to support us:


Influence your surrounding and everybody you know, influential people, ecologists and entrepreneurs with ethics. Spread the word. Do some ads for this project. The short link to this fundraising site is  http://igg.me/at/freedom-with-permaculture

Ask others you may know and who are able to contribute financially 
Send us more ideas and suggestions for improvements. Our contact page is: http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/

Come visit us or come to be trained and volunteer at Ecovillage Madagascar 
Become our long term friend and let's collaborate in other projects. You have access to us, just contact us at http://ecovillagemadagascar.com/contact/

story:
Hello everyone! I will be furthering my education at Kingston University near London, England this summer, and am looking for a bit of help. I attend the University of Wisconsin La Crosse as a full time student and student athlete. I have been working four days a week, as well as for the school newspaper. I have always disliked the idea of asking for help, but given the minuscule amount of financial aid and loan eligibility i am able to receive going into my senior year of college, i am forced to ask for some assistance. 

I will be going into my senior year in the fall at UW-L and am a double major in English rhetoric and philosophy, with the plan to take the LSATS next winter to see if a degree in law is something i may be able to pursue. I have participated in collegiate level competition in track and field, while also keeping multiple steady jobs. I also do a 3 hours of volunteer work mentoring with Big Brothers Big Sisters every week, as well as other volunteer work through my track program.

In England I will be taking part in a 6 credit program labeled the "Street Haunting" program. One class will be through the faculty going on the trip with us, and the other will be through the University. The program will allow me to go on MANY field trips allowing me to sight-see and explore Europe. Studying abroad has always been a dream of mine and i'm finally going to give myself this opportunity. 

Every penny that i raise will be going to my summer tuition that is estimated at $5,500. Every cent is appreciated to an extent that i cannot begin to express in words. I hope that i can raise enough money to help the financial burden that has resulted from my decision to study abroad, which to me, is an experience that i can't put a price on (but the University can!). Thank you to all that choose to donate, and even to those that have simply taken the time to read about my cause!

story:
The Project

Play On, Philly! ("POP") fosters life skills among its participants by providing high-quality music education to children who would otherwise not receive it. Founded in 2011 with 110 students at St. Francis de Sales School in West Philadelphia, Play On, Philly! is proving that music education can be a force for social change. POP added a second site last year at Freire Charter Middle School in Center City, and now provides  a tuition-free opportunity to master a standard orchestral instrument as well as instruction in choir, general music, composition, chamber music, and orchestra to more than 200 students. Teaching artists from the Philadelphia region lead daily three-hour practice sessions, and students receive opportunities to publicly perform with and be inspired by world-class artists like Bobby McFerrin, Wynton Marsalis, Sir Simon Rattle, and Philadelphia’s own Maestro Yannick Nézet-Séguin of The Philadelphia Orchestra.

This campaign will help fund our summer music program.  The summer program provides 5 weeks of full day music instruction and activities, and two meals daily to Philadelphia students. This program is an extension of our yearly program and provides our students with the opportunity to enhance their music skills during the summer and attend a tuition-free summer program. POP cannot provide this programming without generous support from the community. 

The Goal

We need only $10,000 to reach our goal of $100,000 to fully fund this wonderful project. This funding will support everything from teacher salaries to sheet music to instruments and more.

Each donation is vital to our organization. Perks for donations include recognition in all printed materials, thank you notes from our students, and even dinner with our founder, Stanford Thompson.

All donations will go directly to the 2014 summer program and will help build an invaluable experience for our students. 

The Impact

Your contribution will help us to continue our programming throughout the summer. Our overall program goals include:

•  Participants will develop goal-directed behavior and skills that increase academic and social success.

•  Participants will have improved self-esteem.

•  Participants will show increased academic motivation, achievement and school attendance.

•  Participants will gain high-level musical knowledge and performance skills.

Play On, Philly! has made a significant impact in Philadelphia in pursuit of these goals and our greatest accomplishment has been the effect of our programming on the youth we serve. Last school year, POP initiated a formal evaluation program developed and executed by WolfBrown consulting firm. The first report of this on-going study indicates that Play On, Philly! has a direct impact on students’ academic achievement, prosocial skills, and executive functioning.

Moreover, Play On, Philly! is redefining after school programming and providing an orchestral music education for students who are underserved. Our outcome measures prove that POP programming enriches our students’ lives by deepening their engagement in school, fostering prosocial skills, and improving executive functions, which are the building blocks to sustained goal-directed behavior and academic achievement.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate funds please consider helping Play On, Philly! by spreading the news about our organization and our work. You can like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, and check out our website's "News" section, which highlights recent events and upcoming concerts.

Play On, Philly! is a once in a lifetime experience for students in Philadelphia. Please help us to continue our important programming this summer.

story:
Sprouting Synergy's mission is to create synergy between Illinois small businesses and non-for-profits and Illinois community colleges through student competitions for business initiatives. Our website will bring together the beneficial learning experiences for students and low cost, innovative solutions to businesses.  Our goal is to allow students to unleash their creativity and developing knowledge from classes to help solve business, marketing, economic and technological challenges facing small businesses and non-for-profits, who are limited by small budgets.  Our low cost, high quality, professor monitored consulting services will allow small businesses and non-for-profits to have successful and profitable initiatives completed within 12 weeks.  

Instructors: want to show your students that the theories you are teaching in class are actually applicable in real life?  Want to give students opportunities to make contacts with local businesses? Want to show students what skills they need to be successful in the real world?  We are here for you.  Support our website development and you will have real world projects with real Chicagoland small businesses and non-for-profits.  We will provide you with project descriptions, rubrics and prizes for your in-class competitions.  We will make you the highest rated teachers on ratemyprofessor.com and the educational leaders at your local colleges.

Small businesses and non-for-profits: Low on funds and have lots of projects you would like done?  Want low cost and high quality consulting services in management, marketing, pricing and web development?  Want a new fresh approach of a beginner with the experience of a professional?  We are here for you.  We will take your projects to the future leaders in industry and have them compete for your prizes.  All projects supervised by seasoned professors and completed within 15 weeks or less.  Help us develop the future successful employees of your firms and we will help you grow your businesses. 

We want your financial support to develop the website that brings local businesses and local non-for-profits together with local community college students to create and complete projects.  Your donations will be used to develop this website, find projects and converting the projects into assignments for college professors to use.  The more money we collect, the faster we will be able to bring our project to life. 

We appreciate any kind of help you can give us!  Donations are great but we can also use the hype.  Please use the Indiegogo share tools and watch for us on Facebook, Twitter and Google+.

story:
WHO WE ARE

Nick VandenBosch, D.O. and I (Terrence (TJ) Williams) are recent graduates of medical school and law school respectively.  After graduating in 2011, we decided that we wanted to reach back a helping hand and help pull the next generation up.  We decided to launch The WV Foundation (WVF) in 2012 with the intention of producing fun, exciting, family-friendly events, and using the proceeds to offer opportunities of higher education and exciting life experience for the youth in our communities.  In seeking assistance in launching the WVF  we were faced with many people telling us to “wait until we were more settled in our careers to try to do this”, and when we said our goal for the first year was to award $10,000 in scholarship we were told we needed to “crawl before we could walk”.  We are proud to say that we have awarded nearly $25,000 in scholarships since 2012. 

WHAT WE NEED

We need help in funding our annual Scholarship Program and Community growth initiatives, the proceeds from which go toward preparing young men and women for life after high school.  The money you give will go toward:

  • Scholarships for students
  • Providing supplies for WV Foundation community events
  • Marketing efforts

YOUR IMPACT

Through your donations you will be contributing to:

Money for students to go to college

Create internship opportunities for students

Promote health and wellness in the community

Allow under-privileged people to receive college educations

Contribute to exciting, safe, and fun events for the whole family

OTHERS WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you are not able to contribute at one of the levels through this campaign, you can still help by:

  • Telling your friends and sharing this campaign
  • Lend a helping hand at a WVF event
  • Come out and support the wellness fair, WV day, and all-star game
  • Provide internship opportunities through your company for WV students
  • Contact us at Terrence@thewvfoundation.org for additional in-kind sponsorship opportunities.
  • Click and ‘Like’ our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/MuskegonAllStarClassic or follow us on twitter @MuskegonClassic
  • Check out our website www.thewvfoundation.org
story_txt:
WHO WE ARENick VandenBosch, D.O. and I (Terrence (TJ) Williams) are recent graduates of medical school and law school respectively.  After graduating in 2011, we decided that we wanted to reach back a helping hand and help pull the next generation up.  We decided to launch The WV Foundation (WVF) in 2012 with the intention of producing fun, exciting, family-friendly events, and using the proceeds to offer opportunities of higher education and exciting life experience for the youth in our communities.  In seeking assistance in launching the WVF  we were faced with many people telling us to “wait until we were more settled in our careers to try to do this”, and when we said our goal for the first year was to award $10,000 in scholarship we were told we needed to “crawl before we could walk”.  We are proud to say that we have awarded nearly $25,000 in scholarships since 2012. WHAT WE NEEDWe need help in funding our annual Scholarship Program and Community growth initiatives, the proceeds from which go toward preparing young men and women for life after high school.  The money you give will go toward:
Scholarships for students
Providing supplies for WV Foundation community events
Marketing efforts
YOUR IMPACTThrough your donations you will be contributing to:Money for students to go to collegeCreate internship opportunities for studentsPromote health and wellness in the communityAllow under-privileged people to receive college educationsContribute to exciting, safe, and fun events for the whole familyOTHERS WAYS YOU CAN HELPEven if you are not able to contribute at one of the levels through this campaign, you can still help by:
Telling your friends and sharing this campaign
Lend a helping hand at a WVF event
Come out and support the wellness fair, WV day, and all-star game
Provide internship opportunities through your company for WV students
Contact us at Terrence@thewvfoundation.org for additional in-kind sponsorship opportunities.
Click and ‘Like’ our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/MuskegonAllStarClassic or follow us on twitter @MuskegonClassic
Check out our website www.thewvfoundation.org

story:
Short Summary

→ Only 7% of high school students in the US are financially literate 

→ Deficiencies in financial acumen and discipline lead to poor decisions: on average, young adults collect debt of $45,000 

→ Just 1/3rd of young adults think they can be financially independent by the age of 29

We believe there are two primary reasons that countless young Americans are financially illiterate:

  • They aren't taught financial principals in school
  • They aren't taught in an way they understand

Solution

Common Cents is a unique solution to the financial literacy problem. We are designing an engaging game for students that conveys financial principals through simulated experiences. As the student progresses through the lessons and examples, they are rewarded for sound financial understanding demonstrated via in-game decisions. By positively reinforcing good choices with material rewards, we will foster an environment for students to develop strong financial habits.

Specifically, the game is a story line that takes a student through the financial decisions that they will make in their life and the challenges associated with those decisions. 

Step 1

  • Create account (Facebook Signup)
  • Choose a character (high school senior)
  • Embark on Life Journey
Step 2

  • Start Financial Tutorials based on life decisions
  • First Tutorial: Getting a part time job
  • Second Tutorial: Opening a checking account
  • Third Tutorial: Balancing a checkbook
  • X Tutorial:
Step 3

  • Earn rewards based on achievements 
  • Example: Get discounts to favorite retailers/restaurants by passing sponsored challenges
  • Redeem in-game dollars for rewards
The lessons learned from our game will translate into real life results for students. The goal is to show discernible improvement in financial literacy scores in the school districts were the game is implemented. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $25,000 to fund the development of the game. In order to make this game engaging for students, we need to create stimulating content and refine our curriculum. We have a team of developers, designers, educators, and financial professionals working to generate the content. 

Your support is greatly appreciated. To show our appreciation, we have designated several perks depending on the level of your financial commitment to the financial literacy cause. 

The Impact

Our game has the potential to impact the lives of thousands of students that use our game. Common Cents will arm students with the financial acumen necessary to be successful adults. More importantly, it will aim to prevent students from making catastrophic financial decisions that could negatively impact their entire lives. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone can not provide financial backing for our idea. For the Common Cents team, any and all support is imperative to make our idea a reality and tackle financial illiteracy, especially in informing parents and schools about this exciting new resource. Please help us spread the word!

story:
Merry Christmas

Text in English und unten auf Deutsch

It is Christmas time once again. The first snow has fallen, Christmas decorations have been put out and surely you are enjoying beautiful Christmas markets. Probably you have bought the first Christmas presents, treated yourself to a nice pre-Christmas dinner or booked a nice holiday with the 13th month wages.


Here in Bolivia it is hard to imagine that Christmas is just around the corner. The rainy season has FINALLY begun, we needed to wait longer than expected for the first rain to moist the dried out land by the strong sun. The last weeks water has often been short, sometimes had been cut off for a couple of days.


I could or should also feel Christmassy here in Sucre, a small city in 2800m because globalization has also arrived in this town. Shops are decorated with reindeers and Santa clauses, the market stalls sells Christmas trees, lights and decorations, not to mention the amount of toys and gadgets. But here it hurts seeing these things, which I was so used to in Europe. Because I look around and see Antonio (14) on the street corner cleaning shoes of a client or José (9) and Luis (11) washing cars on the main square, Mario (8) and his little sister trying to sell black plastic shopping bags on the market, Luisa (5) sitting on the cold steps of market helping her mum to sell mangos. For them and so many other working children Christmas will be the same like any other day, maybe they will receive a bigger portion of dinner if they are lucky. But that is it.


I work with these children and adolescents who are supported by the educational centre Ñanta on a voluntary basis since February 2009, giving especially support in education as I am a teacher myself. To find out more about Ñanta´s work please check the website: http://www.centronanta.org


How you can help

With your Christmas donations we could buy the urgently required new desks, chairs and cupboards for the study room, we need new books. Some new paint would make to room look brighter and friendlier. We would love to buy new rucksacks and school materials for the coming term in February. Last year I also bought some sports equipment but of course 150 children using a football and basketball on a regular basis will make sure that it won´t last for many months. It would be wonderful to buy some new ones again. Furthermore not only the rent of our centre where we work have risen, but also water, electricity and food costs and it will be very hard to keep paying everything in 2012. Your donation would also help to keep our centre running well and smoothly.


Two days before Christmas also arrive the poorest of poorest in flocks from the surrounding countryside in hope to reach the heart of less poor people in the city. People from these communities often travel days to reach Sucre. In their areas water and electricity is still scarce, they life from local agriculture and farming. Local companies as well as my friends´ language school Fenix www.fenixbolivia.com start collecting weeks before to be able to help out. Everything is welcome: especially clothes, but also toys for the smallest children, food and school materials. Some might say, it is not right to give out presents and I agree normally – but it is Christmas and thanks to globalization everybody knows it´s Christmas!!! With your support I could buy clothes and school materials and we personally hand everything out through the school.


Please forward this link to your friends and relatives as well


Frohe Weihnachten

Die Weihnachtszeit ist wieder da. Der erste Schnee ist gefallen, die Weihnachtsdekoration schmückt Häuser und Straβen. Sicherlich genieβt du schon die wunderschönen Weihnachtsmärkte, hast die ersten Weihnachtsgeschenke gekauft und dir vielleicht eine Reise mit dem 13. Monatsgehalt gegönnt.


Hier in Bolivien ist es schwierig sich vorzustellen, dass in zwei Wochen Weihnachten sein wird. Die Regenzeit hat ENDLICH bei uns begonnen. Jedes Jahr müssen wir länger auf den so ersehnten Regen warten, denn die Erde ist schon seit Monaten durch die starke Sonneneinstrahlung verstrocknet. Wieder kam es soweit, dass mehrmals der Wasserzugang in den Häuern abgedreht wurde, manchmal sogar für einige Tage.


Ich sollte mich eigentlich auch in vorweihnachtlicher Stimmung fühlen, denn man kommt daran eigentlich gar nicht vorbei. Die Geschäfte sind hübsch dekoriert, an den Marktständen werden Plasteweihnachtsbäume, Lichterketten und Dekorationen verkauft, ganz zu schweigen von dem vielen Spielzeug. Aber es tut weh diese Dinge, die ich doch eigentlich von Europa gewöhnt bin, zu sehen. Denn ich sehe mich um und sehe meine kleinen Freunde Antonio (14) an der Straβenecke einem Kunden die Schuhe putzen, oder José (9) und Luis (11), die auf dem Marktplatz Autos waschen, Mario (8) und seine kleine Schwester, die versuchen schwarze Plastiktüten zu verkaufen, Luisa (5) sitzt auf den Treppen des Zentralmarktes und hilft ihrer Mutter beim Verkauf von frischen Mangos. Für sie wie auch viele andere arbeitende Kinder und Jugendliche wird Weihnachten wie jeder andere Tag sein, nur dass es vielleicht (man hoffe) ein bisschen mehr zu essen geben wird.


Ich arbeite mit einigen dieser Kinder und Jugendlichen, die durch das Bildungszentrum Ñanta unterstützt werden, auf ehrenamtlicher Basis, in der Regel im edukativen Bereich, da ich selbst Lehrerin bin. Mehr Informationen über Ñantas Arbeit findest du hier http://www.centronanta.org


Wie du helfen kannst

Mit deiner Weihnachtsspende könnten wir endlich die so dringend benötigten neuen Tische, Stühle und Schränke für den Arbeitsraum kaufen, wir brauchen neue Bücher. Ein bisschen neue Farbe würde das Zimmer heller und freundlicher wirken lassen. Wir könnten neue Schulrucksäcke und Schulmaterialien für das neue Schuljahr besorgen. Letztes Jahr kaufte ich neue Sportsausrüstung, aber wenn 150 Kinder einen Fuβ- oder Basketball regelmäβig benutzen, hält dieser natürlich nicht sehr lang. Gern würde ich neue anschaffen. Des Weiteren sind auch hier in Sucre die Mieten, Wasser-, Strom- und Lebensmittelpreise erheblich gestiegen. Es ist in diesen Zeiten noch schwieriger, ein solches Zentrum auch 2012 erfolgreich aufrecht zu erhalten. Deine Spende würde uns auch hier sehr zu Gute kommen!


Zwei Tage vor Weihnachten erreichen auch die ärmsten der armen vom Lande die Stadt, in der Hoffnung das Herz der nicht ganz so armen Bevölkerung der Stadt zu erwärmen. Die Landbevölkerung ist dafür oft Tage auf den Beinen, um Sucre zu erreichen. Dort, wo sie wohnen, gibt es oft nicht ausreichend Wasser und Elektizität, sie leben von der Landwirtschaft.


Die Mitarbeiter und meine Freunde der Sprachschule Fenix www.fenixbolivia.com sammeln daher jeder Jahr vor Weihnachten Spenden für diese Menschen und sind dankbar für jegliche Unterstützung. Mit deiner Unterstützung könnte auch ich Kleidung und Essen kaufen. Diese Dinge werden wir dann persönlich zu den Weihnachtstagen verteilen.


Bitte leite diesen Link auch an Freunde und Bekannte weiter


Thank you so much for your help! / Vielen Dank für deine Hilfe!
