story:
Update

Hello Everyone!  This is Isaac speaking to you.  Matt has made it safely home from Ghana and was successful in his mission to find awesome art products and artisans.   He was able to directly connect with the women who made the Bolga Baskets and offer them fair trade value.   Below is a picture of the inventory he brought back.


He was also able to connect with the Single Mothers Association in Bolgatanga and build good ties with them which might allow us to have these baskets shipped directly from them so we could continue to offer fair trade to the women of Ghana and awesome baskets to the people of America.  

So Good Job Matt!

Matt is currently working on writing up his experiences at the market and buying the Bolga Baskets (well actually he is currently cooking me some veggie burgers.. what a good friend) which we will share with you soon....the experiences....not the burgers... And Done.  You can check out his post if you click on the update tab. 

In the mean time check out some of the pictures from his trip!

Single Mothers Association who you are helping to support when you pledge to this campaign!

Ok, this picture isn't from Ghana. It's Isaac's new puppy Lea hanging out in what apparently is her new Bolga Basket.


Providing Fair Trade to Underprivileged Women in Northern Ghana

We need your help to aid these communities that are in desperate need.

In an already unprivileged country the women of Ghana aren't even allowed to own property. The men of the north take advantage of that by not allowing women to sell their products at market. Instead they must sell to the male shop owners at a fraction of the market price.

The Campaign:

By funding our campaign we will be able to purchase these amazing products from the women at a fair trade value (at least 2 to 3 times the amount currently offered) and bring them back to you. We will also be documenting our journey to show you how these products are made and what type of lives these artisans live.

With the extra money in their pockets, these women, most of them single with children, will be able to help provide for their families. They will be able to buy things like new shoes, school supplies and medications that are desperately needed.

… Oh and by the way did we mention the products are stunning... No Breathtaking...Amazing...Righteous...We can't decide on a word. You'll  just have to pick one.

Since the plane tickets have already been purchased your contributions will go directly to those in need and educating the public on these communities.

The funding of this project will go to:

  • $300 will go to being able to offer these women fair market trade value. As a general rule we will be offering the women twice to thrice the amount they receive from the local men.

  • $150 will go into transporting the goods back to America and shipping the goods to you.

  • $300 will go to making the various documentaries. This includes the purchase of memory cards, renting a camera and equipment and the editing process.

  • Any extra funding will go directly into our next fair trade mission.

Your contributions will help those who labor over their goods and are taken advantage of provide a better life for their family and community. Our main goal for future projects is to set up a steady shipping lane directly with the women so they can continue to receive fair market value for their awesome wares. Not only that but you will get some unique well made products that you can't find anywhere else!

The Products:

Calabash Gourds: The West African Shaker

Made from hollowed out baby plants and connected with either nylon or leather; these seed filled instruments have been used for thousands of years to keep beats and aid in outrageous dances.  

Cowrie Shell Necklace: The New Fashion

These shells, once used as currency themselves, are now fashioned into high quality necklaces by locals. They use a sturdy leather backing to keep the sewn on shells secure and to insure durability.

The Bolga-Basket: Bolgatastic

Matts Favorite! These handmade baskets are woven in the north and show a rich part of Ghanaian culture. Each is made to be durable, malleable, and unique in design.

Excited to be a part of this campaign and obtain these funkadelic products?  Then Pledge Now!

Here is the story on how the idea of this campaign began:

The idea for this Indiegogo campaign began last year when I decided to travel to Ghana with one of my theatre professors. In Ghanaian culture, history is often taught though the use of verbal stories passed down from one generation to the next. Unfortunately the crucial role women have played in the history and growth of the Ghanaian culture is often downplayed or left out altogether. Ghanaian women of this generation are still left out of decision making, fair wages, and many other roles while still performing much of the day to day duties of society.

While there we travelled the country from the capitol of Accra in the south to the small village of Bolgatanga in the north. We listened and learned from the locals of their traditions and culture. By using these ideas and themes we have written our own stories to not only accent the role of women but to show the importance of gender equality and social justice. Next month I will be returning to Ghana with my professor as well as 5 other actors and storytellers to perform these skits, stories, music, and dances. Our hope is that new generations will learn these new stories and be providedawith knowledge and support to work toward an equal and fair life for both genders.

The Single Women's Association of Bolgatanga.

It was during this time last year I came across many of the interesting and cool products that were not only well crafted, but had a vibrant and rich history behind them. Unfortunately the profit from these products; which often help to support families and communities; are not going to those who deserve it. The women artisans are often forced to sell their products to local men for a fraction of the market price. Instead of buying from the men I often would make purchases from the women to support their business.

Then while competing in an international rock paper scissors competition over Skype, a friend noticed my Cowrie Shell Necklace and thought it was so cool he had to have one for himself. After returning home many of my friends and family began asking about the different products I had brought back.

I then realized that I had a great opportunity to provide two things:

  1. Bring unique products and cultures back to the people in America.
  2. Help boost the local economies by providing fair trade to the women who labor and create these products.

In order to combine these two points I will also be documenting my time in Ghana with personal interviews and footage of the work put into these amazing items. It is our hope that by sharing the culture and inequalities throughout Ghana that we can understand and promote equality not only here but around the globe.

Matt and Isaac looking Super Fly.

editing process.




	Any
	extra funding will go directly into our next fair trade mission.



Your
contributions will help those who labor over their goods and are
taken advantage of provide a better life for their family and
community.  Our main goal for future projects is to set up a steady shipping
lane directly with the women so they can continue to receive fair
market value for their awesome wares. Not only that but you will get
some unique well made products that you can't find anywhere else!
The
Products:
Calabash
Gourds: The West African Shaker

Made
from hollowed out baby plants and connected with either nylon or
leather; these seed filled instruments have been used for thousands
of years to keep beats and aid in outrageous dances.  

Cowrie
Shell Necklace: The New Fashion

These shells, once used as currency themselves, are now fashioned into high
quality necklaces by locals. They use a sturdy leather backing to
keep the sewn on shells secure and to insure durability.
The
Bolga-Basket: Bolgatastic

Matts
Favorite! These handmade baskets are woven in the north and show a
rich part of Ghanaian culture. Each is made to be durable, malleable,
and unique in design.Excited to be a part of this campaign and obtain these funkadelic products?  Then Pledge Now!




Here
is the story on how the idea of this campaign began:

The
idea for this Indiegogo campaign began last year when I decided to
travel to Ghana with one of my theatre professors. In Ghanaian
culture, history is often taught though the use of verbal stories
passed down from one generation to the next. Unfortunately the
crucial role women have played in the history and growth of the
Ghanaian culture is often downplayed or left out altogether. Ghanaian
women of this generation are still left out of decision making, fair
wages, and many other roles while still performing much of the day to
day duties of society.

While
there we travelled the country from the capitol of Accra in the south
to the small village of Bolgatanga in the north. We listened and
learned from the locals of  their traditions and culture. By using
these ideas and themes we have written our own stories to not only
accent the role of women but to show the importance of gender
equality and social justice. Next month I will be returning to Ghana
with my professor as well as 5 other actors and storytellers to
perform these skits, stories, music, and dances. Our hope is that new
generations will learn these new stories and be providedawith
knowledge and support to work toward an equal and fair life for both
genders.
The Single Women's Association of Bolgatanga.
It
was during this time last year I came across many of the interesting
and cool products that were not only well crafted, but had a vibrant
and rich history behind them. Unfortunately the profit from these
products; which often help to support families and communities; are
not going to those who deserve it. The women artisans are often
forced to sell their products to local men for a fraction of the
market price. Instead of buying from the men I often would make
purchases from the women to support their business.

Then
while competing in an international rock paper scissors competition
over Skype, a friend noticed my Cowrie Shell Necklace and thought it
was so cool he had to have one for himself. After returning home many of my
friends and family began asking about the different products I had
brought back.

I
then realized that I had a great opportunity to provide two things:

Bring unique
products and cultures back to the people in America.
Help boost the local economies by providing fair trade to the
women who labor and create these products.


In
order to combine these two points I will also be documenting my time
in Ghana with personal interviews and footage of the work put into
these amazing items. It is our hope that by sharing the culture and
inequalities throughout Ghana that we can understand and promote
equality not only here but around the globe.Matt and Isaac looking Super Fly.

story:
Who We Are

We are the Community College of Aurora, a community of 13,000 students representing five continents and over 60 different countries. Many of us are the first in our families to attend college and most of us need aid to afford college. We are rich in curiosity and our commitment to world peace, justice, lifting the voices of the un- or under-represented, finding common ground, and enabling all peoples globally to live free of war and oppression. We are not, however, rich in resources -- which is why we need your help.

We are raising money to send a delegation of 13 students and 2 advisors to the National Model United Nations Conference in New York City in March 2015. We will be the only community college from Colorado to attend the national conference and one of only a handful of two-year schools nationally. We bring an important voice to the national conference--a voice that rarely has the means and opportunity to participate. We are excited to raise our voices, learn, grow, and achieve in New York City.

What We Need 

We are raising at least $15,000 to cover the registration, travel, and hotel costs of our student delegation to attend the national conference. Our goal is to send 13 students. For every $2,043 we raise above our campaign goal, we will add one additional student to our delegation. We raised $10,543 toward our goal prior to launching this campaign.  Please help us raise the balance of funds needed for our delegation.  Your donation is tax deductible.

The Impact

This really is a life changing event for us. For an entire week we will be diplomats on the world's stage--at the actual United Nations headquarters. We will not simply be role-playing, but will engage in real-world political dialogues, meet with UN personnel and diplomats, and interact with thousands of college students from around the world. Help us join the ranks of famous Model UN alumni like US Supreme Court Justice Steven Breyer, UN Secretary General Ban Ki Moon, and Chelsea Clinton. We are embarking on an eight-month journey of hard work, academic rigor, and sacrifice to prepare for the national conference and sincerely hope you will join us in our journey by contributing today.   

    Other Ways You Can Help

    In addition to donating to our campaign, you can help by spreading the word on Facebook, Twitter, email, at dinner or over drinks, and encourage your family and friends to donate. 

    Here's a message and photo you can use:  Help CCA students become the only Colorado community college students to attend the Model United Nations in New York City: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/cca-model-un 


    Press

    CCA's Model UN is in the news:

    ·  http://www.ccaurora.edu/students/support-services/library/model-united-nations-resources

    ·  http://www.ccaurora.edu/news-events/news-releases/model-united-nations

    ·  http://www.9news.com/story/local/2013/04/05/1853200/

    · http://www.ccaurora.edu/sites/default/files/cca_files/file/News%20and%20Events/InterComs/april2014intercom.pdf

    Corporate Sponsors

    Thank you to the following organizations that have committed to help underwrite the costs of this project.  We are excited to add you to the list.

    Community Banks of Colorado

    Community College of Aurora

    Jeppesen

story:
www.selwynschool.com

Selwyn School is a private, non-profit school of 150 students from Early Childhood - Grade 12. For over fifty years it has provided a high-quality education for students from Denton and surrounding communities and beyond.

The fire that tore through the main building early Thursday, Jan. 26, destroyed everything in the Music, Art, and Kindergarten through Grade 5 classrooms; the Administrative and Business offices; and kitchen. 

Even though this fire was financially devastating, this tragedy has brought students, parents and alumni together to share their grief at this loss, to help clean up the campus and move forward rebuilding our school....one brick at a time. As a result of this strong community bond, the students and faculty resumed school within a few days of the fire.

Please help us spread the word so that our school can rebuild, and continue to educate our wonderful family of students.

What We Need

It would just be a beautiful gift for Selwyn if someone would help us.

  • We need financial support to replace the lower school building, replace technology and furniture, and promote our business before the start of school.
  • We are pursuing architects and will be using the money we receive from insurance but our building was over 50 years old. It will cost more to replace the items lost.
  • These funds will go towards: textbooks, classroom libraries, kitchen supplies
    and equipment and all the supples and furnishings in the administrative and
    business offices. Every little bit will help us continue to provide a valuable
    service for the community and our students, so even $1 will help.

The Impact

Your contribution will make an impact in helping us replace primarily educational classroom space, but also other essential requirements. Unfortunately, insurance proceeds won't cover the entire cost for a new building, or all our supplies lost in the fire.

  • Every teacher lost entire classrooms including furniture, classroom and personal libraries, textbooks, and technology
  • Art and Music teachers lost entire classroom of art supplies and musical instruments
  • Ten thousand square feet of furniture, electronic equipment, kitchen supplies, textbooks, science materials, and irreplaceable memories - photographs, transcripts, etc.

We are not just building a school building, we are providing an environment where children are going to grow and develop into leaders and contributors.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support our cause monetarily, we would be more than appreciative if you could share our project via any means possible, whether it be word of mouth, or through some form of social network. Spread the word! Please use the tools located directly under the video to share our story with your friends and family. Any assistance in our campaign would be greatly appreciated.

"One is too small a number to achieve greatness." - Dr. John C. Maxwell

story:
Our Story

After nearly 4 years of developing the Aloha Movement Project 501c3 and the AMP "Education Energy" Program, Jonathan Fritzler has been nominated to attend the United Nations World Youth Congress in June of 2012. As a representative the United States of America and an ambassador of Hawaii, Jonathan will be given the opportunity to speak to hundreds of young leaders from around the world, and share his vision of how AMP will transform higher education, and the world. 

 

As a keynote speaker, he will empower students to reconsider the real value of their "Education Energy" and share his message of how students school projects can be implemented in the real world to have a positive impact in their communities.  His workshop will encourage students to "Plant an AMP" within their university, and join a world wide movement of students who implement positive change.

 

"He has been selected among thousands of applicants for his motivation and interest in the Rio+20 Summit, his cultural values, and his active commitment to his community to build a sustainable future and the green economy" - Roberto Vamos, Executive Director, World Youth Congress.

 

The Impact

Be a part of the Aloha Movement Project's first international outreach: AMP South America! The cAMPus cAMPaign is designed to change the paradigm of higher education, and empower students to become peace leaders and social entrepreneurs. In South America the youth often face the challenge of finding viable means of financial support for their families, resulting in students leaving school early to work and support their families. Jonathan Fritzler is on a a mission to spread the AMP Movement to student activists, social entrepreneurs, innovators, and revolutionaries. His book "Plant an AMP" will help students realize where opportunities exist within the university and how to utilize all the resources available to create positive change in their local communities. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Before Jonathan departs on his journey, he plans to hire the best webdesigners to build a bullet proof web platform designed to unite students across the world (est. $10,000). In June of 2012, Jonathan will embark on a journey to Rio De Janeiro. Our first expense is the plane ticket for $1,800. The UN will cover all ground expenses including food, lodging, and transportation once he arrives in Brazil. Upon completion of the World Youth Congress, Jonathan will tour to Universities across Brazil on his first official cAMPus cAMPaign. $2,000 of the funding will cover travel, accommodation, and food while he tours with a team of Spanish and Portugese speaking AMPtivists. $2000 will provide Fritzler with the ability to launch his cAMPaign to media outlets in target cities, and host events which will feature an empowering presentation, music, and food. The remaining $7,000 will cover the cost of travel, accomodation, food, and cAMPaign expenses in the United States as he tours to schools, summer camps, churches, and festivals which match our mission. The remaining $2000 cover the Indigogo Fees. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

CALL TO ACTION: "Plant an AMP" 

AMP is reaching out to university and high school students across the world! "Plant an AMP in your school and join a global network of student innovators who harness "Education Energy" as a renewable resource for positive change!

 

SPREAD THE WORD!!

Watch the TED Talk: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jE0-fYh68FU

Like our Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/alohamovementproject

Follow us on Twitter: twitter.com/Aloha_AMP

Check out our website: AlohaMovementProject.com

story:
St. John's is not only the place of worship for many members of the Rockaway community, but its also a community center with day care, after school programs, baseball teams and more. The day care center alone served ~50 children until Hurricane Sandy flood damage destroyed it. The loss of the center and the church’s services created devastating ripples throughout the tightly knit community. It is imperative that this center of one of Rockaway Beach's communities is opened again as soon as possible.

During the week of March 17-23, ten college students spent their Spring Break helping clear away some of the damage done to Rockaway Beach, NY during Hurricane Sandy. During their time there, these young individuals found that it was not merely a week of volunteerism, but rather a life-altering experience that they would never forget.

 The students who worked at St’ John’s have committed to raising at least $15,000 to help revive this center of the community.

 The students traveled from all over the country, including longer distances like California, Utah,Missouri, etc., unsure of what to expect in Hurricane Sandy-affected areas. They were shocked to see how much work was left to be done in places like St. John's Baptist Church. Many around the country remain unaware of the amount of damage that still lies untouched in many parts of New York and New Jersey.

 While the volunteers finished an amazing amount of work during their time in Rockaway, much more is left to be done. They were able to clear out two of the bathrooms and kitchen that once held 7 feet of water, however, extra steps must be taken to make the building habitable again.

 Mold remediation, a process that will ensure that no one using the building again will become ill due to flood damage, costs about $10,000. After this process is completed, upwards of $25,000 will be necessary to fix the plumbing and electricity alone.

This church is not merely a place of worship; it is a thriving center that ties the diverse community in Rockaway Beach together. The people have lived through the storm, and now helping each other recover, are heroes. Even though entire neighborhoods have been devastated,many are working tirelessly each day. We’re asking you to fight alongside them.

Regardless of your religious affiliation or personal beliefs, help us bring this symbol of hopeand safety back on its feet. Although we are not all part of the Rockaway or even Christian community, we are all human, and each of us deserve a safe, joyful gathering place.

Please give what you can. We believe it's the way we come together as a whole that inspires the world. With your help, St. John's Baptist Church will be able to truly reflect the passion and hope of the people working to rebuild it.

 

Sincerely,

 

Ten college students who believe they can change the world for the better.

story:
RISING CITY ARTS is a Queens, New York based Theater Arts in Education organization dedicated to providing youth of all ages with alternative educational strategies through artistic expression.

Our mission is to help students develop a healthy relationship to self, others and nature.  With our uniquely designed theatrical programs, we enhance a child’s ability to peacefully solve problems, make informed choices, collaborate effectively with others and appreciate the importance of creative play. 

The Rising City Arts Team reaches nearly 600 children each year with the joys of live theater.

For the past two years, one of our favorite residencies, “All About Acting”, had been alive and well at The High School of Applied Communication in LIC, Queens. However, due to the recent Department of Education budget cuts, we are about to be brought to a dramatic, grinding halt before our culminating project. A production of a published play with sets, costumes, make-up, tech/dress rehearsals and two performances is our ultimate goal. For the past two years, it has been the crowning achievement for these eager High School of Applied Communication teens and teachers who have committed to theatre-making, grown as creative thinkers and connected like an ensemble of true artists.  

Please support Rising City Arts and the teens of the High School of Applied Communication. Help them build theater and their dreams for a better future.

 All funds raised will be distributed among the following:

  • Teaching Artist and Theatrical Designer Salaries
  • Props, Costumes, Lighting
  • Supplies - scripts and copies of teaching materials
  • Rights to whatever play we choose
  • Programs for the show
  • and Operating Expenses

 

From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you!

Dina Comolli & Julian Rozzell

Rising City Arts, Theatre for Youth

story:
Your contribution will go directly to supporting campus E2C2 teams and their work to get tobacco off of their campuses for good! Your donations will directly contribute to:

  1.  Smoke-free and tobacco-free residences
  2. Outdoor Designated Smoking Areas, or if feasible, a 100% smoke and tobacco-free campus
  3. A ban on Tobacco advertising, promotion and sales on campus
  4. The provision and promotion of cessation resources and services to all students, faculty and staff
  5. A ban on tobacco industry funding for research projects, grants, student scholarships and any other type of arrangement or association
  6. A ban on companies that sell tobacco participating in campus fairs or other recruitment activities
  7. The divestment of tobacco industry stock by the education institution.

Key steps identified in The Tobacco Free Campus Action Plan developed by the Non-Smokers Rights Associations in 2011.

             

Why Now?

Student teams are engaged and ready to act on 5 major campuses across Ontario: 

  • Carleton University
  • Lakehead University
  • McMaster University
  • Queen's University
  • University of Toronto

                 

Skilled and motivated, these E2C2 teams have been working as a part of the healthy campus movement and in cancer control initiatives for the past year. In this short time they have made great strides towards cancer control and making their university campuses healthier environments for students. 

This work has identified a major gap concerning the presence of tobacco on Canadian university campuses. 

                

                                       

The presence of tobacco on campus is a major but changeable barrier to creating a healthy campus environment. Students have decided to bring the tobacco free campus movement to Canada, and making Canadian campuses tobacco free one of their major focuses.

Canada is behind and it's time to catch up!


Why We Can Do This

E2C2 teams have gained skills in lobbying, policy change and health promotion on each of their respective campuses. Major victories to date include collaborating to develop World Cancer Day event featuring major global leaders in cancer control (more info here, link) and more recently lobbying and successfully removing tanning beds from the Queen’s University campus. 

          

Some major victories to date include collaborating to develop World Cancer Day event featuring major global leaders in cancer control (more info here, link) and more recently lobbying and successfully removing tanning beds from the Queen’s University campus. 

You can find more information on the E2C2 teams and their other initiatives HERE.

                     


Perks

Name: Throw a Butt In                 

Amount: C$ 1.00

Description: Really want to help but don't have much money to spare? No problem! Donating a butt for a buck can make a huge difference. Every little bit counts! You can help even more by sharing this campaign with your friends http://bit.ly/14AphGC. 


Name: A Pack of Smokes

                                         

Amount: C$ 10.00 +

Description: In Ontario, 20-24 year olds have the higher prevalence of smoking compared to all other age groups. With you help WE CAN reduce this number. Donate a pack of smokes today!


Name: Smoke Break

Amount: C$ 15.00 +

Description: In Ontario, 20-24 year olds have the highest prevalence of smoking compared to all other age groups. With your help WE CAN reduce this number. Donate a pack of smokes today!


Name: A Breath of Fresh Air

Amount: C$ 50.00 +

Description: By donating $50 or more, you are helping to give students on campus the clean fresh air they deserve. Cause in university, students already have enough to worry about. Smoke filled air shouldn't be on their list.


Name: Wear Your Support

Amount: C$ 75.00+

Description: Donating $75 + or more means so much to us, that we want to give you a way to wear your support. Donations of $75 or more will receive a Cancer Control t-shirt (featured in the above description). Get yours while quantities last!

story:
These days, the competition to get accepted into some of the most academically competitive colleges in the United States is more cut throat than ever. Good grades, impressive SAT scores, and involvement in school activities are no longer enough to grab the attention of that certain college’s eye. Students need to up their game to gain the advantage that will get them right where they want to be when applying for colleges, whether it be from taking high level AP courses to engaging in nationwide scholastic competitions.

                With all this being said, I recently began to run out of ideas of things I could do to up my game and make me standout when applying to the colleges I hope to attend. As a rising high school senior, it seemed as if my time to participate in extra academic experiences was running out. However, an opportunity recently fell into my lap that sounded too good to be true! This academic enhancing opportunity is sponsored by People to People.  People to People is an organization that provides student ambassador trips for high school and college students to help enhance student’s overall performance in life. Not only do these expeditions help give students the chance to immerse themselves in various cultures that differ from their own, but also provide high school and college credit. A once in a lifetime opportunity that would not only allow me to view the world from a different perspective but also provide me with real life knowledge and experiences that will enhance my college essays and applications? Sign me up!

                The trip I hope to be able to attend is the Winter Break 2013 Mediterranean Holiday Expedition to Barcelona and Rome. This trip would provide me with the chance to experience the traditional cultural experiences that I’ve learned about throughout my academic career along with participating in a hands-on experience that is meant to enhance my grasp of art, history, language, and architecture in various places of the globe. Academic wise, language is a subject I’m personally interested in, so this trip would provide me with the materials needed to help gain a different view on how languages affect certain cultural interactions as well as increase the level of interest my future college letters will soon need.

                To be able to walk where ancient gladiators once stood or stand in the presence of some of the most historically influential cities and landmarks throughout world history, such as the Vatican, would truly be a humbling and academically enhancing experience. Chances like this don’t come along very often which is exactly why I’ve decided to let my guard down and educate myself on a whole new level! Any amount of donation would be very much appreciated, and any excess money that is not used towards this trip will be used for future college prep experiences. This trip will help shed light on the world that exists outside the United States along with giving me new profound global knowledge that colleges are looking for when accepting their applicants! If you’d like to know more information about this educational trip here is the link, http://www.peopletopeople.com/find-a-trip/all-p....  Thank you very much for the bottom of my heart for your participation!

story:
Who I am...

     Hello, my name is Ncamsile Vilakati. I am 23 years old and I live in Tshaneni, Swaziland, Africa. I was born in Hlathikhulu (in the Shiselweni region of Swaziland). Here are a few things you should know about me. Swaziland is a place where teenage pregnancies are very high and as a result many students drop out of school. I was the result of a teenage pregnancy and my mom didn’t know who the father was. It was not easy growing up without my mom or not knowing who my dad was. This affected me a great deal because growing up I had no sense of belonging. In Swaziland a child born outside of wedlock is not supposed to go with her mom to the new family. When I was young my mother married and started a new family and I was left home with my grandma. Even though my mother was working, she barely helped me financially. My grandmother treated me well but did not have much to give to me. I recently met my father in 2009, but he has no interest in getting to know me. He never calls and when I asked him to help with school fees for nursing school he said he’d rather use the money to fix his car. I moved to my current home with Make (siswati for mother) Sizakele in Tshaneni, in February 2012.

     Since moving to Tshaneni my life has seen major improvements. I finished secondary school and have been accepted to Good Shepherd College of Nursing. However, Make Sizakele cannot afford to pay my school fees as she is currently supporting four other children and is a single mother. She has done what she can and I am very thankful for her help. This is the first time in my life that I feel like I have a purpose and a chance to fulfill my dream of going to nursing school. Despite not receiving help from my real family, I refuse to give up on my dream. Through the help of some friends and family I was able to pay the initial school fees but they were over a month late. If I do not fundraise the money soon, I will lose my place at the college and possibly my last real chance of making my life better for myself. I am ambitious, hard working, and willing to do anything to get a better education. My goal is to fundraise the necessary school fees (4000 USD) for nursing school. The $4000 will pay for my two year program. Raising the money enables me, with your help, to continue my dream and gives me a fresh start for my future. When I’m not thinking about school, I enjoy going to church, singing in the choir and spending time with my family (Make Sizakele and her children). I thank God for the life He has given me and I am determined to make a better life for myself.

(Below: Ncamsile with Make Siza)

Where will the money go?


*USD = U.S. Dollar / E = Emalangeni (currency used in Swaziland)

Here is the breakdown of the $4000 USD:

School fees: 18,500E (1,850 USD) for first year

                     18,500E (1,850 USD) for second year

                        3000E (300 USD) will go towards miscellaneous costs which  are detailed below

Any extra money fundraised will go towards the following:

Rent: 1,200E per month (x12) = 14,400E (1,440 USD)

Laptop: 4,000E (400 USD)

Food: 750E per month (x12) = 9600E (960 USD)

Transportation: 2000E (for school travel for whole year) [200 USD]

Total expenses for year 1: 30,000E (3,000 USD)

Total: expenses for year 2: 26,000E (2,600 USD)

Total expenses for 2 years (Year 1 + Year 2) = 56,000E (5,600 USD)

School Fees (37,000E) + Secondary living expenses (56,000E) = 93,000E (9,300 USD) *This covers 2 years of schooling and basic needs

Why invest in my future?

By making a donation, no matter how big or small, you can make my dream that much more a reality. Words cannot express how much your donations mean to me. By investing in me, you are investing in Swaziland’s urgent need for medically trained professionals who can combat HIV/AIDS and other illnesses effecting the country. Your help enables me to give back to members of my community, especially those who are living in rural Swaziland. Donating gives me a chance, that very few girls in Africa get – a chance to fulfill your dream. You will not regret investing in me because I promise I will work hard to make a difference in my life as well as the lives of my family. Actually I have a big vision for myself. I want to be successful so I can be a provider and take care of my family so they won’t have to worry about anything. I promise you won’t regret helping me.

What do you get out of this? (A Personal Appeal from Kevin)

Dear friends and family back home, I want to personally thank you for investing your time in a campaign that is very dear my heart. Even if you can’t donate personally, spreading the word is extremely important. Why donate? Because your donation, no matter how big or small, is an  affirmation to a special woman who has been neglected and ignored her entire life, that in spite of all of her suffering, that there are people out there who believe in her ability to be successful. The power to believe in our own abilities is limitless and can help us achieve our potential. Ncamsile is a young woman who believes in herself, and with a little help will accomplish her goal to become a nurse. Ngiyabonga kakhulu (Thank you very much).

story:
Startup Exchange is a student-run organization based out of a tiny room in the Georgia Tech Library. This is a hub for entrepreneurship and ideation. A connection space. A home for student designers, coders, businessmen, and ideators to begin something together. This space cultivates thought-leadership, community, and a desire for learning. It creates cultures to inspire collaboration, problem-solving, and a deep rooted sense of humility.

We believe that Georgia Tech’s entrepreneurial renaissance will begin in this tiny tiny room of the Library. Here’s to the Institute. To Atlanta. And to the exchange of ideas. Let’s bring 3DS to Atlanta for the second year in a row!

Here's what we do at Startup Exchange:  

1)  Launched an incubation space for student entrepreneurs at Georgia Tech. Over 70+ members. We've hosted workshops on design thinking, business model canvas, customer discovery, and introduced students to the resources in Atlanta’s startup community. We've gone out on field trips to Hypepotamus and the Atlanta Tech Village. We even have street cred from Venture Atlanta, and an article about us that made it to the top of Hacker News.

2)  Run a startup accelerator program. In Fall 2012, we coordinated a pilot program to simulate the conditions of a rigorous startup accelerator. It provided ten student teams with structure, mentorship, and curriculum on the business model canvas. By the end of 10 weeks, the program made it to Hacker News and was praised in the blog posts of the Atlanta Startup Community. The Results: 10 teams, 10 weeks, 3 really cool stories. One interviewed with Y-Combinator, another pitched at Startup Riot, and a third went the finals of the Inventure Prize.

This Fall we’re doing it again, and we’re expanding the program to students at Georgia State!

3)  Coordinated 3DS last Fall. We had 55 people from 8 different colleges come together to form 10 startup teams over the course of a weekend. Over 20 mentors dropped in this weekend. We had RedBull girls, the Startup Bus, the late night shenanigans as promised (you know who you are) and concluded with a Hypepotamus Harlem Shake. It was epically legendary. Here's a recap.

We’re doing it again this Fall and we want it to be bigger and better than last year!

4)  Collectively, the entrepreneurs of Startup Exchange are working on 50+ startups. From apps and software to digital media and ecommerce, our student entrepreneurs are the best and the brightest who want to show Silicon Valley what it means to be a startup community with a touch of southern hospitality.

WHAT IS 3DS?

3 Day Startup is an entrepreneurship education program designed for university students with an emphasis on learning by doing. The idea is simple: start tech companies over the course of three days.

Last October, Startup Exchange helped bring Atlanta its first 3 Day Startup Weekend. This is a 48-hour energy drink-fueled intense weekend program that gives students the opportunity to develop their startup muscles.

Starting Friday evening, September 27th, the students form teams and begin brainstorming ideas. Saturday, they hit the ground running, turning these ideas into business models. The teams work day and night Saturday, only stopping for food and Redbull breaks. They polish their business plans and pitches on Sunday in preparation for the pitch competition Sunday night in front of their friends, families, and judges.

With your help, we can make this 3DS better than last year!

THE IMPACT YOUR CONTRIBUTION MAKES

Bringing 3DS to Atlanta will allow students from all over the Southeast to get a taste of the startup life. The excitement. The passion. The hard work. The sleep deprivation. The lifelong friendships The 3DS will immerse students in the startup world for 48-hours… Let’s give these students a chance to feel what we, in the Atlanta Startup Community, feel on a daily basis.

Here are the costs of bringing 3DS to Atlanta:

1.  Event Fee: $2000

2.  Free Event Space: Courtesy of Hypepotamus

3.  Food: $2000

4.  Startup Exchange Swag: $1000

Our goal is to raise $5000 for this event. We are expecting around 50 students and 10 mentors. Please help us bring this event to Atlanta so we can continue improving our startup community.

We are also trying to raise additional funds for Startup Exchange. If you are interested becoming a corporate sponsor, please contact us for more details. 

Every dollar you donate pushes us forward as entrepreneurs, and as a community. We sincerely appreciate your help.

improving our startup community. 
We are also trying to raise additional funds for Startup Exchange. If you are interested becoming a corporate sponsor, please contact us for more details. 
Every dollar you donate pushes us forward as entrepreneurs, and
as a community. We sincerely appreciate your help.

story:
Short Summary

Presentation

The Miragoane Association of teachers of English (MATE-TESOL) was founded in 2003 as a professional community for EFL teachers, educators, researchers, administrators, and students committed to enhancing English language teaching and learning in Haiti. MATE fosters exchange of ideas, professional networking and peer-to-peer knowledge, while providing resources, expertise, and professional educational guidance on issues affecting this field. MATE, through TESOL International Association, engages and trains thousands of secondary education public school English language teachers in Haiti. For its 9th Annual Affiliate Conference to be held in August 2013, MATE will be the host of an American keynote speaker from TESOL. This year the focus will be on Global Trends in English Language Learning and their implications for English Language Teachers.

English is hugely important as an international language and plays an important part in different countries. It is learned as the principal foreign language in most schools in Western Europe. It is also an essential part of the curriculum in far-flung places like Japan and South Korea, and is increasingly seen as desirable by millions of speakers in China.      

With the fast-paced changes brought about by globalization and technological development, TESOL professionals need to understand current socioeconomic factors and their influence on English language teaching (ELT). The industrial societies of the past are giving way to a new postindustrial economic order based on globalized manufacturing and distribution; flexible, customized production; the application of science, technology, and information management as the key elements of productivity and economy growth; and increased inequality between those who control technological and media resources and those who lack technological access.

 Objective

The principal objective of the 9th Annual Affiliate Conference is to provide needs-based professional development for TESOL teachers in Haiti. This conference focuses on promoting an understanding of the impact of the English language in an era of changing global economy and technological development and the role of TESOL instructors in facilitating students’ conceptual understanding of such impact.

 MATE TESOL promotes best teaching practices in the English language education. Within the framework of this conference, effective professional development will

  • improve and increase teachers’ knowledge of methodologies used in the teaching of English in the twenty first century;
  • give teachers the knowledge and skills to provide students with the opportunity to use technologies that are accessible to students to enhance fluency;
  • advance teacher understanding of effective instructional strategies;
  • align with and directly related to global trends in English language learning;

In order to increase practitioner’s content knowledge and pedagogical skills, and to cause increases in students’ English fluency, sessions are coded so that practitioners can schedule a series of sessions designed to provide intensive professional development within a focus strand.

Participants

An estimated number of TESOL instructors from different regions of the country are expected to participate in the conferences. 

Session Format

All presentations are expected to provide well-planned, interactive, and meaningful experience for practitioners. Handouts are required and may be subject to review.

Seminar/Demo: Workshop content will be presented in a two hour lecture format.

Workshop Hands-On: These sessions are designed to be fully interactive with the audience and

facilitate the audience in gaining material, hands-on knowledge around the given topic.

Panels: Consist of 3-4 presenters who are coordinating their presentations around a central theme. Each presentation will be 15-20 minutes in length.

Abstract of key Presentations:

Teaching English as a global language

The field of English Language continues to be deeply shaped by economic, social and technological changes happening on a global scale. For instance, English has taken on a prominent role in science, economics and diplomacy.   In under-resourced countries, English proficiency is often seen as a vehicle to social mobility.  As a result, an increasing number of countries have implemented educational policies that seek to teach English language in early grades and use English as a medium of instruction.  In this session, participants will learn how these mega trends affect their profession and their classroom experiences.

Teaching English against all odds

What can Haitian teachers of English do to help their students overcome adversity and foster their academic and social achievement? Having grown up in a country where social and economic inequalities and the devastation of war were barriers to growth and education, Rosa Aronson will draw on her personal experience and research to discuss ways teachers can foster resilience among students and prepare them to become prosperous and productive global citizens in an interdependent world. 

 

Global English and Community Advancement

Globalization will result in the further spread of English as an international language and a shift of authority to nonnative speakers and dialects. Economic and employment trends will change the way English is used. Increasingly, nonnative speakers will need to use the language daily for presentation of complex ideas, international collaboration and negotiation, and location and critical interpretation of rapidly changing information. Information technologies will transform notions of literacy, making on-line navigation and research, interpretation and authoring of hypermedia, and synchronous and asynchronous on-line communication critical skills for learners of English. The above changes, taken together, will render ineffective curricula based strictly on syntactic or functional elements or narrowly defined tasks. Rather, project-based learning-incorporating situated practice and critical inquiry, and based on students' own cultural frameworks-will be required if students are to master the complex English literacy and communications skills required by the emerging informational economy and society. In this session, participants will understand the importance of adjusting their teaching to the needs of the local community.

 

Estimated Expenses

Food Costs                                                             $ 1500

 Advertisement / Printing & Postage Costs                  $ 800

Operating Expenditures / Services                              $ 3640

 

Total Estimated Expenses                                         $ 5940

 

Jean Frantzy Italien

International Advocacy Representative

President Founder & CEO

MATE TESOL Affiliate Haiti & USA

Italien_jeanfrantzy@yahoo.com

https://www.facebook.com/events/605562449468286/

story:
John Njoroge ~ RZIM.ORG, Facebook Page

Short Summary

My name is Ezra and Its My Calling to Proclaim His Truth and Grace of Salvation.  The Most Valuable Christmas Gift!!

The tickets cost: Round Trip Ticket from Atlanta to Nairobi, from December 1st to January 4th. Price is $2050.00. Round Trip from Nairobi to Lagos, Nigeria December 4th to December 9th is $981.00.  That is just for travel ~ I will be there for a month but will be accommodated for living but will need at least 500 for foods and travel necessaries.  This is for a grand total of 3,531.00.

The funds will be going to my Pay Pal account ~ If I don't reach my goal then I will use the funds to sign up for classes for apologetics.  

This will impact me by giving me an experience of traveling with one of Gods most influential apologist and evangelist John Njoroge with RZIM.ORG Ministries.

This will also be advertised as testimony to what the Lord is doing in this ministry of impacting lives by defending and sharing His Gospel and Good News to ALL His precious Creation! 

Word get in the way of my gratitude  ~ I Love you all! My earnest prayers are with you always for time and eternity by our most loving and powerful Saviour Jesus Christ Immanuel.

story:
We all know how awesome Ruth is, right? (Pretty darn awesome, yes, that's correct)

Well she's just been offered an equally awesome opportunity to be a part of a 75-person  Laussane consultation on Christians engaging in media - basically christians from around the world who are connected to media and who are also amazing leaders and generally super-awesome (which is totally Ruth).

But the thing is, it's in November, and she has to let them know in just over a week, so it's short notice, and will all add up to about $2500.

She was going to just say no, but I thought, well, it's her birthday in a couple of weeks,  and I reckon that there would be a bunch of people who would like to help her be a part of such an amazing opportunity to make incredible connections and just generally spread her awesomeness to the world!

If that's you, it would be so fantastic if you wanted to help Ruth take up this incredible, out of the blue opportunity to connect with media influencers from all over the world! 

It's a short time-frame, I know, so if we don't raise the necessary funds, all donations are returned to you guys! But I totally think we can make it happen, what do you think?

Let's send Ruth to LA! :)
